column4: Answers
column5: api_response

column3: What distinguishes Novak Djokovic from his contemporaries?
column4:
He came from nothing. By the time he was 13 years old, he'd already gone through two wars between 1991 and 1999. The few tennis courts that Serbia had at the time were bombed to dust, including his favorite court on Mount Kopaonik, where he was first introduced to the sport.

It's not easy, as a kid, being hungry most of the time, losing your loved ones and watching your dreams and birthplace get shattered. Poverty was a problem as well as his country‚Äôs banned passport, so he couldn't travel to train on a higher level or compete as a youngster. That was a serious disadvantage right at the beginning.

Luckily for Novak, things started to change a bit and he was allowed to go abroad to foreign tennis academies. Before that he trained in empty swimming pools. His first coach and tennis Mom, Jelena Gencic who also taught Monica Seles, sent him to Nikola Piliƒá, an ex player and doubles grand slam champion, who had an academy of his own in M√ºnich, Germany. This is where Novak met players like Ernest Gulbis, Gilles Simon and many other prospects. The famous Goran Ivanisevic and Michael Stich, former Wimbledon champions, also went there.

Traveling with his father who was a rough disciplinarian was tough, but this helped him form a winner's mentality. Quiting in life was never an option. His mother worked 3 jobs, had to raise two of his brothers mostly on her own and send him and his father money. When that wasn't enough, they had to borrow money from loansharks which pretty much meant that Novak needed to win whatever event he was competing at to make sure all the debts were paid on time.

Standing in line for food, not having any options as a competitor while fighting a hostile crowd, staying in the cheapest, most dangerous ghettos while playing various tournaments turned him into the ultimate warrior.

He had early back and neck injuries, deviations in his nose that troubled breathing, was plagued by many allergies, survived serious food poisonings and coach sabotage before finally figuring things out in 2007. His struggles, mental and physical were still there but smaller until the end of 2010 when he started putting things in order. After winning the Davis Cup that year, Novak had one of the most impressive seasons in the sport‚Äôs history. In 2011 he won 10 titles (3 grand slams, 5 Masters and a couple other titles) with a 43 win streak and ended it with a record of 70‚Äì6 (92.1%). He had an even better season in 2015(best in tennis history) where he won 11 titles with 3 grand slams, 6 Masters, Tour Finals and another title, ending it with a record of 82-6(93.2%).

Some of his stand-alone achievements are:

Having won the most grand slams, 24.

Winning at least 3 titles at every slam.

Being the only man who has a positive record against the other two greatest players of all time, Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal.

Winning 30 consecutive Grand Slam matches and setting up a record of 16.950 ATP points.

Being in 6 consecutive GS finals, winning 5, of which 4 in a row on 3 different surfaces.

Winning 31 consecutive Masters matches.

Being in 6+ finals at each Grand Slam.

4 streaks of 3+ consecutive Grand Slam titles.

Having the highest winning percentage of all time at 83.3%.

Winning 10 Australian Open titles and I'm sure he'll add more.

Winning 39 Masters titles.

Winning 6 Masters in a single season.

Winning all 9 Masters and doing it twice.

Winning 13 hardcourt Major finals.

Winning 66 Elite tournaments.

Winning 3 Majors after being 2 sets down for the comeback of the year.

Winning a Major after being 2 sets down twice in the tournament.

Three-peat at 8 different elite tournaments.

Getting the double-elite title sweep.

25+ wins over each member of the Big Four and winning head-to-head record against all of them.

80%+ on all three surfaces

Highest hardcourt win percentage at 84.3% (88.6% at GS/Majors).

4 winning streaks of 26+ match wins at GS events.

6 seasons reaching 3+ Major finals.

6+ finals at each GS/Major.

9+ semifinals at each GS/Major.

34 five-set GS wins.

Over 80 wins at each Major.

55 singles Masters finals.

Dethroning 8 GS champions.

Earning a record 7 time year-end #1 and ITF player of the year.

In his career Djokovic has played 29% of his matches against top 10 players, while Federer has played 22.8% and Nadal 22.4%. Yet Djokovic has the highest win rate versus the top 10 at 69%.

Since 2011 Djokovic has won 20 slams, 33 masters, 4 ATP Finals and spent 373 weeks at world #1. Meanwhile, Nadal and Federer have won a combined 17 slams, 29 masters, 1 ATP Final and spent a total 132 weeks at #1, which is way less than half.

It starts making sense why he's the player of the decade and quite possibly our lifetime.

The list of his crazy achievements goes on and on as he keeps adding new records. These are just some to let everyone know that we are witnessing greatness.

There hasn't been a stronger player in terms of willpower and fitness.

He's the master of silencing the crowd, just look at the US Open 2011 & 2015 and Wimbledon 2014, 2015 & 2019. It doesn't matter if there's 15.000-30.000 fans booing, he still wins.

No other tennis star had to endure all that. He knows how to channel his inner wolf. üê∫

–ïdit: Novak is also a humanitarian. He makes very generous donations for those who need help the most. He has built many kindergartens, schools, playgrounds and shelters. In 2012 and 2016 he covered all the expenses for different teams representing his country including the special and para-Olympic teams. He has also financed the construction of their training centers. It's important to note that during the coronavirus outbreak he helped not only Serbian hospitals but the ones in Italy and Spain as well because they were hit the hardest. Back in 2014 when the horrific floods devastated the former Yugoslav region, he gave up all of his earnings from the Masters tournament in Rome and added extra resources from his Foundation to help repair the damage and provide housing. He did the same when we had flares, earthquakes and blizzards a couple of years before that and personally assisted the authorities in bringing all the necessary supplies. It's worth noting that he started a campaign with Maria Sharapova to help stop the Australian bushfires and repair the damage in 2019-2020. Unfortunately, people are quick to forget.

He loves kids and appreciates his fans more than any other athlete.

Novak gives his racket to the kid who was ‚Äúcoaching‚Äù him in his win over Stefanos Tsitsipas in the final of Roland Garros 2021 after being down 2‚Äì0, making it one of the greatest comebacks in all sports. They had a special moment after the match.

Making a ball boy's dream come true at the French Open 2014.

Other players have great respect and admiration for Novak and his sportsmanship. He's the quickest to applaud their effort and compliment their game on and off the court and the first to comfort them after a loss. Players such as Carlos Alcaraz, Daniil Medvedev, John Isner, Alexander Zverev, Simona Halep, Dominic Thiem, Dennis Shapovalov, Riley Opelka, Borna Coric, Kei Nishikori, David Goffin, Yannick Sinner, Casper Ruud, Holger Rune, Thomas Etcheverry, Hyeon Chung, Hugo Dellien and many others see Novak as an inspiration and often seek advice from him. He's great friends with Vasek Pospisil, Juan-Martin Del Potro, Andy Murray, Maria Sharapova, Paula Badosa, Aryna Sabalenka, Serena Williams, Grigor Dimitrov, Fabio Fognini, Malek Jaziri, Nick Kyrgios, Gael Monfils, Simona Halep and all his fellow Serbian players, male and female. Former players and legends such as Boris Becker, Ivan Lendl, Andre Agassi, Pete Sampras, Monica Seles, Jimmy Connors, John McEnroe, Rod Laver, Andy Roddick, Tim Henman, James Blake, Barbara Schett, Laura Robson, Ivan Ljubicic and Mardy Fish think very highly of him.

In 2017 he gifted his own apartment in Paris to his countryman and Davis/ATP Cup partner Filip Krajinovic. Novak knew that France was always Filip‚Äôs favorite place outside of Serbia and believed in him when no one else did during that tough time in his life. He wanted his friend and colleague to feel at home there. They remain close to this day and often play doubles together. He shared his entire apparel with Nikola Cacic, a doubles player from his home country who idolizes him and helped Mirza Basic out by giving him his extra pair of shoes. Through 2021 and 2022 he covered all the expenses of training and coaching of his young compatriot Hamad Medjedovic. Hamad‚Äôs father said he couldn‚Äôt believe how generous Novak‚Äôs support was and that it won‚Äôt cost them anything. They often train together and Hamad considers Novak as his mentor. This is what it means to be a true leader.

Here's Novak with Nina Stojanovic. He promised to play doubles with her when she was a kid. Her dreams came true in Tokyo 2021.

column3: Is Nadal unlucky to be born in the same era as Federer?
column4:
Not just Nadal, all the three - Nadal, Federer and Djokovic are very very unlucky to have been born in the same era of others.

Let me start by a stat.

As of now, in the entire history of tennis, only 8 gentlemen have achieved career slam. In the open era, only four have done this.

Andre Agassi

Roger Federer

Rafael Nadal

Novak Djokovic

And we have three of them at the same period, three of the eight great players in the whole history of tennis are playing alongside at the same time, lucky for us, but completely unlucky for them.

Despite having played in the same era, they are the top 3 grand slam winners in the entire history.

Federer - 20 grand slams

Nadal - 19 grand slams

Djokovic - 16 grand slams

This clearly shows that hadn't at least one of em been there at the same time, the other two would have been beasts.

Despite having won huge number of grand slams, none of them has actually won a calendar slam( all 4 grand slams in a calendar year).

Nadal prevented Djokovic twice and Federer twice from a calendar slam.

Also they have records that are very very unlikely to be broken.

Nadal - 12 titles at a single surface clay

Federer - Has more than 5 titles in every surface other than clay‚Ä¶

Djokovic - Only player in the history of tennis to hold all four grand slam titles and all nine Masters in three different surfaces.

This shows how lucky we are to witness three legends of the game at the same time.

Yeah‚Ä¶.

This picture is and will be a gem forever in the tennis world.

EDIT 1: Djokovic moves to 15 grand slams defeating Nadal in the Australian open 2019 final‚Ä¶Yes,their dominance still continues.

EDIT 2: Nadal makes it again in French open, defeating Thiem and extending it to a whopping 12 Roland Garros titles.

EDIT 3: Djokovic beats Federer in one of the historic Wimbledon finals to clinch his 16th Grand Slam title‚Ä¶.

EDIT 4: Nadal moves to 19 grand slam titles, beating Medvedev in a five set thriller in the finals of US Open.

Dominance of top three in grand slams continues, still.

column3: Why was Serena Williams' outfit banned from the French Open?
column4:
First the short version:

Q: ‚ÄúWhy was Serena Williams' outfit banned from the French Open?‚Äù

A: ‚ÄúBecause she (and Nike) wanted it to be.‚Äù

Now the longer version:

Q: ‚ÄúWhy was Serena Williams' outfit banned from the French Open?‚Äù

A: Well, the first thing to know is that it probably isn‚Äôt for the reasons you think it is, or for the reasons you‚Äôve been hearing people write about. And it isn‚Äôt for the reasons stated in any of the other answers here (at least as of this writing). It relates much more to ankles, calves, fabrics and technicalities than it does to prudishness, self-expression, body shaming or other hot button issues. It‚Äôs also not really about tennis authorities being so old fashioned or too caught up in tradition to stay with the times. And it‚Äôs not even about tennis‚Äôs aristocratic origins, and class indicators, as some answers have suggested.

Obviously, that‚Äôs going to require a little explanation. So here goes. Serena‚Äôs cat suit, while form fitting, isn‚Äôt really that different from what many athletes wear in some other sports. It‚Äôs fairly modest really. Here it is:

Not particularly scandalous, right? In fact, Serena herself wore a much more revealing outfit at the French Open in 2004. Take a look at that one, which was considered to be within the rules:

So all the talk about uptight French men telling women what to wear because they can‚Äôt handle people‚Äôs bodies seems like it isn‚Äôt the case, right?

So what could it be? Well, it turns out it has to do with a few piddly little rules and standards of both the women‚Äôs tour and the tournament itself. One of them is that although Serena‚Äôs 2004 catsuits weren‚Äôt considered too short, this year‚Äôs version was considered too long. What‚Äôs that, you say? How could that be? Well it turns out that Serena was in violation of a couple of rules that are well known on the tour but little known to the public, one of which is that leggings or tights can be worn but only until the middle of the calf at the longest. They also are supposed to be worn under a skirt or pair of shorts, no matter how short or tight those may be. Here‚Äôs a picture of Serena wearing form-fitting tights at Roland Garros that were perfectly legal and not banned.

Lastly, Roland Garros has a rule stated explicitly in their code that all players must wear clothing that is ‚Äúcustomarily acceptable tennis attire‚Äù. The catsuit in question is not customarily acceptable tennis attire. It doesn‚Äôt look like anything that tennis players have ever worn, and doesn‚Äôt try to be. Neither the shape, color, cut or material are in any way customary for tennis. That doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôre scandalous or racy, just that they‚Äôre not typical. And the rule exists to keep players from just randomly wearing anything they want, and the tournament not being able to address it. Offices have similar standards, so it‚Äôs not really that unexpected or unreasonable.

Now obviously Serena is very familiar with these rules. She‚Äôs been on the tour for over 20 years and put together many an outfit that complied with them. So why would she suddenly forget or decide purposely to break them? The answer is fairly obvious once you look at her actions and those of the company that made the banned outfit: Marketing. Really smart marketing.

The outfit Serena wore works on many levels. First off, it‚Äôs really cool-looking. Secondly it recalls the super-powered outfit worn in the smash hit movie ‚ÄúBlack Panther‚Äù, released just three months before Roland Garros and reprised in the most recent installment of Avengers, which was released just one month before Roland Garros. The movie contained messages of empowerment, and was loved by more than 100 million people around the world. What better imagery to associate herself with? Third of all it was, by her accounts, comfortable.

The only thing is that it was illegal. And she (and Nike) knew it. You can guess all you like about whose idea it was first (I have a pretty good idea myself). But the point is that both Serena and Nike knew going in that the outfit was unlikely to be allowed. The only time anyone had worn a full-length catsuit at a major tennis event previously, it had been banned that night. But is that actually a bad thing? If she wears an outfit and people talk about it a bit in the press because it‚Äôs cool and looks like Black Panther, then you get a little buzz, and a few days later it all dies down. However, if you make sure that said outfit breaks the rules, however petty, you run the chance of getting a much huger publicity benefit. Buying ads is expensive. But getting articles written about you is free. There‚Äôs a saying in the marketing world: ‚ÄúAdvertising is what you pay for. PR is what you pray for.‚Äù And that fits this case very well. It would have been a small win if Serena had worn her catsuit and gone about her business. But if it were to get censured or banned, then all of a sudden it‚Äôs a marketing bonanza! Not only do you get talked about for months in every news outlet and millions of online outlets (including this one), but you get to call out Serena‚Äôs heroism instead of just her fashion acumen.

Heck, you might even design a major ad specifically around the occurrence, that just by chance, coincidentally, through a total fluke of nature that no one could possibly have seen coming because it was such a huge surprise that no one expected in any way fit the scenario perfectly, as well as the entire new positioning of the company that was just being rolled out:

Oh my god, I can‚Äôt believe Nike got so lucky! Total coincidence. They couldn‚Äôt have expected any of this. I mean, the press releases probably aren‚Äôt a thing either. And the link that the OP included with the question refers to a business win that surely Nike couldn‚Äôt have seen coming: Nike had the perfect response to French Open's controversial decision to ban Serena Williams' catsuit that made her feel like a 'warrior princess'

It‚Äôs a lucky thing the suit just happened to break a few of those obscure rules, and that they had the perfect carefully-crafted response at the ready for when it did. I‚Äôm sure Nike and Serena didn‚Äôt design it with that in mind just to generate crass publicity. That would be out of the realm of possibility for a large marketing-savvy corporation like that, wouldn‚Äôt it? (Fortunately for them, the campaign wasn‚Äôt quite as impactful as it might have been, since they let her wear it and only banned it later, scuttling Nike‚Äôs initial Roland Garros PR attempts. I‚Äôm sure they would have been simply mortified if it had blown up during the tournament.)

And Nike is lucky they chose an actual superhero to wear the outfit, because the mere mortals on tour all know they would have been immediately punished if they‚Äôd even tried to masquerade as superheroes and wear that outfit themselves.

With great power comes great responsibility.

column3: Why do some people say that Rafael Nadal‚Äôs tennis style of play is defensive?
column4:
One of the beauties of Rafa‚Äôs game is his ‚Äúpercentage play‚Äù.

What is percentage tennis?

It is safe tennis. You don‚Äôt hit flat shots which have a high risk factor of either going into the net or sailing wide. You don‚Äôt look to clear the net by simply a few inches. You play to clear the net by a good few feet. To do that, you have to usually hit constant top spin shots. They sail up above the net, but also come falling down fast after that reach the high point. This either adds depth to a shot, or simply makes the ball bounce high if it lands short. In either scenario, the trajectory of the ball is difficult to tackle, especially because it is not the usual way the ball comes back to a player.

Needless to say, this is not an aggressive brand of tennis. Aggressive players usually hit flatter, faster shots and volley more. Federer is a good example. Federer is an extremely aggressive player. Nadal‚Äôs style is aggressive too, but not as aggressive. His focus is more on extracting mistakes and using bounce to displace his opponents (who often move further back to get the shot on a hittable level), and when he gets an open court, he can easily slam a winner.

Nadal also consistently stands far behind the basline when receiving serve. It‚Äôs obviously a much more defensive position, from where he takes a couple shots to come up to the baseline. If you look at Federer, he usually stands right around the baseline while returning serve.

Look at this difference in their receiving positions. It‚Äôs a classic aggressive/defensive contrast.

Lastly, if you look at Federer‚Äôs matches - most times, he outhits his opponents on winners. And even when he loses, it‚Äôs because he lands up with more errors. In contrast, Nadal may or may not have more winners, but he usually does far better in terms of unforced errors and that‚Äôs where he makes the difference count.

Both these approaches to playing the game have their own merits. After all, both these players have made their own style work incredibly. But yes, Nadal does have a more defensive approach, which relies on him making as few mistakes as possible. It‚Äôs really phenomenal though how he maintains the level of power and consistency with a constant top spin game.

ETA

Fun fact: Nadal‚Äôs phenomenal ability to hit so many ‚Äúbananas‚Äù is a result of his percentage play. Because he usually looks to clear the net more, he doesn‚Äôt catch the net-tape like most players do while hitting their forehands down the line. His higher margin of error comes into play here. And of course, it‚Äôs this top spin that he imparts on the ball that allows the ball to curve round the outside of the line to finally drop into it. He is not hitting a different forehand, but his forehand is just so well suited to hit this shot!

Look at the net clearance. Look at the curve. Look at the shot.

You play to clear the net by a good few feet. To do that, you have to usually hit constant top spin shots. They sail up above the net, but also come falling down fast after that reach the high point. This either adds depth to a shot, or simply makes the ball bounce high if it lands short. In either scenario, the trajectory of the ball is difficult to tackle, especially because it is not the usual way the ball comes back to a player.

Needless to say, this is not an aggressive brand of tennis. Aggressive players usually hit flatter, faster shots and volley more. Federer is a good example. Federer is an extremely aggressive player. Nadal‚Äôs style is aggressive too, but not as aggressive. His focus is more on extracting mistakes and using bounce to displace his opponents (who often move further back to get the shot on a hittable level), and when he gets an open court, he can easily slam a winner.

Nadal also consistently stands far behind the basline when receiving serve. It‚Äôs obviously a much more defensive position, from where he takes a couple shots to come up to the baseline. If you look at Federer, he usually stands right around the baseline while returning serve.

Look at this difference in their receiving positions. It‚Äôs a classic aggressive/defensive contrast.

Lastly, if you look at Federer‚Äôs matches - most times, he outhits his opponents on winners. And even when he loses, it‚Äôs because he lands up with more errors. In contrast, Nadal may or may not have more winners, but he usually does far better in terms of unforced errors and that‚Äôs where he makes the difference count.

Both these approaches to playing the game have their own merits. After all, both these players have made their own style work incredibly. But yes, Nadal does have a more defensive approach, which relies on him making as few mistakes as possible. It‚Äôs really phenomenal though how he maintains the level of power and consistency with a constant top spin game.

ETA

Fun fact: Nadal‚Äôs phenomenal ability to hit so many ‚Äúbananas‚Äù is a result of his percentage play. Because he usually looks to clear the net more, he doesn‚Äôt catch the net-tape like most players do while hitting their forehands down the line. His higher margin of error comes into play here. And of course, it‚Äôs this top spin that he imparts on the ball that allows the ball to curve round the outside of the line to finally drop into it. He is not hitting a different forehand, but his forehand is just so well suited to hit this shot!

Look at the net clearance. Look at the curve. Look at the shot.', 'aiModelVersion': '1'}

column3: Who is the unluckiest player in the history of sport?
column4:
Monica Seles

She was born in 1973 and before turning 20, Seles had racked up 8 Grand Slam Singles titles and 3 year-end final titles. Also keep in mind that:

This achievement took place during the Steffi Graf era - a player currently considered as one of the greatest, if not the greatest tennis player of all time.
No other player (male or female) has ever been able to win more than 6 Gland Slam titles before the age of 20 (which happened to be Steffi Graf after winning the only Calender Golden Slam in History in 1988)

In 1990, at the age of 16, Seles became the youngest ever French Open Champion and less than a year later she was ranked as the world number 1.

By the start of 1993, Seles had cemented herself as the top women's tennis player and heading into the season, she had won the French Open for three consecutive years and both the US Open and Australian Open in consecutive years (again worth remembering... she was still in her teens and had turned 19 just a few months earlier)

Then on April 30, G√ºnter Parche, an obsessed fan of Graf ran onto the court during a break between games and stabbed Seles with a knife between her shoulder blades. She was quickly rushed to a hospital and did not return to competitive tennis for more than two years.

When she finally returned to tennis a couple of years later. Seles managed to add one more Grand Slam to her tally but she was never the same.

So my questions now are?

How often is Seles mentioned during discussions about being the GOAT (‚ÄúGreatest of all time‚Äù)? Very rarely I‚Äôd say..
and how may things have been different if that teenager with 8 Grand Slam titles under her belt did not get stabbed on that awful day?

I‚Äôve compiled the below table just to illustrate how astounding Seles‚Äô achievements were when compared to those names we usually hear during discussions of the ‚ÄúGreatest of All Time‚Äù.

** Reference data refreshed to reflect the correct statistics as at January 2024, prior to the 2024 Australian Open to keep up with Novak Djokovich & Rafael Nadal üòâ

column3: What does a tennis coach who is a former player know that he didn‚Äôt when he was a player? I‚Äôm referring to coaches like Stepanek (Djoko) and Ljubicic (Federer) but also many others. They weren‚Äôt great champions but are training legends. Why?
column4:
Thanks for the A2A.

First, allow me a quick rant.

The statement ‚Äúthose who can do, and those who can‚Äôt teach‚Äù is one of the most misunderstood and often idiotic statements of all time.

Ivan Ljubicic was as high as #3 in the world, helped win Croatia the 2005 Davis Cup, won 10 titles, and beat the following world #1 players: Federer (x3), Nadal (x2), Djokovic (x2), Murray (x3), Safin (x2), Agassi (x2), Kafelnikov (x3), and Roddick (x4). He earned over $10 million in his career, and had one of the best backhands of all time.

It‚Äôs ridiculous not to acknowledge how amazing this guy was as a player. The only thing he didn‚Äôt do was win big at the Grand Slam level, mostly due to his relative lack of mobility.

Radek Stepanek was ranked as high as #8 in singles, winning 5 titles, and #4 in doubles winning multiple titles including the Australian Open and the US Open. He also had wins over Federer, Murray, Del Potro, Safin, Roddick, Nalbandian, and Davydenko. He earned over $11 million in his career and was one of the few serve and volleyers who succeeded during the modern era‚Äôs change to uniform court surfaces. If he had played in the 80s or early 90s, he might have had a shot at winning Wimbledon. He suffered from a chronic neck injury that caused him to miss six months just as he hit his highest singles ranking.

So, when you dismiss incredible players like Ljubicic and Stepanik as not being great champions, you are basically saying that only players who win Grand Slams and reach #1 in the rankings can be considered as ‚Äúthose who can.‚Äù

Now, on to the question ‚Äúwhat does a tennis coach who is a former player know that he didn‚Äôt when he was a player?‚Äù

There are three parts to this answer, and only one of them has anything to do with knowledge of the game. They have to do with the maturation process that players go through as they get older and what it takes to become a great coach, which has almost nothing to do with being a former Grand Slam winner.

First, as players mature, have a family and eventually retire, they start to become aware that they are not the center of the universe. It is almost impossible for an elite athlete not to be totally focused on themselves and their sport on a 24/7 basis.

Look at Murray and Djokovic. Once they got married and had kids, their focus went to other things. This happens to every player at every level.

Except Roger Federer, who is a freak of nature. His ability to continue to play at his level while helping to raise two sets of twins is miraculous. He even got injured running a bath for his daughters.

Who‚Äôs the other guy who‚Äôs still playing unbelievably well? You guessed it, Rafael Nadal, the bachelor.

As a player stops focusing only on themselves, their awareness of others grows, and possibly characteristics like empathy and compassion ofthen develop. Without those two characteristics, a great player can‚Äôt be a great coach, because they won‚Äôt have the patience or provide the emotional support to help their student get through the toughest hurdles.

In fact, people who have suffered the most to achieve some level of success, but were prevented from reaching the very top (due to injury, fewer physical blessings, or the slightest lack of confidence or concentration) are the most tuned into what is needed to become the best.

The second aspect of being a great coach is their ability to build trust, bond with and provide emotional support for their client. In some cases, being a former top pro allows them to build camaraderie with their client. In some cases, it is a parent. But however this bond gets built, it usually requires a top coach to travel with the player on a year round basis. And not everyone wants to do that.

Lendl started coaching Murray, and helped the Scot to his greatest achievements. But he just didn‚Äôt want to travel on the circuit all the time, so he stopped after a couple of years.

At different times in a player‚Äôs career they will need a different type of support. When Lendl coached Murray, the dour faced Czech was probably strong on tactic and strategy, but not a font of emotional support.

After they split up, and Murray went through some injuries, requiring a lot of patience and caring, he found that by hiring Amelie Mauresmo, which was a huge shock as she became the first woman to coach a top male player.

Finally, former Grand Slam level players like Ljubicic, Stepanek and Lendl may give them a slightly better understanding of how potential opponents think and how they react under different kinds of pressure.

In the same way that a singer with a range of three octaves can imagine writing a melody using their vocal range, a player who has played at the highest level may see patterns or ways to exploit an opponent that lower ranked players may not understand.

I‚Äôm not saying this is the only way a coach can be successful. Nadal‚Äôs uncle was a professional soccer player, and he still figured out enough about tennis to help Rafa become one of the greatest players of all time.

But rest assured that someone who is used to the fame and pressure of playing at at a professional level will have more insights than a person who was never involved in a sport at an elite level.

Think about all the great basketball coaches who didn‚Äôt make it to the NBA. They were still playing college ball, and trying to make up for their lack of height or quickness by knowing the game and anticipating situations. It wasn‚Äôt like their basketball career ended in middle school or on a recreation league at a ...

column3: Did Roger Federer ever lose at Wimbledon during his prime?
column4:
Best example? The 2008 Wimbledon final.

There‚Äôs a reason this match is widely considered the greatest match in the history of tennis. Federer was in ridiculous shape, he was riding a 65-match winning streak on grass, had just won his last grass tournament without dropping a set or a service game, and had won the last 5 Wimbledon's (personally dispatching Nadal in the last 2). He was 27-years-old and already lauded as the king of grass.

Nadal, by contrast, was 22-years-old, had clawed his way to his first grass court title as a warm-up to Wimbledon, and had never won a grass court match against Federer.

But right from the get-go, Nadal was incredible. He took the first two sets 6‚Äì4 6‚Äì4, absolutely dazzling on court with sheer athleticism. Federer took the hint and upped his game, clawing his way back into the game for a tiebreaker in the 3rd set that he won 7‚Äì5. Some players would have buckled under the pressure, Federer refused. The fourth set was even crazier, Nadal blasted to a 5‚Äì2 lead and Federer, unperturbed, saved multiple championship points to win another tiebreaker, this time 10‚Äì8.

Then came the 5th set. Both players were dialed in, both players knew everything was on the line, and both players fought tooth-and-nail for every point. It wasn‚Äôt until the 15th game of the set that Nadal broke Federer‚Äôs serve and held for the win.

Some believe that was the beginning of the end for Federer. I disagree. He still won the US Open that year, won the 2009 French Open for the first (and only) time, and took back Wimbledon in Nadal‚Äôs absent. Federer may have lost his Wimbledon streak, but he never lost his grass court crown.

Djokovic did not beat Federer at Wimbledon until Federer was 33 and slowing down. In my opinion, only Nadal beat Federer in his prime at Wimbledon.

Nadal, by contrast, was 22-years-old, had clawed his way to his first grass court title as a warm-up to Wimbledon, and had never won a grass court match against Federer.

column3: What is Roger Federer like in real life?
column4:
I know my answer to this question is kind of late, but I will throw in my own experience.

I met Roger Federer in February 2011 during the Dubai Tennis Tournament.
At the time, I was a member of the Aviation Club, the same place that hosts the tournament. One of the nice perks of being a member is that we share the lockers with the players during the tournament. We get to see them train in the gym. The tennis courts are covered during the tournament to give the players some privacy. I still managed to see Roger Federer, Andy Murray and Novak Djokovic practice a couple of times.


So what is Roger Federer like in real life?

First of all, he is tall! Really tall! I am 175 cm, and yet Roger Federer felt like a giant next to me. Maybe it is the celebrity thing, I am not sure. All I can say that this man in reality is bigger than what he looks like on TV.
He did not feel intimidating though, and he did not look down at any one around him.

Roger would come into the lockers each day, take off his Rolex, and take a shower. His trainer would accompany him regularly. Roger seemed happy, calm and focused most of the time.

Every once in awhile, a guy will come in with his kid and ask for an autograph and a photo with Roger, to which Roger happily agrees.
There was this French family one day who spoke with Roger for an extended period, and although Roger‚Äôs time was very valuable, the talk seemed to be very positive.

Generally, things were going very well‚Ä¶ until the final vs Djokovic!

Roger lost that game 6‚Äì3, 6‚Äì3, and it was the first time I saw Roger in this way. Obviously, losing a final is not exactly fun, and you could clearly see this on Roger‚Äôs face! He managed to take a very quick shower, pack his stuff and leave, while Djokovic remained until midnight celebrating in the Rainbow Room as I recall.

The most interesting thing was that some fan got into the locker with his son, and Roger agreed to take a picture with the guy and his son, sign an autograph, and have small talk with total strangers. All of this is after losing a final! I thought that was something else!

I think Roger Federer is an awesome person. He is nice, calm and humble. If you see him on the street one day, I am sure he‚Äôll be more than happy to take a picture with you.

column3: What is Roger Federer like in real life?
column4:
"I was having breakfast with my kids (at a beach resort) and he just walked up to us and asked if he could join us since he didn't like to eat alone; he had to be one of the most grounded people I would have ever met"
- someone I met at that beach resort

column3: What is Roger Federer like in real life?
column4:
I met him in Scotland. I was in a small Scottish town not too far from Dundee, called Pittenweem. We were incidentally in the same hotel. It was small, not at all like a big hotel you would expect him to go to. He was vacationing with his wife and daughters.

We were at the hotel eating breakfast and he came in with his wife and two daughters, who were just a year and a half at the time, and extremely attention seeking. Roger did all the work and let his wife be. He fed them, cleaned them, tried to calm them down every time they would be noisy and cranky. What a great guy! He and his wife looked like they were so happy with each other. There were no helpers. Just the four of them and he did all the work.

When we finally got the chance to speak with him he was so good to us. He offered to take photographs and gave us all the autographs we wanted. When we asked him for one too many, he said, "Hey! Those better not be for sale. I'll keep an eye out," with a big smile. He was extremely patient with us. Every time his daughters needed attention and he would have to take them out to calm them down, he would profusely apologise to us and say he would catch up with us later.

In a few words, what a great guy! Seriously.

column3: What are some of the mind-blowing facts about Roger Federer?
column4:
Rafael Nadal once said about Federer ‚Äú If someone thinks that i play better than Federer , he doesn‚Äôt know anything about tennis.‚Äù
Federer facts :

At the beginning of his career, he played in but couldn‚Äôt go past quarter-finals in 16 grand slams.
Federer has served a total of 9734 aces in his entire professional career. While his rivals are far behind with Djokovic having 4655 and Nadal with 2735 aces.
Federer also holds the worst record among players active since 1990 in so-called ‚ÄúSimpson‚Äôs Paradox‚Äù matches‚Äìthose where the loser of the match wins more points than the winner.
Federer was gifted a cow by the organisers of the Swiss open, when he returned to play the tournament after winning his first Wimbledon title in 2003.

5. Federer and his wife Mirka competed together just once, playing in the Hopman Cup, held in Perth, Australia.

6. Roger Federer holds the record for the most consecutive points won on serve:
35 against Feliciano Lopez in the US Open 2007 4th round.

7. Roger Federer also hold 2 of 3 longest match record. Longest singles final match by time played. ‚Äúin 2008, 4 hours and 48 minutes, vs Rafael Nadal.‚Äù
Longest singles final match by number of games. ‚Äúin 2009, 77 games against Andy Roddick. This match also had the longest final set in a Grand Slam final by games.‚Äù

Edit: Thanks Arvind Chouhan for point 7.

column3: What is it like to be a ballboy or ballgirl at the US Open?
column4:
It truly is an experience like no other. As a ballperson (they no longer officially use the term ‚Äúballboy,‚Äù since adults are also considered for the position), there are quite a few perks to being a part of the job.

Let‚Äôs start with obtaining the job in the first place:

In order to earn the title of ‚ÄúUS Open Ballperson,‚Äù you must attend tryouts to be considered for the position. You must have good hand-eye coordination, amazing stamina, the ability to sprint if and when necessary, a sense of urgency, at least a basic understanding of tennis scoring, and the ability to roll and catch a ball.
Once you make it past the first stage of tryouts, you must attend callbacks. You will receive a specific date and time to attend this session, and, similar to tryouts, you must perform well for consideration. My friend and I both made it to the callback stage and she was cut from the crowd. You need to exhibit the same qualities that you possessed at tryouts, but show that you understand your responsibilities as a ballperson.
Once you get the job, there is a massive number of paperwork you need to fill out. Most of the documents are provided online, but I assume that filling out paperwork applies to any job. In addition, you will need to receive a credential from the US Open in order to attend any sessions. This year, there was a week specifically designed to receive your credential early, and I was one of the first rookies to take advantage of the opportunity.
There are multiple training sessions that you must attend. For rookies, you must attend at least four training sessions. I attended six in order to understand the position better. It might just be me, but I truly did enjoy these sessions. Then, there will be one mandatory session a few days prior to the start of the US Open. On this day, you get your paycheck (yes, you get paid for training), your call time for your first day, and your uniform.

Now, let‚Äôs get into life once you‚Äôve officially become a ballperson:

You‚Äôre a walking advertisement for Polo and Ralph Lauren. And we all know how their products aren‚Äôt exactly cheap‚Ä¶ And as a result, you get uniforms like this:

(The shoes are the best part, though I must warn you that they aren‚Äôt very comfortable)

These uniforms are simply cute and professional while simultaneously providing comfortable material for strenuous activities.

In total, you get a pair of white shoes, two pairs of socks, two skorts (or shorts for boys and men), two shirts, and either a hat or visor. And, if you get lucky like myself, you might also obtain two wristbands. This year, most rookies didn‚Äôt get their wristbands because they ran out of stock halfway through uniform distribution. I, however, did.

The total uniform has a value around $500, all for free.

UPDATE: I‚Äôm not sure about previous years, but this year they gave jackets and sweatpants to ballpeople who show commitment and stay for the entire event.

The jackets cost about $300, while the sweatpants cost $150.

Did I mention that the uniform was cute?

And free?

You get to work alongside some amazing tennis players, although it does depend on how good of a ballperson you are and how long you‚Äôve worked there for. As a rookie, I don‚Äôt expect to work a Federer match simply due to my lack of experience. Oh, well! Maybe next year. (Update: I may have exaggerated a bit in terms of my skill. If you tuned in to the women‚Äôs semifinals, I made it to Arthur Ashe for the Serena Williams vs. Anastasija Sevastova match.)
The staff can be strict at times, but they‚Äôre also compassionate and understanding. This year, the US Open switched from throwing to rolling, and it was a shock for the veterans. However, the ballperson staff has ensured that the change was implemented smoothly (though, for some reason I still have trouble rolling a ball smoothly).
Although the job is minimum wage, you get a credential with $25 loaded onto it daily. You can go to any location in the site for food and simply scan your credential. Therefore, instead of simply earning $13 an hour, you can add the daily amount of $25 to that total solely for food.
There are two positions as a ballperson: the net and the back. The net is in charge of collecting any balls that hit the net and servicing the player during changeovers. The back is in charge of servicing players the balls after every point, providing towels, and holding up the umbrella for them. In short, the ballpeople are there to facilitate the match and to ensure that the players are being treated well.
As implied, being a ballperson is no easy task. It requires an immense amount of discipline, attention, passion and athleticism. You also need to understand tennis well and how tennis is scored. Without these skills, you likely won‚Äôt make it past callbacks.

Overall, it truly is a job that I‚Äôm glad I managed to get. The tryout process is strenuous and tiring; my friend was cut at the callback stage despite knowing more about tennis than I did. However, once you get the job, the experience is truly worth it. If you are considering trying out to be a US Open ballperson, I would highly recommend it.

~~~~~~

EDIT (8/25/18): Wow, this is the first answer I‚Äôve written on Quora that has gotten immense feedback! Thanks for the positive comments and upvotes; I‚Äôm glad you all enjoyed my answer! I also decided to add some points that I missed when writing this answer for the first time.

~~~~~~~

EDIT (8/31/18): Two thousand upvotes??? That‚Äôs incredible! Thanks for the positive response to everyone who sees this! I guess I should post a little update for you guys: I‚Äôm good enough at my job, because I‚Äôve been upgraded to a swing, and I had the opportunity to work during the Venus vs. Giorgi match a few days ago. Yay!

However, the ballperson staff has ensured that the change was implemented smoothly (though, for some reason I still have trouble rolling a ball smoothly).
Although the job is minimum wage, you get a credential with $25 loaded onto it daily. You can go to any location in the site for food and simply scan your credential. Therefore, instead of simply earning $13 an hour, you can add the daily amount of $25 to that total solely for food.
There are two positions as a ballperson: the net and the back. The net is in charge of collecting any balls that hit the net and servicing the player during changeovers. The back is in charge of servicing players the balls after every point, providing towels, and holding up the umbrella for them. In short, the ballpeople are there to facilitate the match and to ensure that the players are being treated well.
As implied, being a ballperson is no easy task. It requires an immense amount of discipline, attention, passion and athleticism. You also need to understand tennis well and how tennis is scored. Without these skills, you likely won‚Äôt make it past callbacks.

Overall, it truly is a job that I‚Äôm glad I managed to get. The tryout process is strenuous and tiring; my friend was cut at the callback stage despite knowing more about tennis than I did. However, once you get the job, the experience is truly worth it. If you are considering trying out to be a US Open ballperson, I would highly recommend it.

Yay!', 'result': {'fake': 0.9988, 'real': 0.0012}, 'status': 'success'}], 'credits_used': 11, 'credits': 1998879, 'subscription': 0, 'content': 'It truly is an experience like no other. As a ballperson (they no longer officially use the term ‚Äúballboy,‚Äù since adults are also considered for the position), there are quite a few perks to being a part of the job.

Let‚Äôs start with obtaining the job in the first place:

In order to earn the title of ‚ÄúUS Open Ballperson,‚Äù you must attend tryouts to be considered for the position. You must have good hand-eye coordination, amazing stamina, the ability to sprint if and when necessary, a sense of urgency, at least a basic understanding of tennis scoring, and the ability to roll and catch a ball.
Once you make it past the first stage of tryouts, you must attend callbacks. You will receive a specific date and time to attend this session, and, similar to tryouts, you must perform well for consideration. My friend and I both made it to the callback stage and she was cut from the crowd. You need to exhibit the same qualities that you possessed at tryouts, but show that you understand your responsibilities as a ballperson.
Once you get the job, there is a massive number of paperwork you need to fill out. Most of the documents are provided online, but I assume that filling out paperwork applies to any job. In addition, you will need to receive a credential from the US Open in order to attend any sessions. This year, there was a week specifically designed to receive your credential early, and I was one of the first rookies to take advantage of the opportunity.
There are multiple training sessions that you must attend. For rookies, you must attend at least four training sessions. I attended six in order to understand the position better. It might just be me, but I truly did enjoy these sessions. Then, there will be one mandatory session a few days prior to the start of the US Open. On this day, you get your paycheck (yes, you get paid for training), your call time for your first day, and your uniform.

Now, let‚Äôs get into life once you‚Äôve officially become a ballperson:

You‚Äôre a walking advertisement for Polo and Ralph Lauren. And we all know how their products aren‚Äôt exactly cheap‚Ä¶ And as a result, you get uniforms like this:

(The shoes are the best part, though I must warn you that they aren‚Äôt very comfortable)

These uniforms are simply cute and professional while simultaneously providing comfortable material for strenuous activities.

In total, you get a pair of white shoes, two pairs of socks, two skorts (or shorts for boys and men), two shirts, and either a hat or visor. And, if you get lucky like myself, you might also obtain two wristbands. This year, most rookies didn‚Äôt get their wristbands because they ran out of stock halfway through uniform distribution. I, however, did.

The total uniform has a value around $500, all for free.

UPDATE: I‚Äôm not sure about previous years, but this year they gave jackets and sweatpants to ballpeople who show commitment and stay for the entire event.

The jackets cost about $300, while the sweatpants cost $150.

Did I mention that the uniform was cute?

And free?

You get to work alongside some amazing tennis players, although it does depend on how good of a ballperson you are and how long you‚Äôve worked there for. As a rookie, I don‚Äôt expect to work a Federer match simply due to my lack of experience. Oh, well! Maybe next year. (Update: I may have exaggerated a bit in terms of my skill. If you tuned in to the women‚Äôs semifinals, I made it to Arthur Ashe for the Serena Williams vs. Anastasija Sevastova match.)
The staff can be strict at times, but they‚Äôre also compassionate and understanding. This year, the US Open switched from throwing to rolling, and it was a shock for the veterans. There are two positions as a ballperson: the net and the back. The net is in charge of collecting any balls that hit the net and servicing the player during changeovers. The back is in charge of servicing players the balls after every point, providing towels, and holding up the umbrella for them. In short, the ballpeople are there to facilitate the match and to ensure that the players are being treated well.
As implied, being a ballperson is no easy task. It requires an immense amount of discipline, attention, passion and athleticism. You also need to understand tennis well and how tennis is scored. Without these skills, you likely won‚Äôt make it past callbacks.

Overall, it truly is a job that I‚Äôm glad I managed to get. The tryout process is strenuous and tiring; my friend was cut at the callback stage despite knowing more about tennis than I did. However, once you get the job, the experience is truly worth it. If you are considering trying out to be a US Open ballperson, I would highly recommend it.

column3: Should tennis umpire Carlos Ramos be temporarily suspended from working Grand Slam events after the debacle at this year's U.S. Open?
column4:
Quite the opposite - he should be praised by anyone who loves the sport, and encouraged to train new officials.

Serena Williams is a superstar in tennis. That‚Äôs not only praise for her skill and experience, but also a focus for the real problem. The problem is superstars who expect to get away with bad behavior, just because they are popular and successful. Carlos Ramos is a veteran official who has worked many important tournaments, including Wimbledon and the French Open for women‚Äôs tennis.

Serena Williams chose to behave in a grossly unprofessional manner, and brought the consequences on herself.

It is Serena Williams who owes an apology to umpire Carlos Ramos

Keep in mind that Mr. Ramos did not lose his temper and punish Ms. Williams. What happened was that Serena‚Äôs coach was signaling her from the stands, and Mr. Ramos followed the rules correctly for the code violation - Serena‚Äô s coach even admitted to the media that he got caught coaching Serena. Serena‚Äôs reaction was defiant and well out of line:

‚ÄúThis is unbelievable. Every time I play here I have problems.

'I didn't get coaching, I didn't get coaching. I didn't get coaching. You need to make an announcement that I didn't get coaching. I don't cheat, I didn't get coaching. How can you say that?

'You owe me an apology. You owe me an apology. I have never cheated in my life. I have a daughter and I stand for what is right for her and I've never cheated. You owe me an apology.‚Äù

FULL TRANSCRIPT: Serena Williams' entire outburst in US Open final

Remember that at this point Ms. Williams has only received a warning, nothing else. And we know from her coach that Williams, perhaps accidentally, broke that rule. Demanding the official not only reverse the call but apologize is out of bounds for an athlete. And blowing up like that over a warning only highlights how badly Ms. Williams over-reacted.

Later, Ms. Williams lost her temper and destroyed her racket, for which she received a point penalty, which again is completely by the rules:

There is no way any sane person can blame anyone but Serena Williams for that action. That is 100% on Ms. Williams.

But rather than take a moment to get her temper under control, Ms. Williams decided to blame the official, Mr. Ramos:

‚ÄùYou will never, ever, ever be on another court of mine as long as you live. You are the liar. When are you going to give me my apology? You owe me an apology.

'Say it, say you're sorry. Then don't talk to me, don't talk to me. How dare you insinuate I was cheating? You stole a point from me. You're a thief too.'‚Äù

FULL TRANSCRIPT: Serena Williams' entire outburst in US Open final

Take a good look at that. Ms. Williams is not only falsely blaming Mr. Ramos for her own violation of the rules, she is threatening him (promising he won‚Äôt be able to officiate any matches where she plays) and no-doubt bullying.

In football, baseball, or basketball, an athlete behaving that way would get a big fine and a suspension. And under the tennis rules, it absolutely constitutes verbal abuse. Here is what the rule says regarding verbal abuse of an official:

(i) Players shall not at any time directly or indirectly verbally abuse an official, opponent, sponsor, spectator or any other person within the precincts of the tournament site. Verbal abuse is defined as any statement about an official, opponent, sponsor, spectator or any other person that implies dishonesty or is derogatory, insulting or otherwise abusive.

ii) Violation of this section shall subject a player to a fine up to $20,000 for each violation. In addition, if such violation occurs during a (m)atch, the player shall be penalized in accordance with the Point Penalty Schedule.

~ ATP Rulebook 2017[4] (bold added)

Note also that Mr. Ramos is not given the discretion to simply warn Ms. Williams: the rule specifically says ‚Äú the player shall be penalized in accordance with the Point Penalty Schedule‚Äù, and following the two previous code violations, that unavoidably means a game penalty.

Rather than realize she had brought this on herself, and stop the damage done at that point, nor stop and realize that she owed Ramos an apology for her outbursts, Ms. Williams went nuclear:

'Are you kidding me? Are you kidding me? Because I said you were a thief? You stole a point from me. I'm not a cheater. I told you to apologise to me. Excuse me I need the referee, I don't agree with that.‚Äù

FULL TRANSCRIPT: Serena Williams' entire outburst in US Open final

And when the tournament officials explained that the decision was fair and appropriate, Williams decided to blame her poor behavior on sexism:

‚ÄúThis is not right... [INAUDIBLE]... He said I was being coached but I was not being coached. That's not right. You know me. You know my character. This is not fair. This has happened to me too many times. This is not fair. To lose a game for saying that is not fair. Do you know how many men do things that are much worse than that? This is not fair.

'There are a lot of men out here that have said a lot of things and because they are a man it doesn't matter. This is unbelievable. No I don't know the risk because if I say a simple thing, a thief, because he stole a point from me.

'There are men out here that do a lot worse and because I'm a woman you're going to take this away from me. That is not right. And you know it and I know you can't admit it, but I know you know that is not right. I know you can't change it but I'm just saying that is not right.‚Äù

FULL TRANSCRIPT: Serena Williams' entire outburst in US Open final

Regarding the sexism claim by Ms, Williams, Kelichi Asika (in an answer to a similar question) observed that the claim is laughable:

‚Äúin all the four Grand Slams this year there were a total of 128 code violations given for reasons such as racket/equipment abuse, coaching, time violation, unsportsmanlike conduct etc. 85 (66.41%) of those violations were given to men and 43 (33.59%) of them were given to women.

In this year‚Äôs US Open:

In the women‚Äôs singles tournament there were 11 fines in a total of 297 sets (0.037 per set).
In contrast, in the men‚Äôs singles tournament there were 16 fines in 460 sets (0.034 per set).‚Äù

Was the game penalty handed to Serena Williams in the 2018 US Open Final reasonable?

It should also be understood that Ms. Williams has anger management issues which have shown up in past tournament conditions:

Serena Williams also has a history of very bad behavior during tournament play.

US Open 2009: Serena Williams loses to Kim Clijsters after 'foul-mouthed' outburst

US Open 2011: Sam Stosur lifts crown after Serena Williams rants at umpire in women's final

It‚Äôs up to the officials whether further discipline is appropriate for Ms. Williams, but I‚Äôd like to address the damage done by such bullies to officials. Mr. Ramos is neither rich nor famous, he‚Äôs just a person who loves the sport enough to endure abuse from bullies in order to protect the sport‚Äôs integrity. What bothers me, however, is that high-profile athletes hurt the sport by pushing for a double standard - rules which are applied only to the ‚Äòlittle people‚Äô. Never forget that Ms. Williams did not lose to a wall, but to a talented newcomer Naomi Osaka. Ms. Williams essentially wanted the officials to help her win the tournament, and that is unconscionable behavior. Apart from the code violations, the bullying by established players for unethical advantage is one of the things against which good officials must fight. Safety, sportsmanship and fair play are the ideals which all officials must put above any other concern, but it‚Äôs very difficult for an official to endure harassment in public from famous and egotistical bullies. Serena Williams demanding an official ignore the rules is the same as Bryce Harper (of the Washington Nationals* MLB team) demanding umpires only call a strike zone he likes, or Ndamukong Suh (of the Detroit Lions NFL team) demanding officials ignore his brutal violence against other players. It takes guts for an official to penalize a popular player who goes out of bounds, and it‚Äôs the responsibility of everyone who believes in the integrity of the sport to support good officials.

(*team corrected, Evan Joz caught the mistake)

US Open 2009: Serena Williams loses to Kim Clijsters after 'foul-mouthed' outburst

US Open 2011: Sam Stosur lifts crown after Serena Williams rants at umpire in women's final

It‚Äôs up to the officials whether further discipline is appropriate for Ms. Williams, but I‚Äôd like to address the damage done by such bullies to officials. Mr. Ramos is neither rich nor famous, he‚Äôs just a person who loves the sport enough to endure abuse from bullies in order to protect the sport‚Äôs integrity. What bothers me, however, is that high-profile athletes hurt the sport by pushing for a double standard - rules which are applied only to the ‚Äòlittle people‚Äô. Never forget that Ms. Williams did not lose to a wall, but to a talented newcomer Naomi Osaka. Ms. Williams essentially wanted the officials to help her win the tournament, and that is unconscionable behavior. Apart from the code violations, the bullying by established players for unethical advantage is one of the things against which good officials must fight. Safety, sportsmanship and fair play are the ideals which all officials must put above any other concern, but it‚Äôs very difficult for an official to endure harassment in public from famous and egotistical bullies. Serena Williams demanding an official ignore the rules is the same as Bryce Harper (of the Washington Nationals* MLB team) demanding umpires only call a strike zone he likes, or Ndamukong Suh (of the Detroit Lions NFL team) demanding officials ignore his brutal violence against other players. It takes guts for an official to penalize a popular player who goes out of bounds, and it‚Äôs the responsibility of everyone who believes in the integrity of the sport to support good officials.

column3: Why is Roger Federer so popular?
column4:
On court:

After decades of players with bad behaviors, i.e. Connors, McEnroe, NƒÉstase, etc it was refreshing to finally see someone displayed toughness without loudness or my gosh rudeness. Quiet determination, and he has gotten quieter as he mature.
Roger seems to genuinely enjoy the game, not just the competition. He pursues excellence by behaving like an engineer in search of last bit of extra efficiency, and he seems to enjoy that process.

Roger‚Äôs approach to tennis was like Nikki Lauda‚Äôs approach to driving, winning by understanding the game. At age 34, he modified his backhand, at 32, he modified his net game.
Being an all court player, he displays a wide variety of shots, which made watching him more fun.
Apparently graceful even in defeat, if he was bitter with Nadal, Roger has done a great job hiding it. Gentlemen‚Äôs sport, remember?

Off court:

Seems to get along well with his rivalries, not only Nadal, but Nadal‚Äôs family reportedly enjoy Roger‚Äôs company.
Always seems to have a smile ready, and seemingly enjoy the media, he approaches media in a humble and low key ways, and rarely, if ever, put his foot in his mouth. Even his jokes, although not always funny, but always appeared to be good-natured.
No enemy, and good at staying out of controversy or trouble.
Happy family man popping out babies in regular intervals. Not an actress/model chaser, do not trade in for something skinnier ever few years.

SO, a good-natured family man that enjoys and excels at doing what he does. An apex competitor that has no apparent enemy on or off the court. For an increasingly aging first world audiences, an old man owning generations of younger players.

Tell me, what‚Äôs there not to like?

column3: How did Rafael Nadal gain so much popularity?
column4:
The main reason why Rafael Nadal is popular is because he challenged Federer in a time where everyone though Fed was invincible. An added bonus was that both were, and still are, extremely respectful to each other. But that‚Äôs the slightly boring reason everybody knows already. Here‚Äôs the fun part:

Nadal is popular because he is a model player, relatable, and his style of play is scintillating to watch.

In his autobiography, ‚ÄúRafa‚Äù, Nadal recounts his uncle forcing him to tend to the clay courts he played on, as well as absolutely forbid him to smash his racket. Viewers have watched and noted throughout the years his odd yet good behavior of never breaking a racket out of rage, something even the usually emotionless Federer has done in the past. Nadal also shows the utmost respect to other players, often calling Federer ‚Äúthe perfect player‚Äù. Of course, it helps that Nadal is VERY attractive and has huge muscles. ;)

In addition, Nadal is relatable. Much like Stan the Man Wawrinka, who is described as ‚Äúworkman-like‚Äù, Nadal does many of the things that regular people do. He doesn‚Äôt have a private jet; he flies commercial instead. In his autobiography, he recounted one of the times he struggled to fit his trophy in one of the overhead compartments of the plane. During the Olympics, to the amazement of his fellow players, he washed his own clothes. In addition, he, much like a majority of tennis, has become tired of reporters asking him about his ‚Äúbromance‚Äù with Federer. In one interview, he even sarcastically replied something to the effect of ‚ÄúOh yes, I love him and I want to kiss him‚Äù to roaring laughter.

Last but not least, Nadal‚Äôs style of play is ridiculously fun to watch. Everyone loves a player who can chase down balls consistently and hit winners from anywhere on the court. Many times, the opponent will have driven Nadal off the court and hit a shot that would have been a clear winner to any other opponent, but WHAM! Nadal obliterates the ball back, leaving the opponent unable to do anything but trudge back to the baseline. Add in dropshots, slices, and tweeners, and you get a complete player who everyone wants to watch.

column3: Why does a player get three or four tennis balls from ball boys and choose two among them for serve?  What is that they look for in selecting the balls to serve?
column4:
First of all I will answer how actually tennis ball works. It has compressed air inside it that is under high pressure which makes the ball tough and on the outer side is fur.


The amount pressure inside the ball is responsible for its bounce and height of that bounce. With time the pressure inside reduces and hence new balls are taken many times during matches.
The fur outside the ball is reason for its different speed after bounce. Obviously cause of friction.With time the furr also gets eroded due to friction.


Now most tennis players like me learn all this through practice and not through physics, but these are the questions a player solves while selecting the ball in their mind:


What shots the opponent cant play well? If he can play the bounce well and ground badly then player chooses pressure less balls. This makes ball lay low and go fast. Opponent won't be able to play it. Fur in this case doesn't matter but generally more fur is preferred cause the ball goes fast with it on hard surfaces. The ball kind-of slides because of the fur.
What shots can we play well? If we are extremely good at top spin (top spin is when the ball goes with a certain projectile and spins or bounces more, this happens cause you Roll the ball) then we choose hard ball with more pressure so that it will bounce well and move fast. If we play flat then we can choose any ball with fur cause we don't care about the bounce. Fur will make it go faster and for flat players, faster the better.
What court are we playing on?


This is really important cause we always want ball to travel fast. So the court will decide the amount of fur on the ball.

These all basic points are taken into consideration while serving and choosing the right ball to win.

column3: What have you learned from Rafael Nadal?
column4:
Although I belong to the opposite camp and am a huge admirer of Roger Federer, you just can‚Äôt really sit back and not hail a man of the stature of Rafael Nadal. Here are the things that one can learn from Rafael Nadal:

Anyone can reach the top, through hard work and perseverance.

Nadal‚Äôs rise to the top is not only significant because of the man he dethroned (Federer), but also because he never gave up. It is easy to get intimidated by those at the top.

Federer‚Äôs overwhelming dominance was unchallenged and he marched his way through to grand slams after grand slams, burying any competition in the process. Nadal was the cog, between Federer and complete dominance, as he handed him consecutive defeats in 2005 (semis), 2006, 2007 and 2008 finals of the French Open. People will argue that Nadal was the clay sensation, but he did it on grass as well.

After a disappointing defeat in the 2007 Wimbledon Final in a grueling 5 setter, Nadal came back strong and defeated Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final, in five of the most epic sets in men‚Äôs tennis history.

Excelling at multiple fronts is possible.

Nadal is the prime example of utter domination in your preferred field and maintaining that level outside. With a jaw-dropping 10 French Open titles, Nadal has undoubtedly established himself as a clay legend. But Nadal also has his name on 2 Wimbledon, 2 US Open and 1 Australian Open titles and a host of other titles on different turfs.

It is easy to go down, but very difficult to pick yourselves up and regain your previous stature.

There have been a number of times that people had deemed Nadal as down and out, but every time he came back stronger. His early exit against Lukas Rosol in the 2012 Wimbledon, brought about an avalanche of setbacks and injuries for the Spaniard and people wrote Nadal off.

But he came back strong in 2014 and defeated Lukas Rosol at the same stage in Wimbledon. After a string of poor performances in 2015 and 2016 mostly due to injuries, it seemed like the end of an era.

But Nadal prevailed, fighting off opponents with injured knees and elbows sometimes and hit back again this year, with the juggernaut facing just one defeat on clay on his way to a 10th French Open, reminding of vintage Nadal in the process.

Always give back something to the society, whenever you can.

Nadal has excelled on the philanthropy front as well and has set up tennis academies across the world to support budding talent in tennis. He has an academy at Anantpur, India as well and pays regular visits to inspire children.

Talent makes you a king, sportsmanship and humble nature make you a legend.

Nadal has always been in the good books of his peers and fans, due to his humble nature and the ability to give appreciation where it is due. Federer vs Nadal is one the most epic rivalries in sports history, but never have the two men spoken ill of each other.

Nadal‚Äôs admiration for Federer and the rest of his peers for that matter, even after facing heart breaking losses against them, make him a legend.

column3: What is Roger Federer like in real life?
column4:
My experience with Roger goes back to 2007. He came to India for seeing those victims affected from the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami since he was part of UNESCO. Exactly at 4 pm he came to my district, Cuddalore. There were 50 kids who lost their parents waited to see him, and the humble man along with his wife went to see all those kids. He literally turned like a kid played with each & every one and learned some local languages (Tamil). At one point some kids got fear due to a lots of flashes that came from the photographer, some even cried and this man had tears in his eyes too. He didn't care what dress they wear and hugged each & every one with same amount of love...

At last he was to leave the area. I was waiting with my notebook to get his autograph. He closed the door and suddenly opened the car door again and called me near to him and gave his autograph with a lovely smile :)
For me Roger is better and best human than the best player ..!

column3: Why hasn't there been a supermatch between Serena Williams and Roger Federer?
column4:
Because there is no point of having this match . Federer will win . How ?

In 1998 , Venus williams and Serena Williams claimed that they could beat any male player ranked outside the world's top 200. Karsten Braasch(ranked 203) agreed to the challenge and defeated the williams sisters 6‚Äì1 and 6‚Äì2.

Serena williams is a great player but she can‚Äôt win against Roger Federer . Even Fernando Verdasco or Tsonga can defeat her on regular days. If you only want a game for fun then sure it can happen. But a competitive match ? I don‚Äôt think so.

column3: What determines a ball to be out in tennis?
column4:
Tennis uses the Hawk Eye system, very successfully, to determine whether the ball is in or out. As the boundary lines are about the same width as a compressed tennis ball striking the ground, the ball is considered in if any part of it touches any part of the line.

The ball is out if no part of the ball touches the line:

The umpire and linesmen/lineswomen can call a ball out any time they like, but if a player uses Hawk Eye to challenge a decision, then Hawk Eye gets the final say.

Hawk-Eye is built from a network of 10 cameras around the court that capture 60 high-resolution images per second. At least five cameras cover every bounce of the ball.

Players are given unlimited opportunities to challenge a call in each set at Wimbledon.

However, once three incorrect challenges are made, that player can‚Äôt challenge again until the next set.

If the set goes to a tiebreak, an extra challenge is awarded to each player.

It rarely happens, but the umpire can reject a challenge if it is an ‚Äúunreasonable request or... not made in a timely manner‚Äù, according to the International Tennis Federation rules.
