column3: Why didn‚Äôt Federer play his best tennis at the Australian Open 2018?
column4:
Considering that he hadn‚Äôt lost a set until the final, and only had one rough patch of play in his first set against Berdych, maybe we should rephrase the question to ‚ÄúWhy didn‚Äôt Federer play his best tennis in the AO 2018 Final?‚Äù

The short answer is, aside from a serving lapse when he lost he serve twice (and almost three times) in a row when serving at 3‚Äì2 in the fourth, Federer played at a very high level but was forced to adapt his game to the demands placed by his opponent.

Casual fans are probably asking themselves what happened to all the big backhand winners and the forays to the net? The answer is, this final was completely different from last year, where Federer's brilliant play, especially off the backhand return, won him the title.

Taking nothing away from Federer and his incredible achievements, this was a match where Cilic's play determined the outcome. Here are the factors that gave Cilic control of the second and fourth sets and a chance to break serve at the start of the fifth set:

After a poor start, Cilic started taking chances on every shot, and during the second and fourth sets he played the best tennis I've ever seen him play. Unlike his victory in the 2014 US Open semis, Cilic forced Federer into defensive situations from almost the first ball in each rally.
The depth, placement and pace of Cilic's ground strokes (his average backhand was faster than Federer's average forehand) seemed to ignore the laws of physics. He seemed to be playing within one foot of the lines on almost every shot. No matter how well Federer hit a shot, Cilic just hit it back harder. There were a number of long exchanges where Federer was crushing his backhand cross court, and it had absolutely no effect on Cilic. When Federer finally opened up the court by hitting up the line, Cilic not only got there, he hit huge shots in response.
Unlike Nadal, who returns and rallies from far behind the baseline, Cilic is very good at Federer‚Äôs strategy of staying close to the baseline in rallies, and then stepping up into the court when he gets a ball he could attack. This tactic takes time away from your opponent, and with Cilic‚Äôs greater pace, Federer was the one who was under pressure all the time. There were some amazing points where both Federer and Cilic were hitting ground strokes of the half volley at the baseline (one of Federer's most amazing abilities) to maintain control of the point.
Cilic has improved his first and second serve over the last few years. When it was on, he was able to control the points from the first shot on, and Federer was doing everything in his power just to keep the ball in play. During the second and fourth sets, his serve was good enough that Federer missed a couple of shots where he tried to step in and attack the return. I think this made Federer get a little tight, and hope that Cilic would make enough errors to lose the match, instead of Federer winning the match.

To his credit, Federer recognized how well Cilic was playing, so he did everything he could to stay in points in the hope that his opponent would cool off:

He chipped most of his backhand serve returns, taking hardly any chances to rip returns on break points, hoping Cilic would make an error. If the match had stayed close in the fifth, I think Federer would have finally understood that his only hope to win would be to take chances.
He sliced a lot of backhands, trying to make Cilic work to get down on low balls. In the first set, this worked as Cilic made a lot of errors. There was a match stat that showed Federer was hitting slice backhands over 60% of the time. This is much tougher for tall players, and, in the case of Cilic, a means of wearing down an opponent who had played six hours and 400 points more than Federer throughout the tournament. However, when Cilic got hot, he started to punish the slices, and Federer started hitting more topspin backhands (the TV graphic showed that the ratio was 50‚Äì50 in the second set). I don‚Äôt know the ratio of the later sets, but there were so many rallies where each player was trying to outhit the other, I would say it was similar to the second set. As I wrote above, Cilic was covering the court so well and hitting so big, fans underestimated how well Federer was actually hitting the ball. I think a lot of his shots would have been winners or forced weak returns against pretty much any other player.
Federer hit a lot of balls into the middle of the court, to take away angles from Cilic, and also to jam him. Tall players have long arms, so when they run wide for a ball, it allows them to stretch out and hit in total freedom. If you don‚Äôt hit a winner against them, they may hit a winner off your shot. Federer learned this the hard way. After hitting a large number of aces wide of the forehand in the deuce court, Cilic hit a couple of massive cross court winners, which forced Federer to change his serving patterns. In spite of this, Federer hit some gutsy second serves, especially a wide one in the deuce court that came on a break point in the fourth set.

The one thing that kept Federer on top was his fantastic serve. And the reason he won is the difference between Cilic and prime Djokovic in the consistency and depth of their serve returns. Cilic took a few chances and hit some huge winners, but missed or got aced on tons of points. At the 2011 US Open, Federer served 11 aces against Djokovic; at AO18, he hit 24 against Cilic.

On the other hand, Cilic simply couldn‚Äôt keep playing at his other worldly level for five sets. Whether it was a case of getting nervous, finally running out of gas, or the law of probabilities catching up to him, Cilic started missing a lot of first serves and began to make errors in the fifth set. Once Federer got up a break, Cilic's energy level dropped and he made too many errors to stay competitive in the last three games of the match.

Conclusions

Cilic played two sets at the same level as Del Porto‚Äôs 2009 US Open Final. They are very similar in size and style, and at their best are part of a very small group of players who move well enough and have enough power to neutralize Federer‚Äôs forehand and force him to play defense on most of the points. But Federer is so good and so consistent, it‚Äôs extremely difficult to maintain that level of play over an entire match as evidenced by Federer‚Äôs head-to-head record against these great players: 9‚Äì1 vs Cilic; 18‚Äì6 vs Del Potro; and 20‚Äì6 vs Berdych.

NOTES:

Federer‚Äôs path to the title might have also devalued his play in the eyes of casual fans. Last year, he beat three Top Ten players (Nishikori, Wawrinka, Nadal) in five set matches, with an expected quarter final match against then #1 Murray. This year, none of the top seeded players made it far enough to create the same quality matches, so people thought he had an easy draw.

In reality, Federer‚Äôs side of the draw should have been incredibly hard, filled with players who have either beaten Federer, won Slams or are more than ten years younger: Zverev (#4); Thiem (#5); Goffin (#7); Wawrinka (#9); Del Potro (#12); Djokovic (#14); Berdych (#19); and Raonic (#22). 10 of the 16 seeds have won matches against Federer. Aside from Djokovic (22‚Äì23), Alexander Zverev (3‚Äì2), and Thiem (1‚Äì2) who are basically tied with Federer in head-to-head matches, the rest of the field combined to win 22 matches against Federer (22‚Äì115).

Compare that to the top half of the draw. Aside from Nadal, only Tsonga (6‚Äì11), Kyrgios (1‚Äì1) and Isner (2‚Äì5) have even won matches against Fed. He is a combined 41‚Äì0 against the remaining seeds.

Aside from Djokovic (22‚Äì23), Alexander Zverev (3‚Äì2), and Thiem (1‚Äì2) who are basically tied with Federer in head-to-head matches, the rest of the field combined to win 22 matches against Federer (22‚Äì115).

Compare that to the top half of the draw. Aside from Nadal, only Tsonga (6‚Äì11), Kyrgios (1‚Äì1) and Isner (2‚Äì5) have even won matches against Fed. He is a combined 41‚Äì0 against the remaining seeds.", 'aiModelVersion': '1'}

column3: Should Roger Federer consider retirement?
column4:
Sometimes you're just happy playing. Some people, some media, unfortunately, don't understand that it's okay just to play tennis and enjoy it. They always think you have to win everything, it always needs to be a success story, and if it's not, obviously, what is the point? Maybe you have to go back and think, Why have I started playing tennis? Because I just like it. It's actually sort of a dream hobby that became somewhat of a job. Some people just don't get that, ever.

- Federer, Shanghai 2012

And even in defeat the guy says, "I'm impressed" with the serve and volley tactic used against him. I mean, how much more into the game can you get? Just let the guy be. He has earned that right.

Source: http://www.atpworldtour.com/News/Tennis/2012/10/41/Shanghai-Thursday-Federer-Recalls-Rise-To-Top.aspx

Federer: No Need To Panic

column3: What is your favorite tennis moment?
column4:
For me, this is it. 4th set tie break 2008 Wimbledon final.
To understand the significance of this point one must know little about the Federer-Nadal Rivalry and the build up to this match.

Federer was the reigning champion and almost untouched on grass courts. He won his first Wimbledon in 2003 and was on his way to win sixth one. He was looking strong and hadn't dropped a set on his way to the final.
Nadal won his first French open in 2005 and since then their rivalry has only intensified. Nadal was also showed great promise, reached finals of major events consistently (winning many of them) and had reached his 4th consecutive finals. Previous Wimbledon results when they played each other:
2006 - Fed beat Nadal in 4 sets.
2007 - Fed beat Nadal in 5 sets
2008 - Huge expectations were riding on his game.

Before this match, together they had won 14 of the last 16 slams amongst them. Federer was playing to win 6th Wimbledon title in a row (that Borg missed) and Nadal was playing to become the third man in open era to win French and Wimbledon in the same year (after Borg and Laver). Before the final Federer and Nadal had played 3 times in the year 2008, all three clay court finals which Nadal won. Their head to head was 11-6. But Nadal was thirsty for a victory on grass. Federer stood tall with 65 straight wins on grass courts.

The game started and the unexpected thing happened. Federer lost the first two sets 6-4. Mind you Federer had beaten Nadal before twice in 5 setter games (Wimbledon 07 and Miami 04) and one of them (Miami) was where he came back from 2 sets down. Could he repeat the feat?



The third set began and each held his serve till the rains interrupted at 5-4 Federer leading. This is when Mirka walked upto Federer and said ‚ÄúYOU are Roger Federer‚Äù to invigorate him. Even the ever composed, Toni Nadal chose to have a siesta in the locker room and shake of the anxiety. The match resumed and Federer managed to pull the third set from Nadal 7-6 (5) in the tie break.

The fourth set began and each player held his serve till 6-6. The future of the holy grail of tennis was to be decided on this tie break. It began and after a few points Federer found himself trailing 5-2 with Nadal to serve. If Nadal held his serves Fed was done. But Nadal got nervous and double faulted and put a weak backhand into the net. The score moved to 5-4. Federer also held his two serves; Federer leads 6-5. Federer now had a set point and Nadal had to hold his serves to keep himself alive which he did; score progressed to 7-6 in favour of Nadal. Nadal on match point and Federer holds his serve 7-7 with a great serve followed by mini break (my heart break); 8-7 to Nadal. But this was no ordinary break Nadal had just hit the best pass of the match. Fed was almost sure of winning this point but Nadal is not letting him have his way. He clinches his point out of Federers claws. What this point meant to both was clearly seen on their faces, Federer was almost destroyed and in despair and Nadal had almost felt the trophy.


(Kindly watch the videos)

But the drama was not over it. Federer is Federer and is known for his magic. This was THE moment. He came up with this own stroke of genius and it was most elegantly done. And this pass was my favourite tennis moment. My heart never ran faster and I have never felt more relieved.

Nadal had everything in his favour. He likes to serve from the left side of the court to Federer backhand forcing him out of the court and having the court empty for the winner. He did exactly that. Served on Fed backhand, Fed chipped and he came in another shot into Federer backhand and Nadal was at the nets. Fed had to pass him or else it was all over. If he did he would be in the fifth set with a great 5 setter record and his surging confidence from winning the last two sets would help him in the fifth. Nadal on the contrary could second guess himself for not converting the 3rd and the 4th sets. To raise the stakes, it was set point and match point and Championship point for Nadal. Fed had to pass him, he had to pull the rabbit out of the hat.

And He DID. He pumped in disbelief and clawed his way back to push the match into a fifth set.


This was the greatest match I have seen. Finally the better man won.
"I tried everything," said Federer. "But Rafa's a deserving champion, he's the worst opponent on the best court."

"I must congratulate Roger," Nadal said. "He's still the No1, he's still the best, and he's won five times here. But now I have won, and that's very important to me."



This should sum it up:


Hills spokesman Graham Sharpe said: "What you have here are two players at the peak of their powers and popularity. "They are almost a tennis soap opera - traditional Federer appeals to the mums and dads with his cardigan, and Nadal is the modern sex symbol, appealing to kids with his sleeveless vests. (Wimbledon 2008: John McEnroe hails Rafael Nadal victory as greatest final ever - Telegraph
)


You might also like:
Vijay Singh's answer to Why do most people consider Roger Federer to be better than Rafael Nadal?

column3: Should Naomi Osaka give back the US Open title in solidarity with Serena Williams?
column4:
Look at the Smile of Tennis Players when they Won their 1st Grand Slam Title

Roger Federer

Rafael Nadal

Novak Djokovic

Andy Murray

Martina Hingis

Venus Williams

Maria Sharapova

Last but not least Serena Williams

What a great smile :)

Now look at Naomi Osaka‚Äôs face during the presentation ceremony.

Instead of smiling she cried and covered her face.

Can we ask Serena Williams/Fans/US Open team to organize a similar stage to get back the smile? Not fair right. Similarly it is not fair to ask THE CHAMPION to return her title.

CONGRATS OSAKA. Wish to see a great smile during the next presentation.

Note: I am a huge Tennis Fan and have great respect for Serena. But Osaka deserved more, that‚Äôs my point.

Image Source: Google web search

column3: Is Carlos Alcaraz the future of men's tennis?
column4:
Yes. In every way.

2022 has been Carlos Alcaraz‚Äô breakout year as a tennis player. He‚Äôs only 19, but he‚Äôs already reached World No.1 (making him the youngest ATP No.1 ever) and won his first Grand Slam, becoming the youngest Grand Slam winner since Nadal in 2005, and the 7th-youngest ever. We‚Äôve had plenty of new players pick up speed over the last few years, like Medvedev, Tsitsipas, and Zverev, but none of them have been this good so early.

Part of the reason other players haven‚Äôt had a chance to shine is because Nadal and Djokovic keep dominating. Alcaraz is one of the few players to give them a run for their money in every match. Look no further than the Madrid Open, where Alcaraz beat Nadal and Djokovic (arguably the two greatest clay court players of all time, especially Nadal) back-to-back on clay. Nobody has ever beaten those two back-to-back on clay. In fact, Alcaraz was the first teenager to ever beat Nadal on clay. That‚Äôs big.

But Alcaraz is more than that, he‚Äôs also an amazing role model in tennis. Rafael Nadal was Alcaraz‚Äô idol growing up, and he strives to demonstrate the same sportsmanship as Nadal in every match. It shows.

Alcaraz never smashes his racket, never attacks his collegues in interviews, and regularly extends grace to his opponents during a match. On multiple occasions, Alcaraz has even replayed points because it was a close call and his opponent was frustrated. Very few players do that.

That‚Äôs the kind of attitude and example the Big 3 set, and it‚Äôs very encouraging to see another tennis star carry it forward. We need more humble, compassionate, earnest players on court who can show their fans what it looks like to lose with grace and win with grace.

Sharing a warm handshake with one of his biggest rivals, Jannik Sinner. Usually, you meet at the net, but Sinner came over to Alcaraz‚Äô side instead.

And in terms of playing style, Alcaraz is also a very complete player.

His athleticism is unbelievable. Like Nadal when he first debuted, Alcaraz has a habit of wearing his opponents down with sheer stamina and speed. He somehow sprints to the ball every point, always stretching for that next return, forcing another mistake from his opponent.
His groundstrokes are top-tier. Alcaraz has impressive strength, especially for only 19, and slams his forehands and backhands to the back of the court forcing his opponents furhter toward the baseline. He has consistency similar to Djokovic‚Äôs, and over time it will only improve.
His shots are very diverse. One of Alcaraz‚Äô favorite moves is his drop shot. He has a well-disguised, light drop shot that often ends a point after his opponents are pushed too far back to get to the net again. Federer liked doing that too.

Overall, I‚Äôm excited for Alcaraz‚Äô career. He‚Äôs got a lot of experience already and certainly enough confidence. Couple that with his playing style, and he should win a lot of Grand Slams before he retires.

And more importantly, he‚Äôs a good role model for players and fans alike.

2022 has been Carlos Alcaraz‚Äô breakout year as a tennis player. He‚Äôs only 19, but he‚Äôs already reached World No.1 (making him the youngest ATP No.1 ever) and won his first Grand Slam, becoming the youngest Grand Slam winner since Nadal in 2005, and the 7th-youngest ever. We‚Äôve had plenty of new players pick up speed over the last few years, like Medvedev, Tsitsipas, and Zverev, but none of them have been this good so early.

Part of the reason other players haven‚Äôt had a chance to shine is because Nadal and Djokovic keep dominating. Alcaraz is one of the few players to give them a run for their money in every match. Look no further than the Madrid Open, where Alcaraz beat Nadal and Djokovic (arguably the two greatest clay court players of all time, especially Nadal) back-to-back on clay. Nobody has ever beaten those two back-to-back on clay. In fact, Alcaraz was the first teenager to ever beat Nadal on clay. That‚Äôs big.

But Alcaraz is more than that, he‚Äôs also an amazing role model in tennis. Rafael Nadal was Alcaraz‚Äô idol growing up, and he strives to demonstrate the same sportsmanship as Nadal in every match. It shows.

Alcaraz never smashes his racket, never attacks his collegues in interviews, and regularly extends grace to his opponents during a match. On multiple occasions, Alcaraz has even replayed points because it was a close call and his opponent was frustrated. Very few players do that.

That‚Äôs the kind of attitude and example the Big 3 set, and it‚Äôs very encouraging to see another tennis star carry it forward. We need more humble, compassionate, earnest players on court who can show their fans what it looks like to lose with grace and win with grace.

column3: What are your thoughts on Carlos Alcaraz's stunning Wimbledon 2023 title win?
column4:
It's a Sport defining moment.

I regard this win as a change of baton from an already legend to a legend in making.

Having seen how Medvedev plays, I was surprised how Carlos humbled him in straight sets in semifinals. It asked me to watch the big final. Even before the match started, I thought this took me back to 15 years, where a similar thing had happened. A young sensation in Nadal was up against an established Federer, who had won 5 consecutive Wimbledon titles till that point. And here Alcaraz was against Djokovic, who hadn't lost a Wimbledon title since 2018 and is a phenom on Grass courts.

The first set lasted for what, just 34 minutes. Djokovic was at his usual best and thrashed the youngster in no time. Many would've felt ‚ÄúIs it going to be another easy final win for Novak?‚Äù at that point. Alcaraz struggled a bit in the first set and in the start of the second set. He needed to turn the things, and turn them quickly.

Slowly Alcaraz started to get into his grooves. He started returning the serves well. And the crowd was literally behind him. Obviously irked Djokovic like always. Novak being Novak gave back to the crowd with his gestures. But with the progression of the game, Djokovic looked lost. He looked tired very soon, which was highly unexpected. And then, Djokovic committed a lot of unforced errors, actually throughout the match from there.

The second set went to the tiebreaker. Djokovic hadn't lost a tiebreaker in his last 9 games. In a thrilling tiebreaker, Alcaraz held his nerve and got the better of Novak. The Serbian looked lost. He is always cheerful when he plays and likes to give it back to the crowd instantly. But for the remainder of the game, he was so silent. It was probably the first time I'd ever seen Novak not being himself.

In the third set, Alcaraz displayed his best form. He just thumped the World no.2. Alcaraz was leading 3‚Äì1 when that incredible game happened. The game lasted for 26 minutes. 13 deuces happened and none liked to give away the game. Eventually, Alcaraz double broke it for a huge cheer from the crowd. For the first time, Djokovic looked under pressure in Wimbledon, in a very long time.

A commentator perfectly remarked the moment and said ‚ÄúNow Djokovic is feeling how it's like to play against himself‚Äù. It was so apt. Alcaraz was on a different level. The most impressive trait from Carlos was his return, which is very strong BTW. His forehand is mighty dangerous and he has terrific speed. He can cover the court very well. He was particularly good with his disguised drop shots.

Garfia claimed the third set. Djokovic took a break of more than 6 and a half minute to rejuvenate himself. A much needed break indeed. He came back and played better. The Spaniard was at his best. But Djokovic displayed his strength and equalised the match by winning the fourth set. It's believed that as the match goes deep, into the fifth set, Djokovic‚Äôs chances of winning increases manifold. But here, Novak was facing himself !

The fifth set was thrilling. The crowd was literally behind the Spaniard. The 20-year-old hit some wonderful aces. His strong serve was too hot to handle for Djokovic. There was also a peculiar problem throughout the game for the Serbian. He missed out too many loosener and struggled to cope with the balls that bounced a bit more.

Alcaraz was so good at hitting the ball in the gaps. His running forehand reminded me how Nadal returns the ball, genuinely. Garfia played some outrageous shot, including the shot of the match where he returned a well placed ball from Novak and produced a more empowered return which had no answer from the 23-Grandslam winner.

Towards the end, Alcaraz looked confident. Very rare for an athlete when against Novak in the fifth set of a match. As Djokovic hit the net, Carlos fell and couldn't believe what he had achieved, very similar to how Nadal celebrated his 2008 Wimbledon win against Federer. Finally, the GOAT was brought down ! Alcaraz won his first ever Wimbledon, at the age of just 20.

The Spaniard has 2 Grandslam titles already at the age of 20, in two different surfaces, despite being injury prone. It was his best game till date. Watching him play confirmed of a greatness. Without a doubt, he's a legend in the making. The World No.1 embraced his coach, who was emotional in the moment and was happy for the youngster.

Novak too‚Äå, was emotional. The crowd which was against him as usual, won the battle against Novak. It was probably a but too much for even a mental freak like Djokovic that he shed tears towards the end of his final speech and thanked the family for being with him.

Will remember this game for a long time.

Alcaraz, you beauty !

On a side note, Alcaraz did what I exactly expected from him.

Image credits - Instagram, Quora.

Thank you.

column3: What made Rafael Nadal a fan favorite?
column4:
When he first came around, Nadal had three big things going for him.

For one, he was young. One of the youngest players on tour, proving himself as one of the toughest players on tour despite only being 17. Fresh new players winning big games at such a young age is a big draw to tennis, as fans love to see a new star.

Nadal was arguably the greatest teenage player in the history of tennis.

But besides his age, Nadal was a warrior.

Every rally, every point, every game, was a battleground and Nadal would never be the one to give up. Unlike Federer, who relied on quick points and winners to clinch his games, Nadal relied on sheer grit and determination. He was fast, strong, and had ridiculous endurance. As long as the point was within reach, he absolutely refused to stop. Fans loved that. It made for exciting rallies and some unbelievable shots.

Still, there was one more characteristic of Nadal‚Äôs play that set him apart. He was a true sportsman.

Nadal never smashed his racket, no matter how frustrated he got. He stayed serious and focused in every game, refusing to let deficits or mistakes ruin his mindset. Sure, he wasn‚Äôt one to applaud his opponent after a good point, but he was also not one to criticize or mock his opponent for any reason. And when the match was over, he shared a handshake and left with his dignity intact, no matter the result.

Fans loved that too. Compared to Federer, who at the time was still a bit of a hot head, Nadal was the sportsmanlike one who always respected his opponents.

Historically, that was unusual for a tennis star. Sure, Stefan Edberg shared that mentality but more famous players like John McEnroe were notorious for tantrums and poor sportsmanship. Nadal helped influence the standard we have now, where all of the Big 3 consistently demonstrate sportsmanship on and off the court.

That‚Äôs how Nadal became a fan favorite, and has stayed one ever since.

column3: What's it like to work as a ball boy?
column4:
I have just recently finished my tenure as a Ball Boy for the Eastbourne International tennis tournament after being part of it for four years running. In answer to your question: bloody hard work but amazingly good fun, and the sense of camaraderie rivals war veterans!

Me in an action shot with Pliskova a couple of weeks ago. This was on centre court - Cap. ~8000.

I first learnt about my school offering the chance to be a ball boy when I was in Year 7, at the tender age of 11. Back then, it was the first year to allow Year 7‚Äôs to join, as before that only Year 9‚Äôs and up were deemed to be up to the task. The first year was very difficult, and this was not helped by the fact that the person who took charge of our vigorous training was an angry Scottish woman who would immediately kick you out if you committed the cardinal sin of rolling twice between serves (when the player has a second serve, any movement out of the corner of their eye could distract them.) This was not a joke - I actually saw it happen on at least one occasion, with the offender (a fellow Year 7) being led off in tears.

The training began in January, in preparation for the tournament in late June, and consisted of 2‚Äì3 hours each week of intensive training, first with the teachers as players, and later on, at a local tennis club. The attrition rate is normally around 50‚Äì60% of people leaving or being kicked and over time, those of us who managed to stick the training found our runs and rolls to be second nature - I still instinctively have to tell myself not to jump to get the ball when it hits the net while watching Wimbledon on the TV!

A further aspect of our training was to learn how to deal with the tricky players. If a player drops a racket, wants chilled or room-temperature water, wants us to hide their towel because the ‚Äúflash of white distracts them‚Äù (I‚Äôm looking at you, Wozniacki) or some other OCD trait, we have to accommodate them as best we can.

Wozniacki at Eastbourne this year - very scary woman.

After the first year of training, I only managed to make it two days into the main tournament before being kicked out. No matter, I was hooked, and couldn‚Äôt wait to be better next years.

The subsequent years of ball crew meant I got progressively better and better at knowing instinctively where and when the balls go at the end of each point, and I found myself more and more able to adapt quickly to a player‚Äôs preference, even in extreme cases like just before this shot was taken:

Me looking very grumpy - I was so embarrassed when my mates pointed this out after the fact.

I can‚Äôt remember the exact circumstances of this, but I‚Äôm pretty sure I had had to run off to re-string one of the player‚Äôs rackets (that is - take it to the racket stringer somewhere in the player‚Äôs building) and by the time I came back, I had no clue whatsoever what was going on so I was just trying to look sensible and cogent.

I can still remember the acute pressure and anticipation I felt when the announcer called my team onto centre court for the first time and 8000 people gave us a round of applause as we ran into position. It was exhilarating!

This past year, I managed to make it onto centre most days, and if not centre, then a ‚Äòshow court‚Äô at least. I was very pleased with my performance, and if this year does turn out to be my last (as I‚Äôve just left secondary school - the school that provides the ballcrew), then I‚Äôm glad I managed to crew on finals day for some of the best players around.

I leave you with a brief recap of what goes through ball boy and girls‚Äô minds on a daily basis while crewing.

Dodgy mum‚Äôs camera quality alert

Is this the end of the game? - ok it‚Äôs going to be even number of games so the balls switch sides, that means next game the players come off. Make sure the crew at the back of the court can get the umbrellas open and that they‚Äôre awake. Also the reserve might need to go off court to get a ball so keep an eye on her behind me. Is this a one-sided game? - it is, so the game will probably go quickly. Also it‚Äôs men playing so mind out for awry aces. When‚Äôs ball change? - ok 3 games away, that means that the players should stay on for ball change unless it‚Äôs a new set which it looks like it might be so bear that in mind. Ah shit the scoreboarder has messed up so I‚Äôll have to keep the score in my head. Also the just keep an eye on the umpire as it looks like it might rain and they‚Äôll have to call off play. Etc etc‚Ä¶

And this is even before I actually go anywhere near a tennis ball.

This was not a joke - I actually saw it happen on at least one occasion, with the offender (a fellow Year 7) being led off in tears.

column3: Who is Roger Federer?
column4:
ROGER FEDERER is a Phenomenal Tennis Player, a True Legend. Many commentators and players regard Federer as the greatest tennis player of all 
time..

Federer holds several records of the Open Era
: holding the world No. 1 position
 for 302 weeks (including 237 consecutive weeks
); winning 17 Grand Slam
 singles titles; reaching each Grand Slam final at least five times (an all-time record); and reaching the Wimbledon
 final ten times.

Not only having a high Sportsman Spirit, he is a True Gentleman.
One such incident happened recently.

This incident is from US Open 2015. This time the Swiss ace ended up surprising them on the court but not just by playing.On 3rd September 2015, after his second round victory over Belgium‚Äôs Steve Darcis, Federer was out for practice at Flushing Meadows, only to find the court in a mess with towels and bottles strewn around.

While the other players, expecting the court to be cleaned by the staff left it as it is, Federer here took sportsmanship to a whole new level and helped dispose of the bottles and towels in the bins provided.

‚Äã

‚Äã

‚Äã

‚Äã

‚Äã

‚Äã

Ladies and Gentlemen,
THIS IS ROGER FEDERER.
Way to go Roger Federer. You teach us more than just tennis.

SOURCE- Twitter

column3: Tennis:
column4:
I wrote an answer to a similar question called: What is it like to win Wimbledon?. It's very similar as Wimbledon is a Grand Slam.

What it's like to win a Grand Slam and/or Wimbledon is one of the common question I get asked in interviews. Strangely, it's also one of the worst and most difficult to explain simply.

I think the feeling of achieving the dream you had as a child, the thing you want more than anything, what you've been working towards almost your entire life is near impossible to describe.

There are so many emotions involved that it's very difficult to put into words. However, I suppose the quick and easy way to explain the feeling for me is that it's a combination of tremendous pride and joy. Pride as I achieved the goal that I was aiming for when I was a young kid. Joy because I got to share that moment with my friends, family and coaching staff.

I also consider myself lucky, despite my many injuries, as I had the right attributes to be able to reach my goal. Many people have dreams, goals and ambitions that just don't go together. For instance I love playing guitar but I just don't have the talent or commitment to sound like Eddie Van Halen no matter what I do.

I think anyone can have a similar feeling to what I had when winning a grand slam. It's about finding your true passion and combining that with your natural talents. Honestly listening to yourself and working towards and with something you love.

Also, here is my Wimbledon celebration climb which was quite controversial at the time. I think it says a lot about how I was feeling at the time. It starts around the 10.40 minute mark.

- - - -

Soon I‚Äôll be sharing a more in depth interview I did on winning Wimbledon (I‚Äôll update this post). I also share talks I have with other tennis stars like Sampras, Safin, Emerson, etc., in my newsletter. If you‚Äôre interested consider signing up here
.

column3: Among Nadal, Federer and Djokovic, who do you believe will have the most grand slams at the end of their careers?
column4:
First of all, congrats to Novak Djokovic on winning the 20th grandslam title. Right now, the guy is on a different level.

Earlier in the year, he won the 9th Australian open title at his favourite den.
He won his second French open title by beating the king of clay Rafael Nadal in the semis and became only the third player after Roy Emerson and Rod Laver to win all the grandslam titles at least twice.
Now, he has won his sixth Wimbledon title, third in a row. He has also become the first player after Rod Laver to win the first three grandslam titles in a year.

With his win at Wimbledon, he has equaled the number of grandslam titles with his counterparts. Now, each of the big 3 have 20 grandslam titles each..!

It's one of the greatest era of tennis and the three greats have certainly made the sport more interesting with their play.

An important factor as to decide who would end their career with most grandslams would be ‚Äòthe age factor‚Äô.

Djokovic is 34, Nadal is 35 and Federer is 39 as of now. Certainly, Djokovic has a big advantage here.

I genuinely believe that Federer's reign in the tennis world is up and he's over trying to get some titles before his body finally gives up. In my opinion, he would retire with 20 grandslam titles intact.

Nadal, if remains fit, can win 4‚Äì5 titles in my opinion. With clay court being his favourite, he might win 2‚Äì3 titles there and might somehow grab a couple of titles somewhere.

Djokovic, has the best chance of winning more titles among the three. He's almost a robot and is consistently winning or at least challenging his opponents in each and every tournament. He can win 8‚Äì9 titles going by his fitness, current form and age factor.

So, according to me, it's Djokovic who's going to finish with more grandslams among the big 3.

Give me your opinions.

Image credits - ATP Tour, Google.

Thank you.

column3: Do feminists actually believe that Serena Williams would stand a chance against Novak Djokovic?
column4:
Some of them do seem to believe that. For example, here is a quote from olympic swimmer and nine time medalist Leisel Jones: ‚ÄúFemales are just as good at sport as men are - if not better.

‚ÄúWe can go back to Serena Williams. If you put Novak Djokovic next to her, I think Serena Williams would flog him every single day over.‚Äù

This quote amazes me coming from an athlete of this caliber. It seems her ability to reason has been clouded by her passion for physical equality between men and women. I agree wholeheartedly with life equality, but that's not the question. The question is, are men physically dominant? Specifically, in sports, are the men at the top of their game, better than the women at the top of their game?

Does Leisel Jones think she can beat Michael Phelps at any event or distance in swimming? All she has to do is compare her times with his, and it is obvious that she cannot. The question cannot arise with any intelligence in sports such as weightlifting, 100 yard dash, running marathons, or any sport with measured time or weight.

It would be a much better question in bowling, darts, auto racing, archery, skeet shooting, chess, poker, golf, and even ultra distance swimming. Tennis, however, does not fall into this category.

I understand why some people ask the question if they do not closely follow tennis. Strategy, belief and mental fortitude play significant roles in tennis. But only when and if strength, endurance and power are fairly close.

Novak vs. Serena is a complete and total mismatch. Novak is equivalent to Roger Federer and Rafa Nadal, and the three of them dominate the rest of the men's field. Please understand, it is just a simple fact that Serena Williams has zero chance of beating any of those three players unless they had a major injury. Yes, you heard correctly‚Ä¶Zero. It would never be close on any day or on any surface. It would be complete and total dominance. Even Serena knows this. When being interviewed for an exhibition match against Andy Murray, she said she would do well if she won a single game.

The men serve faster, hit ground strokes much harder, move much faster and dominate in court coverage.

On an off day for Novak and Serena's best day‚Ä¶ she has no chance.

column3: Why don't tennis players have ripped bodies?
column4:
Generally, ‚Äúripped‚Äù means you have good muscle definition. I can assure, the vast majority of tennis players have excellent muscles definition:

Tennis is a very lean sport, where you want to be agile and quick, which is why players usually look very thin. However, every tennis player also needs to generate a lot of power on their serves and their returns, meaning they need solid upper-body strength. Additionally, tennis requires explosive speed, meaning extra weight training for sprinter type speed, running up and down the court, starting and stopping quickly.

So it may look like tennis players are skinny people without much muscle to show, but there‚Äôs more than meets the eye.

I saved the best for last.

column3: Which is more, the speed of the fastest ball bowled in cricket or the fastest serve in tennis?
column4:
Tennis ball wins the race against the cricket ball.

A 60g Tennis ball has travelled at 263 kmph,

Whereas a 160g cricket ball has attained only 161.3 kmph as its max limit.

If interested in knowing about the fastest moving objects in sports, A squash ball which travels at 280+ kmph, beats a Tennis ball.

A Golf-ball which travels at 330+ kmph beats a squash ball.

Any guess on which object beats all these?

The innocent-looking badminton birdies can travel at 493 kmph

column3: Which is more, the speed of the fastest ball bowled in cricket or the fastest serve in tennis?
column4:
Okay.

The fastest ball ever bowled on records is 161.3 by the great Rawalpindi Express , Shoaib Akhtar against England in 2003 World Cup.

The fastest serve ever recorded is 163.4 recorded by Australian Sam Groth
 at an ATP Challenger event in Busan, South Korea in May 2012.

Seems pretty close,no?

By now you must have realised what I have done wrong. :P

The units haven't been shown.

The tennis serve is in miles/hour.

The ball is in kilometres/hour.

Using km/hour as a reference, the fastest tennis serve is 263 km/hour.

That's atleast 100km/hour faster than Akhtar's express pace.

To out that in context, a batsman has 0.44 seconds to face Akhtar's fastest ball.

But if he were to bowl at Groth's serve, the batsman will have 0.27 seconds to react, which nearly impossible to face unless you are lucky.

Let's just hope bowlers don't get inspired by tennis players.

column3: Given that Sweden used to produce legendary tennis players such as Bjorn Borg, Mats Wilander, and Stefan Edberg, why has Swedish tennis been so underwhelming lately? Are Swedes no longer interested in tennis?
column4:
Tennis has traditionally been an upper class sport. A very, very upper class sport. To the point that Rod Laver, undisputed master of the sport in the 1960s, was ostracised among tennis players for not being upper class; he had the nerve to be good at tennis while being only middle class.

And then, there was Bj√∂rn Borg. Unrepentant working class. Not interested in what anyone thought about who should play tennis, not interested in what others thought about him, simply being insanely focused on being the best tennis player ever.

When he had played his first real match at the age of 13, he walked off the court with tears streaming down his cheeks. He had won. But he didn‚Äôt win 6‚Äì0, 6‚Äì0. That‚Äôs how focused he was on being the best.

And then in 1976 he won Wimbledon, and suddenly, everyone in Sweden was playing tennis. Despite the ‚Äúupper class‚Äù label, it isn‚Äôt an immensely expensive sport, and it quickly became what we term a ‚Äúfolk sport‚Äù.

And it was from that base that Wilander and Edberg came. For a while, most countries still only recruited tennis players from the upper class; Sweden recruited them from the entire population. The best in Sweden were the most talented in a population of 8 million; no country has an upper class that big. That‚Äôs how success breeds success.

Today, everyone else has caught up. And our tennis players are pretty much what you can expect from a population of 10 million: a couple of decent ones, no stars. Undoubtedly, we will one day have someone who wins tournaments, but not in the near future.

column3: Why did Federer get emotional when his boys entered the center court in Wimbledon 2017?
column4: When the girls were born he said his goal was to play until they were old enough to remember him on court, competing and winning‚Äîespecially at Wimbledon. This will probably not be possible with the boys, although the girls were trying to make them pay attention. He loves his family a great deal; his biography says that he plays for Mirka because she can't anymore (she had to retire early because of a foot issue); now, I‚Äôd wager he is playing for all of them. Catching their eyes was obviously an emotional moment and it encapsulates how much he loves both tennis and his kin.

column3: What is Roger Federer like in real life?
column4:
Here is my second story about Roger Federer.

Back in 2003, he was in the finals of the ABN Amro tournament in Rotterdam, and I had tickets to go see it with my 13 year old daughter, who was at the time (and is even more so now) his #1 fan.

Typical of teenagers, I had to shake her out of bed (Westin Hotel) at 10 AM to get going for the day and she somehow dragged herself out and got ready. When we went downstairs we saw 2 cars parked in front of the hotel with the ABN Amro logo and 2 guys waiting around. We asked them and were told that they were waiting for Mr. Federer.

Excitedly we hung out in the lobby and he came down a few minutes later carrying his own tennis kit and alone. I encouraged my daughter to go up to him which she did and addressed him in Swiss German (we live in Switzerland). He chatted with her happily for a few minutes, signed an autograph and posed for a picture until his entourage came down. Remember that he was on his way to play a final, which would normally leave most sportsmen tense and stressed and hardly wanting to be accosted by a teenager in the hotel lobby!

He is a great guy - and he gave his #1 fan a huge boost, and made me the best Dad in the world as well!

column3: What are some tips for a good tennis serve?
column4:
The serve is one of the 6 basic strokes
 in tennis and is the only one that a player has total control over. This makes it one of the most important strokes in the game. It is also the most technically complex out of the 6 core strokes which is why many players struggle with it.

I‚Äôve been lucky enough to coach Mark Philippoussis
 and Greg Rusedski
, two of the great servers in tennis, and I‚Äôll give you some beginner tips on how to improve your serve below. By the end of this post you‚Äôll be able to serve as well as them‚Ä¶ Just kidding ;) But the principles and tips will at least bring you closer.

Fundamental mechanics of tennis.
All strokes in tennis (including the serve) are a sequence of motions referred to as a ‚Äúkinetic chain‚Äù. It begins at a player‚Äôs feet, extending through the legs, hips, chest, shoulders, arm, and wrist to the racquet as it impacts the tennis ball. The kinetic chain allows the build up, storage, and transfer of energy to generate power for your shot.

Biomechanically
 sound tennis technique comes from your kinetic chain working in concert. Bad technique and injuries are the result of dysfunctional movements within your body‚Äôs kinetic chain.

What does this mean?

Essentially it means you want all parts of your body to work together and in harmony. In other words the correct amount of rotation, up/down movement, side-to-side movement, and forward/backward momentum will result in the best possible serve technique.

Now that you understand the basic technical principles let's move on to the tips.

General serve tips.
Before I get specific here are a few general things to keep in mind: A) stay relaxed, B) keep your technique simple, and C) don‚Äôt worry too much about how to move your arm as this‚Äôll take care of itself if the fundamental serve technique is good.

Serve stance.
Before starting, make sure you‚Äôre standing behind the baseline. Next place your feet in a side on stance where if you drew an arrow between the tips of your feet it‚Äôd point towards your opponent (this may feel a little strange at first but will help with power) like this:

Serve Grip.
Finally, grip the racket in your dominant hand using a continental grip (like you‚Äôd hold a hammer) and hold the tennis ball in your non-dominant hand. Now you‚Äôre ready to start serving.

How to serve step-by-step.
The core elements and movements of a serve can be broken down into stance, take back, ball toss, swing, contact point and follow through. I‚Äôll walk you through each of these below.

For the purpose of this instruction I‚Äôll assume you‚Äôre right handed. Here is how to serve in eight steps:

Step 1: Begin your service motion by holding your racket and ball in front of you.
Step 2: Start your momentum forwards by leaning towards the opponent, toss the ball in the air with your non-dominant arm while dropping your racket arm straight back. The ball toss and backswing happen simultaneously.
Step3: Now your body should be in a ready position, fully coiled and ready to unload.
Step 4: As the ball moves into striking position above your head start uncoiling by driving up through your legs, rotating your body, and pulling your non-dominant arm down.
Step 5: Continue extending and uncoiling as your racket arm whips up and around following the rest of your body.
Step 6: At this stage your body and head position
 should be facing or almost facing the net as you pull down and make contact with the tennis ball.
Step 7: As you continue the follow through your body should be falling forward and to the left as your racket arm whips through the ball and slightly to the right.
Step 8: Finally, as you finish your serve motion you‚Äôll land on your left foot in in the court while your dominant arm finishes it‚Äôs swing on the left side of your body (if you‚Äôre right handed).

John Isner serve.

Taylor Dent Serve.

Goran Ivanisevic Serve.

If you‚Äôve followed the steps and watch the gifs closely you‚Äôll see that despite their different styles and minor differences the fundamental movements are almost identical. The reason I picked these examples is because they illustrate best practice principles that the average player (and other pros for that matter) should follow.

- - -

For even more in depth tips check out my free coaching app
 and sign up for my newsletter where I share member exclusive tennis tips and instruction not found anywhere else. Sign up here.

 in tennis and is the only one that a player has total control over. This makes it one of the most important strokes in the game. It is also the most technically complex out of the 6 core strokes which is why many players struggle with it.

I‚Äôve been lucky enough to coach Mark Philippoussis
 and Greg Rusedski
, two of the great servers in tennis, and I‚Äôll give you some beginner tips on how to improve your serve below. By the end of this post you‚Äôll be able to serve as well as them‚Ä¶ Just kidding ;) But the principles and tips will at least bring you closer.

Fundamental mechanics of tennis.
All strokes in tennis (including the serve) are a sequence of motions referred to as a ‚Äúkinetic chain‚Äù. It begins at a player‚Äôs feet, extending through the legs, hips, chest, shoulders, arm, and wrist to the racquet as it impacts the tennis ball. The kinetic chain allows the build up, storage, and transfer of energy to generate power for your shot.

Biomechanically
 sound tennis technique comes from your kinetic chain working in concert. Bad technique and injuries are the result of dysfunctional movements within your body‚Äôs kinetic chain.

What does this mean?

Essentially it means you want all parts of your body to work together and in harmony. In other words the correct amount of rotation, up/down movement, side-to-side movement, and forward/backward momentum will result in the best possible serve technique.

Now that you understand the basic technical principles let's move on to the tips.

General serve tips.
Before I get specific here are a few general things to keep in mind: A) stay relaxed, B) keep your technique simple, and C) don‚Äôt worry too much about how to move your arm as this‚Äôll take care of itself if the fundamental serve technique is good.

Serve stance.
Before starting, make sure you‚Äôre standing behind the baseline. Next place your feet in a side on stance where if you drew an arrow between the tips of your feet it‚Äôd point towards your opponent (this may feel a little strange at first but will help with power) like this:

Serve Grip.
Finally, grip the racket in your dominant hand using a continental grip (like you‚Äôd hold a hammer) and hold the tennis ball in your non-dominant hand. Now you‚Äôre ready to start serving.

How to serve step-by-step.
The core elements and movements of a serve can be broken down into stance, take back, ball toss, swing, contact point and follow through. I‚Äôll walk you through each of these below.

For the purpose of this instruction I‚Äôll assume you‚Äôre right handed. Here is how to serve in eight steps:

Step 1: Begin your service motion by holding your racket and ball in front of you.
Step 2: Start your momentum forwards by leaning towards the opponent, toss the ball in the air with your non-dominant arm while dropping your racket arm straight back. The ball toss and backswing happen simultaneously.
Step3: Now your body should be in a ready position, fully coiled and ready to unload.
Step 4: As the ball moves into striking", 'result': {'fake': 0.0075, 'real': 0.9925}, 'status': 'success'}, {'text': 'position above your head start uncoiling by driving up through your legs, rotating your body, and pulling your non-dominant arm down.
Step 5: Continue extending and uncoiling as your racket arm whips up and around following the rest of your body.
Step 6: At this stage your body and head position
 should be facing or almost facing the net as you pull down and make contact with the tennis ball.
Step 7: As you continue the follow through your body should be falling forward and to the left as your racket arm whips through the ball and slightly to the right.
Step 8: Finally, as you finish your serve motion you‚Äôll land on your left foot in in the court while your dominant arm finishes it‚Äôs swing on the left side of your body (if you‚Äôre right handed).

John Isner serve.

Taylor Dent Serve.

Goran Ivanisevic Serve.

If you‚Äôve followed the steps and watch the gifs closely you‚Äôll see that despite their different styles and minor differences the fundamental movements are almost identical. The reason I picked these examples is because they illustrate best practice principles that the average player (and other pros for that matter) should follow.

Before I get specific here are a few general things to keep in mind: A) stay relaxed, B) keep your technique simple, and C) don‚Äôt worry too much about how to move your arm as this‚Äôll take care of itself if the fundamental serve technique is good.

Serve stance.
Before starting, make sure you‚Äôre standing behind the baseline. Next place your feet in a side on stance where if you drew an arrow between the tips of your feet it‚Äôd point towards your opponent (this may feel a little strange at first but will help with power) like this:

Serve Grip.
Finally, grip the racket in your dominant hand using a continental grip (like you‚Äôd hold a hammer) and hold the tennis ball in your non-dominant hand. Now you‚Äôre ready to start serving.

How to serve step-by-step.
The core elements and movements of a serve can be broken down into stance, take back, ball toss, swing, contact point and follow through. I‚Äôll walk you through each of these below.

For the purpose of this instruction I‚Äôll assume you‚Äôre right handed. Here is how to serve in eight steps:

Step 1: Begin your service motion by holding your racket and ball in front of you.
Step 2: Start your momentum forwards by leaning towards the opponent, toss the ball in the air with your non-dominant arm while dropping your racket arm straight back. The ball toss and backswing happen simultaneously.
Step3: Now your body should be in a ready position, fully coiled and ready to unload.
Step 4: As the ball moves into striking position above your head start uncoiling by driving up through your legs, rotating your body, and pulling your non-dominant arm down.
Step 5: Continue extending and uncoiling as your racket arm whips up and around following the rest of your body.
Step 6: At this stage your body and head position
 should be facing or almost facing the net as you pull down and make contact with the tennis ball.
Step 7: As you continue the follow through your body should be falling forward and to the left as your racket arm whips through the ball and slightly to the right.
Step 8: Finally, as you finish your serve motion you‚Äôll land on your left foot in in the court while your dominant arm finishes it‚Äôs swing on the left side of your body (if you‚Äôre right handed).

Taylor Dent Serve.

Goran Ivanisevic Serve.

If you‚Äôve followed the steps and watch the gifs closely you‚Äôll see that despite their different styles and minor differences the fundamental movements are almost identical. column3: Will Roger Federer finally be crowned GOAT if he wins his 8th Wimbledon this year and 19th Grand Slam?
column4: No doubt he is already beyond legendary status in the game. An additional 8th Wimbledon crown will just be another topping (which by the way will be surprising if he loses at this point to be honest). But like what everyone else here have already stated, it‚Äôs simply not fair and quite impossible to name someone as the Greatest Of All Time. Too many factors to consider but most especially is that you simply cannot compare between generations of players. Surfaces played on, level of competition, equipments used, technology of the time, etc. etc. If we are merely basing it on number of grand slams won then Serena Williams would take the cake (but of course sexism, etc. etc.).

column3: What are some of the mind-blowing facts about Roger Federer?
column4:
Never retired midway through a tennis match, In spite of playing over 1000 matches, Roger Federer has never retired hurt from a match. Nadal and djokovic both did 7 and 11 times respectively
In the 2014 Shanghai Open, he served an incredible 47 second game to the then reigning world number one, Novak Djokovic. he served four back to back aces and took the game in under 50 seconds.
His sister also had twins, he already has two sets of twin kids, two girls and two boys. and now he become uncle to twin.
In 1998, he won the Junior Wimbledon, where he won both the boys‚Äô and singles final. Later that year, he lost the US Open Junior final to David Nalbandian. He won 4 ITF junior singles tournaments in his career.
In 2006, he won 12 singles titles with an impressive match record of 92‚Äì5. Federer reached 16 of the 17 finals during this season.
he spent at cumulative total of 302 weeks at no.1, more than any other player ever.
Federer's strange association with number eight Born on 8/8/1981, eight is his favorite number, he reportedly carry 8 racquets. along with 8 water bottles. he also has won 8 Wimbledon Singles titles.

thank you

column3: What's the most underrated achievement in tennis?
column4:
In 1997 a 16 year old Martina Hingis became the youngest ever in the tennis history to become a world number 1. She also became the youngest ever to win 3 slams in an year. She is also the youngest ever to win a unique achievement of winning all 4 slams in doubles in a calendar year and she did that at the age of 17.

These records will probably never be broken. She also made a record 6 consecutive Australian open finals winning 3 of them and losing 3 of them. All these happened before the age of 21.

She spent 200+ weeks at number in Tennis before retiring at the age of 21. Most of the tennis players start winning slams at that age and become world number 1 but Martina Hingis already spent 200+ weeks won 5 slams lost 7 slam finals and made a few Semi Finals too. Won 8 double slam titles. Everything before the age of 22. She retired from Tennis at that age of 22 and later made a comeback in doubles tennis.

All this is simply incredible and it is probably impossible to repeat all those achievements which she did before the age of 22 for any player. Hence this is one of the most underrated achievement which not many people talk about but it is a great achievement which only a very few talented people can achieve at that age.

column3: Was Andy Roddick truly an exceptional tennis player, or did he take advantage of a lull in top-tier talent between Pete Sampras' retirement and Roger Federer's ascendence?
column4:
He was absolutely exceptional.

When Roddick was only a teenager, he beat three Grand Slam winners: 29-year-old Pete Sampras (14 Grand Slams), 29-year-old Michael Chang (1 Grand Slam, and then World No.1 Gustavo Kuerten (3 Grand Slams). Roddick ended up winning 3 titles and rose to World No.15 in his first full year as a pro. That‚Äôs an incredible start to a teenager‚Äôs tennis career. Keep in mind, Federer had turned pro two years before, and didn‚Äôt win his first title until after Roddick‚Äôs.

That‚Äôs why, when his career started out, many fans considered Roddick the next brightest star of tennis. Eventually, Federer came into his own and took that top spot, but Roddick didn‚Äôt fall off. He continued to compete with the Big 3 for the next 10 years on tour. Fun fact: Roddick still holds a winning record over Novak Djokovic, 5‚Äì4. Admittedly, his last match against Djokovic was in 2010, before Djokovic became nearly unbeatable in his 2011 and 2015 seasons, but it‚Äôs still a solid feat.

Now, it‚Äôs true that Roddick never did manage to win a Grand Slam in the Big 3 era. He made it to three Wimbledon finals, but never had the juice to pull out a win. Nevertheless, he proved himself on court. Like most players in the 2000s, 2010s, and even 2020s, he suffered from playing in the toughest tennis era ever.

So, while Roddick wasn‚Äôt exceptional to the same degree as the Big 3, he was still one of the best players on the tour in his prime.

column3: Was the game penalty handed to Serena Williams in the 2018 US Open Final reasonable?
column4:
I had originally not replied to this question because I thought Carey Page‚Äòs reply covered it so well. But after commenting on another answer, a number of users asked that I post my comment as an answer here. So here are some thoughts:

The problem with many people‚Äôs criticisms of Ramos, and with their understanding of what happened in this match can be explained by the difference between what fans and commentators have seen, and what they think they‚Äôve seen. I don‚Äôt mean this as an attack; it‚Äôs part of how the human brain works. Let me explain what I mean.

The racquet smash: When someone says that ‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen many rackets smashed without any violations handed out.‚Äù, I believe that they believe that, and that they could have sworn they‚Äôve seen it frequently. And I believe they‚Äôve heard other people say that. But the fact is that it almost never happens. In fact, I‚Äôd ask you to do a search for a televised Grand Slam match from the last three years, and find more than one instance of a racquet being smashed to the point of being broken, and no code violation being handed out. The reason I say this is that the umpires are given specific guidelines for the assessment of racquet abuse, and they actually can get in trouble from their supervisors when they don‚Äôt hand one out. There is far more likelihood of suspected corruption when they don‚Äôt call this than when they do, because it has been considered standard since the current code violation system has become codified. There are certain things left to an umpire‚Äôs discretion, but breaking a racquet is not one of them. And neither is the code violation progression of warning, point, game, match. So if you see a player break a racquet on their second code violation, you can bet they got the point penalty. I‚Äôll go as far as to say you‚Äôll have a very hard time finding a current instance of it not happening. But I‚Äôm open to changing my mind if you can find a bunch. Please submit video links here if you can find instances of it.

The coaching violation: Similarly, there has been a lot of talk about how rampant coaching is among the pro ranks. And that much is true. However, the line that ‚Äú100% of the players do it 100% of the time‚Äù could not be more false. (Also even if it were true, the ‚Äúeverybody does it‚Äù defense doesn‚Äôt hold water with speeding tickets, school fights or any kind of cheating in life, and it also doesn‚Äôt here either.) During the regular tour year, most WTA events actually allow courtside coaching. And the women become quite used to it. There is also frequent coaching from the sidelines, although some of it is more subtle than others. But every player on tour knows that the rules against it are more strict at the Slams, and the incidence goes down somewhat. Further, every single player on tour knows that Ramos is famously strict about coaching from the stands. His application of the rule to Serena was totally consistent with similar calls that he‚Äôs made in high profile tournaments against Nadal and other top players. The thing is that most players and coaches know this, and simply don‚Äôt do it when Ramos is calling the match. Whether Patrick had a momentary memory lapse or simply thought he was above Ramos‚Äôs rule, he made what amounts to a rookie error. And Ramos has consistently called people on it. So it wasn‚Äôt overstepping and it wasn‚Äôt unexpected. The fact is that there wasn‚Äôt a single video (or even a still frame) of Osaka‚Äôs coach, Sascha Bajin, doing any coaching in this match. That‚Äôs because he didn‚Äôt do it. (But again, if you can find any footage of Bajin making any kind of signal during the match, please post it here.) That‚Äôs not to say he never has, but he was too smart to do it in this situation. Signalling a player from courtside in an internationally televised Slam final with Ramos in the chair is tantamount to flipping Ramos the bird. It‚Äôs just asking for it. So once again, I‚Äôm sure you feel like you‚Äôve seen coaching happen a lot. Or more likely just heard other people say it. But it‚Äôs not the case here. And if anything, Osaka‚Äôs coach would have had more to say in this instance, because he‚Äôs Serena‚Äôs former coach and hitting partner! He had all kinds of insight into Serena‚Äôs game. But he didn‚Äôt risk his charge‚Äôs match, because he knew what every other person on the tour knows: that Ramos is likely to call it as he has many times before. Regardless of how often it is cited overall in other venues by other umpires, coaching at a Slam on Ramos‚Äôs court is going to get called. It‚Äôs not bad officiating. In fact, the tour regards him as one of their best because he does this. They only wish the other umpires had the spine to do it more often and more consistently themselves, just as Ramos does.

The verbal abuse code violation: The first misunderstanding that viewers have is the idea that Ramos had a choice about what punishment to give Serena. They could have sworn they‚Äôve seen players do more and get off with less. But this is because they don‚Äôt understand the code violation system. With two code violations already under her belt, Ramos didn‚Äôt just decide to penalize her a game. He HAD to. After two code violations, he can do only one of two things; give a game penalty, or act like there is no code violation at all and do nothing. He is no longer allowed to give her a warning. She used that up when Patrick gave her signals. That‚Äôs how the system works. It‚Äôs not a judgment call. Rather than say something to Serena as many suggest, which would have broken the protocols and potentially gotten him sanctioned for not following procedure, he allowed her to continue and repeatedly abuse him for a while, because he didn‚Äôt want to default her. But she was relentless. She would not stop repeating her accusations and demands. There was no chance he could say that he didn‚Äôt hear or see what she was saying. She forced his hand. The game penalty was not out of the blue at all. It came after a warning and a point penalty, and after him not responding to a barrage of abuse over multiple changeovers.

And here is where the other misunderstanding that casual fans have comes into play. There is the mistaken belief that somehow curse words are the worst thing ever. But no one believes this apart from religious zealots and young children. What really matters is WHAT is said, and HOW it is said. The Grand Slam rulebook specifies that any attack on an umpire that ‚Äúimplies dishonesty or is derogatory, insulting or otherwise abusive‚Äù is a code violation. The fact that he let her say it repeatedly first, and didn‚Äôt hand out the code violation until after multiple repetitions was lenient in and of itself. Just because some other (male) players use words like ‚Äúfuck‚Äù or ‚Äúshit‚Äù more often when yelling doesn‚Äôt automatically make what they said worse. Impugning the umpire‚Äôs character or honesty (which ironically is what Serena said made her upset in the first place when she mistakenly thought he did it to her) is why that part of the code exists at all in the first place; to protect the integrity of the sport and its officials and prevent them from accusations like the one Serena made. Because they can be career ending and damage the entire game. Saying things like that is serious business not only in tennis, but in almost every sport, and that‚Äôs why you so rarely hear it done. And the combination of that and actual threats, while missing a few curse words that people are wrongly focused on, was far more egregious than anything I can remember seeing go unpunished in the modern men‚Äôs game. But again, please feel free to find any footage at all of a man repeatedly and aggressively both calling the umpire dishonest or a cheater, and threatening him or his livelihood, and then not getting a code violation. I‚Äôm guessing you‚Äôll find it‚Äôs harder to find than you think. And that you haven‚Äôt actually seen the men do worse once you know how the rules are written and why. It‚Äôs not Ramos who did something that you don‚Äôt do in Slam finals. It‚Äôs Serena. She was the one who tried to abuse her power as the most prominent figure in tennis, and assumed she could operate above the rules that bind every other player. The reason this instance seems so isolated is that, after receiving both an official warning and a point penalty, almost no other players continue to play fast and loose with the rules. But when they do, they are always penalized for it. If people want to assert otherwise, it‚Äôs important to supply specific examples, which no one has been able to do yet.

The reason I say this is that the umpires are given specific guidelines for the assessment of racquet abuse, and they actually can get in trouble from their supervisors when they don‚Äôt hand one out. There are certain things left to an umpire‚Äôs discretion, but breaking a racquet is not one of them. And neither is the code violation progression of warning, point, game, match. So if you see a player break a racquet on their second code violation, you can bet they got the point penalty. column3: What do you think about Serena Williams losing her match? Was it sexism or her behavior?
column4:
I got into a debate about this at another site, and I said she got what ‚Äúshe deserved‚Äù‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶and was immediately pummeled by SJWs, because ‚Äúthat would never happen to a man‚Ä¶‚Äù

I calmly pointed out that in 1984 John McEnroe was fined the maximum fine at that point ($7,500‚Äîa little over $18,000 if adjusting for inflation) and received a 21 day suspension for pretty much the same type of behavior.

I was then informed that even if McEnroe received analogous treatment that it was rare for a man‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶I pointed out that it is rare in general, for a man, a woman, anyone, period.

I was then informed that I was a racist and a sexist, and that my opinion on this was irrelevant because I am ‚Äúan old white man‚Äù‚Ä¶

So it really doesn‚Äôt matter what I say, my opinion is worthless based solely upon my age, race, and gender.

‚Ä¶so much for the SJWs and inclusiveness.

In the meantime, I can sum this up with with what I originally posted in that earlier discussion:

‚ÄúIf you want to act like John McEnroe, expect to be treated like John McEnroe‚Äî she got what she deserved, no more-no less.‚Äù

column3: What are some of the mind-blowing facts about Roger Federer?
column4:
Roger Federer once went 105 points without an unforced error.

Yes,that's right a whopping and unbelievable 105 POINTS!
This was against John Isner in US open 2007!


Here is a snapshot at 98 consecutive points.
Hail,Roger!

:D
