column3: What is Roger Federer like in real life?
column4:
I don't think there is a better way to describe what a mensch Roger Federer is than this fan's touching story. Credit to Mashable for the story - Fan's Touching Story Will Make Roger Federer Your Favorite Athlete 

The whole story of how I got to meet Roger Federer and how it was: Well, I had cancer in 2011/2012, and there's this foundation called the Make A Wish Foundation. They grant wishes to kids, teens and yound adults who have life-threatening diseases. I made my wish in 2012, and my wish was to meet Roger Federer. I waited for more than a year, and I didn't really know if they were gonna be able to grant me this wish (you have second and third options) since Roger has such a busy schedule and it was taking such a long time. In June I was told that ESPN was doing a piece on high school tennis and they were gonna film a bit of my school tennis team. So I went there and we had practice and in the end they told us we had a culminating activity that would kinda test our knowledge of tennis. They gave us an iPad to watch something, and it was the Wimbledon 2012 match point (that already got me like really excited) but then after Roger falls to the ground they cut the video and Roger shows up in a kind of home made video or something, and he says "Hi Beatriz, I heard you're a big fan of mine, so I'm inviting you with your family to come watch me play at Wimbledon. Go pack your bags, have a safe trip, and I'll see you there!" (!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!) I freaked out so so so badly. I couldn't believe it haha. All I could think was "OMG ROGER FEDERER KNOWS MY NAME!" Haha.




So, yeah, this was on a Monday, and my flight to London was on that Thursday (I barely had any time to freak out) and I live in the US so... But yeah, then I found out ESPN was doing a piece on my wish and it's actually gonna air in August :) anyway, I got there and the very next day I met Roger! First I went to the nike house, where players get their gear and everything, and they actually gave me lots of stuff, all white since it was Wimbledon. Then we went to the All England Club where I was actually gonna meet him. We were waiting on the place where players eat and hang out. However, the guys from ESPN told me we might not see him that day because schedules change a lot. So I wasn't expecting anythint, just sitting watching some practices and someone calls my name. I turn and it's FREAKING ROGER FEDERER. He comes up, gives me a hug and a kiss and then sits down and starts talking to me very naturally. I was trying hard not to freak out haha. We talked for about 10-15 minutes (which I was told later he wasn't supposed to do. He was just supposed to come and say hi and then go to practice but he's a perfect human being and talked to me for a while!) oh my gosh this is getting very long haha. After that he went to practice, but he told me to go change, because I was gonna watch his practice from inside the court and maybe we could hit a little bit after he was done. He told me that he would send someone to take me to the court because like no one is allowed in the courts except the players and coaches. So I changed and went there, and I was waiting for someone to come take me to the actual court when I hear someone call my name and oh my god it's Paul Annacone. He sent PAUL ANNACONE to get me. So I go to the court and am introduced to Sev and Steph, and then sit there watching his practice with Hewitt (!!!!).

After his practice he tells me we're gonna hit for a while and Sev says "but she doesn't have a racquet" and Roger is like "she can use one of mine" (!!!!!!!) so he reaches into his bag and gives me one of his racquets to hit with (!!!!!!). I was really scared because I'm not like amazing at tennis, I'm pretty good, but not out of the ordinary, and even if I was, it was freaking Roger Federer. But Paul and Roger told me not to be scared, it was so cute haha. So we hit for a bit, then he told me to come up and volley and he went up too. Paul told me not to be scared of Roger in the net 'cause it was all pressure, he wasn't even that good haha. Then he served and oh my gosh it's fast even though he wasn't even close to full speed. After that he went over the net, shook my hand and gave me a kiss on the cheek (!!!!!!). Then we walked (and talked) together to the other court where he was going to practice more with Hewitt. I watched this second practice and then after they were done Roger came up to me and said "well that's my day" and we talked for a bit more, and then he said "I'll see you on Sunday" (this was a Friday) and I freaked out because oh my gosh I was gonna see him again!!! So yeah that was it for this day. On Sunday the guys from ESPN told me I was gonna take a tour of the grounds, even though I had already taken one when I went to London for vacation. The more time at Wimbledon the better haha. But then when I'm waiting to take the tour I find out that the people who are giving me the tour are the Chairman of Wimbledon (!!!!!!) and Roger (!!!!!!!). Like, OH MY GOD. So yeah, they took me around, and to the walk the players take to get to Centre Court, and then to actual Centre Court, with everything being explained to me by Roger and the Chairman. After we got to Centre Court Roger had to leave earlier than us because he had his press conference (which I was going to), so he left us there to see a bit more of Centre Court. AND on his way out he talked to the main guy that gets Centre Court ready, to let me actually go there. Like, I stepped on the grass on Centre Court because of Roger. He's perfect oh my god. And then we took a while there so his manager called the girl from ESPN to ask her if we were going because Roger was waiting for me to start the press conference (!!!!!!!!!!). OMG HE IS PERFECT. So we went to the press conference and saw everything, and then on my wait out I passed Roger and he was like "So did you like it? Me getting grilled by the press?" He's always so dorky and funny haha. And then the people from ESPN took us to the players lounge because Roger was gonna sign some stuff for me after he had done all of his interviews (a lot of them) and gotten a award (you know, just usual stuff).

I was sitting there waiting for him and it was amazing because I saw soooo many other players. Tsonga asked to get one of the chairs in our table actually haha. I saw Murray, Nadal, Haas, Ferrer, Benneteau, Tipsarevic, Serena, Wozniacki, Radwanska, Lisicki, like, so many of them from up close. It was like heaven for a tennis fan haha. But then Roger finished his interviews and sat at out table with us. I had so many things for him to sign but I knew he was busy so I just took 4 pictures (one for each one in my family) and then 4 blank papers and my tennis bag, and gave for him to sign. He actually addressed the blank papers to each one of us, it was so perfect. In mine he wrote a bit more, and even a happy birthday!! (Did I mention it was my 18th birthday??) And then he asked me "is that it?" and I said "yes" and he was like "are you sure? Don't be embarrassed about it." He's so amazing and kind. So I gave him the rest of the stuff to sign. And he was just sitting there signing and chatting with me, but his manager was telling the guys from ESPN that he needed to go eat lunch, and Roger probably knew he had to, but he would have stayed there the whole day, just talking to us. He stayed a lot more than he had to for sure. But then the people from ESPN tried kinda finishing things up so that he could leave before his manager freaked out. So he went around the table hugging my mom, my dad and my sister, and then it was my turn. He told me I had been through a lot and hugged me really hard and I just started crying so so so much in his shoulder (it was around that time that the picture from my avi was taken haha) He was like "awnn". Then when I let go of him I was still like sobbing and I turned to him and he was kinda tearing up :') I thanked him and then he went.

column3: What are the lesser known facts about Roger Federer?
column4:
The legend changes his racket exactly one game before the new balls are brought in, for all his matches. The reason is to get used to the racket for one game while the balls are still slow and fluffy and to get the strings lose their elasticity and tension.


Note: The balls are changed after 7 games for the first time (since they wear up during warm-up sessions) and then changed again after each additional 9 games.

column3: What do you think was the major problem with yesterday‚Äôs tennis match between Serena and Osaka?
column4:
Serena‚Äôs unwarranted outburst and everyone‚Äôs focus on her ‚Äòplight‚Äô while Naomi wept after winning the championship

Serena was given three penalties in the match :

Coaching (later admitted by her coach
) - Her coach‚Äôs claims that ‚Äúeveryone does it‚Äù doesn‚Äôt make it less of a violation. She received a warning for this.
Racquet Abuse - She received a point penalty for breaking her racquet and started next game at 15‚Äì0. What is most absurd is that she knew she‚Äôd lose a point if she breaks her racquet, yet claims that the umpire ‚Äòstole‚Äô the point from her!
Verbal Abuse - Serena called the umpire a ‚Äòliar‚Äô and a ‚Äòthief‚Äô for stealing her point. She received a game penalty for it, leaving Osaka one game away from victory.

Personally, I feel the verbal abuse was a slightly harsh call, because it was the penultimate game of a Grand Slam final. The umpire though, withdrew himself from external factors and went by the book, which cannot be argued with.

Serena taking the coaching as an ‚Äòattack on her integrity‚Äô is a personal problem. Players‚Äô personal problems were not accounted for when the rules of the game were decided. If she wants to play on court, she follows the rules.

Sport > Player

‚ÄúI have never cheated in my life‚Ä¶you are the liar‚Ä¶you stole a point from me‚Ä¶you are a thief too‚Äù

Clearly, she doesn‚Äôt believe that Tennis is bigger than her

This behaviour from Serena is not uncommon. She had a forgettable exit from the 2009 US Open
. She yelled at a lineswoman in the semifinal, which resulted in a point penalty on match point and thus, she lost the point and match

Her comment back then -

"An apology? From me? Well, how many people yell at lines people?"

No doubt she is a legend. Perhaps the greatest woman to hold a tennis racquet. But she does not have the right to assume she is greater than the game and abuse officials.

On the other hand, Naomi Osaka clearly outplayed Serena. Her shots were not dramatic, she only stuck to the basics and delivered a smooth performance

This frustrated Serena!

Less than two months after losing the Wimbledon final, it was a repeat for her. Even before the first warning, she was netting the ball quite frequently. The angst of not winning another Grand Slam after coming so close and getting penalties at the same time was enough for someone with her history of outbursts to revolt back!

And what did Naomi get after the win?

A lot of boo‚Äôs! Seriously? She just created history by being the first Japanese to win a Grand Slam!

Just after winning a frickin‚Äô Grand Slam

Look at her face. I‚Äôm sure she must have dreamed of this moment

Just for comparison, here is Serena after her first Grand Slam title - US Open ‚Äò99.

Everyone made sure it was not the night of Osaka‚Äôs win. But the night of Serena‚Äôs unfair defeat

Perhaps this is not the finish we were looking for today, but Serena, you are quite a champion of champions, and Naomi, welcome to the big stage.

- Katrina Adams, President of USTA

Honestly, that sounds more like a condolence rather than a congratulations to Naomi.

A lot of former players have tweeted that there should be a change in the rules and that the umpire was too harsh. Till then, Serena has to follow the rules if she plays at the Flushing Meadows. Period.

All in all, this match will definitely be remembered for years to come and not for the right reasons. Dozens of Grand Slam trophies do not offset unsportsmanlike conduct.

Personally, I will never be able to admire Serena as much as I admire Nadal, Federer or Wawrinka. It is just sheer pleasure to watch them, both on and off court

‚ÄúHonestly, I would have been happy to lose‚Ä¶.There are no draws in tennis. I would have been equally happy to share this (his trophy) with Rafa‚Äù

- Federer, after winning Australian Open 2017

Image Source : Google Images

Coaching (later admitted by her coach
) - Her coach‚Äôs claims that ‚Äúeveryone does it‚Äù doesn‚Äôt make it less of a violation. She received a warning for this.
Racquet Abuse - She received a point penalty for breaking her racquet and started next game at 15‚Äì0. What is most absurd is that she knew she‚Äôd lose a point if she breaks her racquet, yet claims that the umpire ‚Äòstole‚Äô the point from her!
Verbal Abuse - Serena called the umpire a ‚Äòliar‚Äô and a ‚Äòthief‚Äô for stealing her point. She received a game penalty for it, leaving Osaka one game away from victory.

Personally, I feel the verbal abuse was a slightly harsh call, because it was the penultimate game of a Grand Slam final. The umpire though, withdrew himself from external factors and went by the book, which cannot be argued with.

Serena taking the coaching as an ‚Äòattack on her integrity‚Äô is a personal problem. Players‚Äô personal problems were not accounted for when the rules of the game were decided. If she wants to play on court, she follows the rules.

Sport > Player

‚ÄúI have never cheated in my life‚Ä¶you are the liar‚Ä¶you stole a point from me‚Ä¶you are a thief too‚Äù

Clearly, she doesn‚Äôt believe that Tennis is bigger than her

This behaviour from Serena is not uncommon. She had a forgettable exit from the 2009 US Open
. She yelled at a lineswoman in the semifinal, which resulted in a point penalty on match point and thus, she lost the point and match

Her comment back then -

"An apology? From me? Well, how many people yell at lines people?"

No doubt she is a legend. Perhaps the greatest woman to hold a tennis racquet. But she does not have the right to assume she is greater than the game and abuse officials.

On the other hand, Naomi Osaka clearly outplayed Serena. Her shots were not dramatic, she only stuck to the basics and delivered a smooth performance

This frustrated Serena!

Less than two months after losing the Wimbledon final, it was a repeat for her. Even before the first warning, she was netting the ball quite frequently. The angst of not winning another Grand Slam after coming so close and getting penalties at the same time was enough for someone with her history of outbursts to revolt back!

And what did Naomi get after the win?

A lot of boo‚Äôs! Seriously? She just created history by being the first Japanese to win a Grand Slam!

Just after winning a frickin‚Äô Grand Slam

Look at her face. I‚Äôm sure she must have dreamed of this moment

Just for comparison, here is Serena after her first Grand Slam title - US Open ‚Äò99.

Everyone made sure it was not the night of Osaka‚Äôs win. But the night of Serena‚Äôs unfair defeat

Perhaps this is not the finish we were looking for today, but Serena, you are quite a champion of champions, and Naomi, welcome to the big stage.

- Katrina Adams, President of USTA

Honestly, that sounds more like a condolence rather than a congratulations to Naomi.

A lot of former players have tweeted that there should be a change in the rules and that the umpire was too harsh. Till then, Serena has to follow the rules if she plays at the Flushing Meadows. Period.

All in all, this match will definitely be remembered for years to come and not for the right reasons. Dozens of Grand Slam trophies do not offset unsportsmanlike conduct.

Personally, I will never be able to admire Serena as much as I admire Nadal, Federer or Wawrinka. It is just sheer pleasure to watch them, both on and off court

‚ÄúHonestly, I would have been happy to lose‚Ä¶.There are no draws in tennis. I would have been equally happy to share this (his trophy) with Rafa‚Äù

- Federer, after winning Australian Open 2017

Image Source : Google Images', 'aiModelVersion': '1'}

column3: What are some of the mind-blowing facts about Roger Federer?
column4:
Yves Allegro, well known as Federer's double partner and good friend, shared one of his childhood memories with the man in the book - The Roger Federer Story: Quest for Perfection by Rene Stauffer.

"We had to fill out a form stating our goals. Everybody wrote: To someday be among the Top 100 in the world, but Roger was the only one to write: To first be among the Top 10 in the world and then become Number 1. From that point on, we viewed him in a different light."( He aged 16 then)

The enchanting fact is that he was able to do that for more than 300 weeks!

column3: Since Rafa Nadal just breaks the Grand Slam record, is he now considered the GOAT in men's tennis?
column4:
No, but he at least made sure the debate stays competitive for years to come. Determining the GOAT of men‚Äôs tennis is very difficult. You want to account for longevity, rankings, titles, and rivalries to get an accurate picture of the greatest. And as it stands now, every Big 3 member has an incredible resume.

And the beauty of it is the diversity in resumes. Each has their separate favorite surfaces where each is widely regarded as the greatest ever, and each has various records that will not be broken for who knows how long. Most Grand Slams, most weeks at No.1, most tour finals, longest streak at No.1, most Wimbledons, most French Opens, most Australian Opens‚Ä¶ the list goes on and on. These three brought us the golden age of tennis. We‚Äôre coming to the end of that era, and it‚Äôs possible that Djokovic or Nadal somehow has the gas to win enough Grand Slams to take a decisive lead, but it‚Äôs unlikely.

At best, Djokovic will equal or top Nadal‚Äôs Grand Slam record by 1, and a majority of anlysts will pick him as the GOAT with a sizable minority sticking to Federer or Nadal. Their talents are just too diverse to ever truly pick an undisputed GOAT. What a privilege to have lived in their era, though.

column3: What is Roger Federer like in real life?
column4: In similar vein - at a restaurant where a friend was a waitress, Roger and a large group of his friends had reserved a few tables. It was really busy and the staff was caught up in everything and weren't prepared. The tables weren't set up. No complaints, no grumbling. Roger just went ahead and helped the staff out with carrying and setting up more tables. Every story I've ever heard about the man reiterates that kind spirit of his.

column3: What are the most unusual / little know facts about tennis and tennis players?
column4:
Unusual Rules & Traditions:

Challenge System: Before 1978, players could challenge umpires' calls, and linesmen had to confirm the challenge if the ball bounced within an inch of the line. This led to arguments and delays!
Wimbledon Whites: The all-white dress code at Wimbledon dates back to the late 19th century when players wore formal attire. Today, it's strictly enforced, with even Serena Williams famously being told to change her socks in 2010.
The Royal Box Debacle: During the 1909 Wimbledon final, a dog ran onto the court, causing a stir. King Edward VII famously quipped, "Take the brute off!" not realizing it was the Queen's dog!

Peculiar Player Quirks & Habits:

Andre Agassi's Hair Extensions: In the 90s, Agassi famously rocked a hairpiece to cover his baldness, later admitting it was to gain sponsorship deals.
Monica Seles' Shoelace Ritual: Before every match, Seles would meticulously tie her shoelaces in a specific order for good luck.
Rafael Nadal's Water Bottle Placement: Nadal has a specific way of arranging his water bottles and towels during breaks, known as his "ritual."

Surprising Statistics & Records:

Worst Grand Slam Record: Jelena Dokic holds the record for the most Grand Slam appearances without ever winning a match, participating in 43 tournaments without a victory.
Self-Destruction: In 1989, Jimmy Connors famously lost a match after intentionally hitting the ball over the fence three times, receiving three penalties and a point deduction.
Double Fault Domination: In 2015, Dustin Brown served a staggering 43 double faults during a single match, still winning against Nicolas Mahut!

Intriguing Off-Court Stories:

King James I's Demise: The Scottish king reportedly died from septicemia after playing tennis in freezing weather, catching a chill that proved fatal.
From Tennis Champion to Pope: Pope Pius X was an avid tennis player in his youth, even winning a regional championship in Italy.
Tennis Racket Rocket: In 1931, Ren√© Lacoste, founder of Lacoste apparel, invented a tennis racket launcher to shoot balls at high speeds for practice.

column3: What are some traditions at Wimbledon?
column4:
The Mystery-Man who always occupies Seat No 7

For the past decade and a half, this man occupies the seat number 7 in the player's box at the center court. In his signature goatee and a cowboy hat, the cameras pan on to him quite often. Year, after year.

Who is he?

He is 79 year old, David Spearing. He has been a steward, at the Wimbledon, since 1974 and now acts as a host to the player's entourage at the center court, which he has been doing for the past decade and a half.





PS: During the QF match featuring Serena, Alan Wilkins (yes, the cricketer who also does tennis commentary) asked Vijay Amritraj about him and also indicated that he cannot recall his name.

Simply Tennis. No Advertisements.

Pic: Wimbledon, with no sponsor background.

Unlike other tournaments, where most of the real estate including the net is taken up by sponsor logos - Wimbledon has absolutely nothing.

Pic: That Gael Monfils dive in the top right is a great advertisement for Longines. Wouldn't you agree?

White, white and always white

Unlike other tournaments, where the officials do not really bother much about player outfits, Wimbledon is a place where officials call the shots and the players have to follow suit.

Andre Agassi, who created a niche for himself with long hair and "weird' colored clothing tried to rebel against Wimbledon and during the earlier years of his career, he boycotted the tournament.

Pic: Yes, that is Agassi, and yes those are denim shorts !

But eventually he had to relent.

After all, this was Wimbledon.

And none other than Roger Federer, even after winning the event multiple times made the mistake of making the officials unhappy, all because his shoes weren't up to the mark. And Federer - had to listen.

After all, this was Wimbledon.

Pic: No, Roger - No, Orange in shoes please.


Royalty on the court

Wimbledon is the only grand slam which is attended by the royalty and the English Royal family has a strong connection with the club.

Pic: Queen Elizabeth II interacting with the players during Wimbledon 2010

The players also have to bow to the royalty, if they are present in the court. Since 2003, however, the bowing tradition is done only if the queen or the prince are present in the royal box.

Pic: Federer bowing to Prince Charles during Wimbledon'12.

During the post-match interview, Federer remarked:

They do brief you. So I guess you don‚Äôt do anything stupid. You behave!!




First match on Center Court goes to defending champions

The matches on the Center Court are kicked off by the defending champion of the Gentleman's Singles. In 2015, this would be Novak Djokovic.

This is a privilege which the defending champion gets as he gets to play on fresh and unused grass surface for his opening match. As the tournament progresses, the grass dries off, specially near the service lines.


No Tennis Please - this is Wimbledon

Grand slams carry on for a period of two weeks, starting from a Monday and ending with the finals on the following second Sunday. Generally, in the first week, most of the lower ranked players get eliminated. And beginning the middle Sunday, excitement starts building up as people start looking forward to more competitive matches and 'Sunday', being a holiday, they finally have some more time for Tennis.

But what happens at Wimbledon?



"Blimey! Have you gone bollocks? What are you doing here on the middle Sunday. We don't play Tennis here. Don't ya all know that? This is Wimbledon. Go home and have some English tea. Off you go now. See ya tomorrow."



Ok. May be that wasn't a great imitation with the British accent. But, nevertheless, yes, there is actually no tennis at Wimbledon during the middle Sunday. A lot of players, including John McEnroe and Novak Djokovic have protested against this. The English weather often interrupts the tournament and at times causes havoc in the schedule.

But hey, this is a tradition. How can this be changed?

Strawberries & Cream

During the Victorian England times, Strawberries were a fashionable thing to eat. And they were in season when Wimbledon used to take place. Many fans started considering Wimbledon as 'Tennis in an English garden", and strawberries and cream just had to be there.

Pic: They do look delicious. Don't they.

How Rafael Nadal is related to Spanish Football and why is there a Pineapple placed on the Wimbledon Trophy?

No Tennis Please - this is Wimbledon

Grand slams carry on for a period of two weeks, starting from a Monday and ending with the finals on the following second Sunday. Generally, in the first week, most of the lower ranked players get eliminated. And beginning the middle Sunday, excitement starts building up as people start looking forward to more competitive matches and 'Sunday', being a holiday, they finally have some more time for Tennis.

But what happens at Wimbledon?



"Blimey! Have you gone bollocks? What are you doing here on the middle Sunday. We don't play Tennis here. Don't ya all know that? This is Wimbledon. Go home and have some English tea. Off you go now. See ya tomorrow."



Ok. May be that wasn't a great imitation with the British accent. But, nevertheless, yes, there is actually no tennis at Wimbledon during the middle Sunday. A lot of players, including John McEnroe and Novak Djokovic have protested against this. The English weather often interrupts the tournament and at times causes havoc in the schedule.

But hey, this is a tradition. How can this be changed?

Strawberries & Cream

During the Victorian England times, Strawberries were a fashionable thing to eat. And they were in season when Wimbledon used to take place. Many fans started considering Wimbledon as 'Tennis in an English garden", and strawberries and cream just had to be there.

Pic: They do look delicious. Don't they.

How Rafael Nadal is related to Spanish Football and why is there a Pineapple placed on the Wimbledon Trophy?', 'aiModelVersion': '1'}

column3: What is Roger Federer like in real life?
column4:
The following article is an essay about Federer, written by Rick Reilly (in 2007), who is a featured columnist for ESPN Sports. This should give a fair idea as to what the man is in real life.

Roger Federer is decent, humble and kinder than Aunt Bee. He is constantly saying, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just a normal guy.‚Äù All his winning shots were just ‚Äúlucky.‚Äù Well, finally, opponents are starting to take his word for it.

Do you realize this man, whom most experts say is the greatest tennis player to ever live, actually goes to restaurants and sometimes waits in line?

He doesn‚Äôt have a full-time coach. Has no tattoos. His entourage is a joke. His publicity agent, his scheduler, his hitting partner and his girlfriend are all the same person. And she‚Äôs not even a lingerie model! Just an ordinary, very nice Swiss miss named Mirka. Derek Jeter has more babes than belts!

Federer flies commercial. Doesn‚Äôt own a jet. Here‚Äôs a guy who has dominated his sport far more than Tiger Woods has over the last three years, yet Tiger has a 155-foot yacht and Federer doesn‚Äôt even own a dinghy.

Federer made an estimated $28 million last year, yet he doesn‚Äôt own a house, just two ‚Äúflats,‚Äù he says. He won four ATP honors in one day last week‚ÄìPlayer of the Year, Humanitarian of the Year, Fans‚Äô Favorite and the Sportsmanship Award for 2006‚Äìyet he has no trophy room. The hardware just piles up on his dining room table.

At 25 Federer has won 10 Grand Slam events yet still stays in the same hotel as the tour schmoes. Roger, you‚Äôre an immortal! Rent a mansion! Do you realize that when Tiger played at a tournament in Tucson in February he not only rented a house, but he also had all the furniture removed and his own brought in, so he could be more comfortable? Wake up and smell the indulgence!
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to overlive,‚Äù Federer says. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need to be too big. It‚Äôs got to feel right when you go to bed at night.‚Äù

Arrrggh!
Get this: You can send an autograph request to his parents‚Äô house‚Äìtheir address is on his website‚Äìand within a month you‚Äôll get a photo hand-signed by Roger. ‚ÄúWell, if I were a child,‚Äù he says, ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt want to wait two years for a picture of my hero, would you?‚Äù Damn, son, at least get one of those signing machines like everybody else!

Tell you what a sucker Federer is, when he‚Äôs done practicing, he picks up his own bench area. ‚ÄúNot many guys on tour do that,‚Äù says Federer‚Äôs best friend, Yves Allegro. ‚ÄúIn fact, most don‚Äôt do that.‚Äù That‚Äôs the other thing‚Äìthis guy Allegro. Federer plays doubles with him a few times a year just to put some folding money in his friend‚Äôs pocket. Nowadays your average tennis superstar would rather join the Elks club than play doubles. But not Federer. Even if the doubles comes right after his singles match, he plays. It would be like Tiger playing the Sheboygan Ladies Par 3 Annual after winning the Masters. ‚ÄúHow can I pay him back?‚Äù Allegro says. ‚ÄúHe won‚Äôt even let me buy him dinner!‚Äù

You have to be who you are, Rog, and you are a heavenly body. Start acting like it! ‚ÄúI tell him all the time,‚Äù says his agent, IMG‚Äôs Tony Godsick, ‚Äúyou‚Äôre too nice.‚Äù

Too Nice Example No. 1: Federer sometimes throws pizza parties for the ball boys at tournaments because he was one himself. And he attends!

Too Nice No. 2: The other day he was in L.A. and called Pete Sampras out of the blue to see if he wanted to hit. No, no, no, Roger! He calls you! And you put him off for a week before you call him back!

Too Nice No. 3: I sent an e-mail to Godsick on Monday morning at eight, asking for a one-on-one interview. By four, I was sitting across from Federer. Eight hours? Barry Bonds will put a reporter off for eight years! There were two chairs in the interview room. A large, cushy one with armrests and a plain straight-backed one. He looked at me sheepishly and said, ‚ÄúWould you mind very much if I took the larger chair? I am very tired from my match.‚Äù

Hello? Roger? Monster sports Goliaths don‚Äôt ask. Monster sports Goliaths plop down in the big one, then put their feet up on the smaller one.
Then they examine their fingernails, sniff once and go, ‚ÄúMake it quick. My exfoliator is waiting.‚Äù

You‚Äôre a tennis star, Roger. Go out there and get some faults!

column3: Who is Roger Federer?
column4:
If someone asks you who's the best player to grace Tennis, you know it's Roger Federer.

‚Äã

If you see someone hit incessant majestic shots, you know it's Roger Federer.

‚Äã

If you see the home crowd chanting an opponent's name in middle of a game, you know it's Roger Federer.

‚Äã

If you see someone defy age, you know it's Roger Federer.

‚Äã

If you see a tennis player adored by everyone, you know it's Roger Federer.

‚Äã

If you love this beautiful game because of someone, you know it's Roger Federer.

‚Äã

And if you want to know what Tennis will miss in coming years, you know it's Roger Federer.

‚Äã



Thank you Maestro, for giving us so many memories to cherish.

EDIT - Thank you for your overwhelming response, really appreciate it.

column3: Who would have won between Federer and Djokovic at the French Open if they both played during their prime?
column4:
In 2011, Djokovic had the greatest season of his career, way better than what he did in 2015 and after. There is no comparison between the level of competition in 2011 and 2015 or any year after.

In 2011, Nadal was 25 and in his prime as the #1 player in the world. Federer was 29, turning 30 that August, and still formidable. That year Djokovic went 70‚Äì6, with 10 titles and 3 grand Slams.

If you include the 2010 Davis Cup Finals, Djokovic went on a 66‚Äì2 run (97.0%), including 43 straight wins, with 3 Slams and 10 titles out of 12 tournaments played.

Injuries and fatigue slowed him down at the tail end of the season, resulting in four losses. Otherwise, it would have been the greatest season by any of the Big 3.

Lon Shapiro
 ¬∑ 5y
Who was the best in their tip prime, Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal, or Novak Djokovic?
This question has been raised many times before, with slightly different wording. You chose the phrase ‚Äútip prime,‚Äù which needs to be defined. Most tennis players and sports writers define ‚Äúprime‚Äù as being that period in an athlete‚Äôs career where they reached the top of their game (as evidenced by winning a Slam or achieving their highest ranking) and continuing until their age starts to limit them physically. Since we are focusing on these three all-time greats, we should compare them to what other all-time greats do at the start of their careers. Most multiple Slam winners win their first title before they turn 23 (List of Grand Slam singles champions in Open Era with age of first title - Wikipedia.) Federer won his first slam just before he turned 22. Djokovic won his first slam four months before he turned 21. Nadal won his first Slam as he turned 19. I believe that once a player wins a slam we have to consider that the beginning of their prime. (On the other hand, some players - Wawrinka, for example - underachieve for years before they finally combine the right attitude, training and coach to break through mentally and play their best tennis. They may have passed their physical peak, but the breakthrough is where you have to measure their prime.) I would also argue that a player‚Äôs prime ends at 28 years of age. The proof is that only a handful of the greatest players of the Open Era have won more than one slam after the age of 28. The exceptions are Laver, Rosewall, Newcombe, Connors, Sampras, Agassi, Wawrinka, Federer and Nadal. Djokovic turned 29 as the 2016 French Open began and won that event. He hasn‚Äôt won another title since then. If you want to know who is the greatest player of the three in their ‚Äúprimes,‚Äù the answer is clear. I did a deep dive into this subject by looking at each of the players‚Äô head-to-head records during their prime. The margins are very, very close, but the order still comes out the same as their grand slam records: 1) Federer; 2) Nadal; and 3) Djokovic: Lon Shapiro's answer to At their peaks, how would you rank Nadal, Djokovic and Federer? For those people who argue for Djokovic, the biggest problem is he only dominates Federer and Nadal during his magical 2011 season, staying #1 for 53 weeks starting in July 2011. He was passed by Federer in 2012, regains #1 for 48 weeks in November 2012 and gets passed again by Nadal in October 2013. That‚Äôs only a total of 101 weeks at #1 while Federer and Nadal are in their primes. (Djokovic‚Äôs longest streak at #1 (122 weeks) comes between July 2014 and November 2016, at precisely the worst periods of Nadal‚Äôs and Federer‚Äôs play.) Nadal is ranked #1 on three separate occasions (2008, 2010, 2013) for a total of 141 weeks. That puts him clearly above Djokovic. Federer was ranked #1 (with Nadal #2), between July 2005 and August 2008, again in 2009, and again in 2012, approximately 221 weeks. For those who want to use the ‚Äúweaker era‚Äù argument, Nadal from age 19 to 22 was a far greater opponent than the older, weakened versions of Nadal and Federer from 2014‚Äì2016. His record is still clearly better than Djokovic. So what is a ‚Äútip prime?‚Äù My guess is you are describing what most people call a player‚Äôs ‚Äúpeak.‚Äù The difficulty with the word peak is to know where to draw the lines that define it. Is it one match? Is it one tournament? Is it a season? An entire year? Or some arbitrary number of months or year? The next problem is to compare one player‚Äôs peak to another. Djokovic might have had an amazing 2015 season, but Nadal (20 losses, no Slams past the quarters) and Federer (11 losses, including Seppi, Kyrgios, Wawrinkia, Ramos-Vinolas) were not playing anywhere near their old level. A lot of people have written about which player had the greatest single season, and most of them focus on Federer 2005, Federer 2006, Djokovic 2011, Connors 1974, McEnroe 1984, and Laver 1969 in the Open Era. Because you asked for the ‚Äútip prime,‚Äù I would like to analyze the best portion of each player‚Äôs best seasons. Here are the greatest seasons for these players: Federer (2005), Federer (2006), Nadal (2008), Nadal (2010), Djokovic (2011), Nadal (2013), and Djokovic (2015). There are amazing things to be pulled from parts of each of these seasons. Here are the all-time peaks for each player. I‚Äôll list them in reverse order: Honorable Mention, Nadal 2010: Nadal was 71‚Äì10, won 3 Grand Slams and 7 titles overall. However, this is the biggest what-if season. Nadal was recovering from the injuries that ended his 2009 season. He came back to the circuit, losing in the finals of Qatar, before defaulting in the Australian Open quarter-finals. Was he unwise to come back so quickly, or did he get hurt during the tournament? What makes this season special is Nadal might have won the calendar Slam, as he went on to with the next three Grand Slams. Nadals‚Äôs tip prime: starting with Monte Carlo, Nadal went was 42‚Äì3 (93.3%), with 3 consecutive Slams and 6 titles out of 9 tournaments. #6 Djokovic 2015‚Äì2016: Djokovic was 82‚Äì6, won 11 tournaments, with 3 Grand Slams and the ATP Finals. While others regard this one of the all-time great seasons, it happened against a greatly diminished Nadal and a 34-year-old Federer who beat him three times that year. He had a bad loss that year against Karlovic in Qatar. But the worst thing was blowing his chance to win a calendar Slam by losing to Stan Wawrinka in the finals of Roland Garros. In 2016 (again with Nadal and Federer no longer a factor), he won the Australian and the French to hold all four titles at the same time. But bad losses kept popping up every third week, so he never had a real run of invincibility. And after winning the French, he only won one more tournament the rest of the year, while Murray took over the #1 ranking. Djokovic‚Äôs tip prime: From the 2015 Australian Open to the 2016 French Open, Djokovic won all four Slams, compiling a record of 118‚Äì8 (93.6%), and winning 12 of 16 tournaments. #5 Nadal 2013: Nadal was 75‚Äì7, won 10 tournaments and 2 Grand Slams. It doesn‚Äôt boast the same gaudy numbers as Federer and Djokovic‚Äôs best seasons, but there are a number of reasons I ranked it fourth overall: 1.¬†For the second time in his career, he came back from an injury that sidelined him since Wimbledon 2012 and regained the #1 ranking 2.¬†After being dominated by the younger Djokovic, he reversed their psychological dynamic beating the #1 player at the French, the Rogers Cup and at the US Open. Nadal‚Äôs tip prime: starting at the Brazil Open, Nadal played himself back into shape, winning two of three Slams, compiling a record of 56‚Äì2 (96.5%) and winning 10 out of 12 tournaments. #4 Nadal 2008: Nadal was 82-11, won 8 tournaments, 2 Grand Slams and the Olympic Gold Medal. While the overall season isn‚Äôt regarded as highly as some of the others, there‚Äôs a fantastic streak in the middle marked by the following special achievements: 1.¬†In spite of a freak loss to Juan Carlos Ferrero in Rome, Nadal won the last two clay court tournaments and finished it with one of the most dominating performances in the history of finals at Roland Garros, beating Federer 6‚Äì1, 6‚Äì3, 6‚Äì0. 2.¬†Nadal made a rare seamless transition to grass, winning the Artois Championships, followed by his legendary 9‚Äì7 in the fifth win over Federer at Wimbledon 3.¬†Nadal was still getting beaten by a lot of different players on hard courts that year, but put together a terrific run where he won the Canadian Open and then the Bejing Olympics. Nadal‚Äôs tip prime: starting with a Davis Cup match in April, Nadal won two consecutive Slams, plus a Gold Medal on three different surfaces, compiling a record of 52‚Äì2 (96.2%) and winning 8 out of 10 tournaments. Because Nadal won three ‚Äúmajors‚Äù (most people consider the Olympics almost as important as the Slams), on three different surfaces, I gave it the slightest edge over 2013. #3 Federer 2005‚Äì2006: Federer won 11 titles, and 2 Grand Slams. His 81‚Äì4 record makes this season as close as a tennis player will ever come to perfection because: 1.¬†Federer held at least one match point in three of his losses (Safin 9-7 in the fifth, Gasquet 7‚Äì6 in the third, and Nalbandian 7‚Äì6 in the fifth). That‚Äôs three points away from being 84‚Äì1, with 13 titles and the chance to win 3 Grand Slams and the Masters finals. (The only match where he didn‚Äôt have a chance to win was a four-set loss to Nadal at the French Open.) 2.¬†In the fall, Federer was injured in a training session, suffering torn ligaments in his ankle. After pulling out from Madrid, Basel and Paris and being confined to a cast and crutches for several weeks, Federer agreed to go to Shanghai for the Masters Finals after five top players pulled out due to injury or family matters. He was unsure if he would be able to play even two days from the start of the tournament, and somehow hobbled through the tournament before losing to Nalbandian in the finals. 3.¬†The loss ended his 35-match winning streak, and broke his record of 24 consecutive finals won. 2005 Roger Federer tennis season - Wikipedia 4.¬†In 2006, he won the Australian Open and another 15 straight matches. Federer‚Äôs tip prime: from the French Open semi-finals until his loss in the 2006 finals at Dubai, Federer won three consecutive Slams, compiling a record of 50‚Äì1 (98.0%), and winning 7 titles out of 8 tournaments. Or, you could count until his loss in Monte Carlos for a 68‚Äì2 (97.1%), winning 9 of 11 tournaments. Either way, it‚Äôs razor close to being the all-time best run of invincibility, but I still think it‚Äôs only number three. #2 Djokovic 2011: people overlook this season, focusing on 2015. But there is no comparison between the level of competition in 2011 and 2015. In 2011, Nadal is 25 and in his prime as the #1 player in the world. Federer is 29, turning 30 that August, and still formidable. Djokovic was 70‚Äì6, with 10 titles and 3 grand Slams. Injuries may have slowed him down, losing 4 matches to end the year, but here‚Äôs why it is by far his all-time best season: 1.¬†Djokovic was 7‚Äì16 head to head against Nadal, including 0‚Äì8 on clay. Djokovic was playing so great, he beat the Spaniard twice on the dirt, and went 6‚Äì0 overall against Nadal that year. 2.¬†In December 2010, Djokovic led Serbia to its first Davis Cup title, giving him a burst of confidence that would carry him to his greatest heights. 3.¬†Adding his 2 Davis Cup singles wins, Djokovic ran off 43 straight wins to start the 2011 season, for the fifth longest win streak in history. 4.¬†Federer bested Djokovic in four tough sets at the French Open semi-finals, which ended his streak, but he came back and won 15 straight matches, including Wimbledon, before retiring against Murray in the finals at Cincinnati. 5.¬†Djokovic recovered again to win the U.S. Open, hitting the riskiest (luckiest?) serve return winner I‚Äôve ever seen when down match point in the semis against Federer. Djokovic‚Äôs tip prime: Including Davis Cup, Djokovic went on a 66‚Äì2 run (97.0%), including 43 straight wins, with 3 Slams and 10 titles out of 12 tournaments played. Or, if you want to cut off his record before the second loss, Djokovic went on a 58‚Äì1 run (98.27%), with 2 Slams and 9 titles out of 11 tournaments. #1: Federer 2006‚Äì2007: Federer won 12 titles, 3 Grand Slams and the ATP Finals. His 92‚Äì5 record is .005 lower than 2005, but is even more incredible, as only two players in the world won matches against him, a 20-year-old Nadal, already the greatest clay court player in history, and a rising Andy Murray, about to enter the top 15. The season is notable for the following reasons: 1.¬†Out of 17 tournaments, he only lost one match that wasn‚Äôt in the finals. 2.¬†Out of his 5 losses, four would come against Nadal, of which 3 were on clay. (He beat Nadal once on grass and once indoors that year). 3.¬†Federer held match point against Nadal in the finals of Rome, but lost 7‚Äì6 in the fifth set. 4.¬†This might have been Federer‚Äôs best chance to win the calendar Slam, reaching a fourth set tie breaker in the final against Nadal. Federer‚Äôs tip prime: Federer started the season 32‚Äì1, winning the Australian and three other titles. After losing three clay court finals to Nadal including the French, Federer won 3 consecutive Slams, compiling a 59‚Äì1 record (98.33%), including 41 straight wins, and won 10 titles out of 11 tournaments played. Notes: the difference between Federer and Djokovic‚Äôs best runs really comes down to microscopic differences: 1) Djokovic lost to Federer at Roland Garros, instead of getting the chance to test Nadal; and 2) Federer was up two sets to love and match point at the US Open; and 3) Federer won three consecutive Slams while losing only one match over a period of seven months, while Djokovic won three non-consecutive Slams while losing two matches over a nine month period.

But the thing that makes this season so special is because he went 6‚Äì0 against Nadal and 4‚Äì1 Federer that year. No one has ever dominated against that level of competition.

There is only one problem.

He lost to Federer in the semifinals at the French Open that year. At his absolute peak. Against a guy 5 1/2 years older.

People just don‚Äôt remember how good Federer was.

In his prime, Federer was the second best player in the world on clay. Federer lost to Nadal in the semis and then three consecutive French Open finals between 2005 and 2008.

From 2005 up until the fourth round of the 2009 French Open, Nadal won 81 straight matches on clay and went 139‚Äì3. Only two players in the world beat him. One was Juan Carlos Ferrero and the other was Roger Federer, who did it twice. During that time, Djokovic was 0‚Äì10 against Nadal.

Even after he ‚Äúretired‚Äù from clay for two years in 2017 and 2018 to preserve his energy for Wimbledon, Federer could still play on the dirt. In 2019, he decided to play the French Open and reached the semis, losing to Nadal.

So not only do we have evidence of how good Federer was by using Nadal at his most invincible at a measuring stick, we have direct evidence.

[Update] Over the last six years, Djokovic has had a remarkable run of success, winning 12 majors after the age of 30, including 2 French Open titles. His performance has been an incredible feat of endurance, training and recovery discipline and a dedication to improving his game to make up for deteriorating physical skills.

Once again, we have to use Nadal as the standard for comparison. After the 2014 French Open, Nadal‚Äôs physical level fell off due to all his injuries and his grueling style of play. The following two years saw his ranking drop as low as #10 and he didn‚Äôt win a major again until the 2017 French Open. During that time, he added a new coach and had to change his style to play shorter points to preserve his body. As a result, he is a combined 0‚Äì13 against Djokovic and Federer on grass and hard courts since 2015.

Taking into account these physical limitations, there is no way to claim that Nadal‚Äôs level of play on clay from 2017‚Äì2022 was as good as it was from 2005‚Äì2013. And yet, he still beat the brakes off Djokovic.

In the 2020 French Open final, a rested Nadal gave Djokovic the worst loss of his career: 6‚Äì0, 6‚Äì2, 7‚Äì5. In 2021, Nadal was hampered by a foot injury at the end of a loss to Djokovic at Roland Garros. Nadal tried to come back to the tour after resting 3 months, played two matches and then sat out the rest of the year.

The only way to judge the performance of an all-time great player is by the level of his competition.

That‚Äôs why Djokovic‚Äôs greatest clay court match was losing to Nadal 9‚Äì7 in the fifth in the 2013 Roland Garros semifinals. Nadal was basically still invincible on the red clay back then.

Federer‚Äôs highest level of clay court play was in the period of 2006‚Äì2008, when Nadal was at the height of his clay court powers, winning 81 matches in a row.

Federer served for the match against Nadal in the fifth set in the 2006 finals at Rome, and played a competitive 4-set match a couple of weeks later at Roland Garros. Just watch the highlights to see the level of speed with which these guys covered the court back then.

In 2007, Federer beat Nadal in the finals of Hamburg, breaking Nadal‚Äôs 81-match winning streak.

Could 2013 Djokovic have beaten 2006‚Äì2007 Federer on clay? There‚Äôs no way to know.

All we have is that one match in 2011 when Federer beat Djokovic at the absolute height of his career. Later that year, Federer had two match points against Djokovic at the U.S. Open, so I don‚Äôt think Federer‚Äôs play at the French was an aberration.

Who was the best in their tip prime, Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal, or Novak Djokovic?
This question has been raised many times before, with slightly different wording. You chose the phrase ‚Äútip prime,‚Äù which needs to be defined. Most tennis players and sports writers define ‚Äúprime‚Äù as being that period in an athlete‚Äôs career where they reached the top of their game (as evidenced by winning a Slam or achieving their highest ranking) and continuing until their age starts to limit them physically. Since we are focusing on these three all-time greats, we should compare them to what other all-time greats do at the start of their careers. Most multiple Slam winners win their first title before they turn 23 (List of Grand Slam singles champions in Open Era with age of first title - Wikipedia.) Federer won his first slam just before he turned 22. Djokovic won his first slam four months before he turned 21. Nadal won his first Slam as he turned 19. I believe that once a player wins a slam we have to consider that the beginning of their prime. (On the other hand, some players - Wawrinka, for example - underachieve for years before they finally combine the right attitude, training and coach to break through mentally and play their best tennis. They may have passed their physical peak, but the breakthrough is where you have to measure their prime.) I would also argue that a player‚Äôs prime ends at 28 years of age. The proof is that only a handful of the greatest players of the Open Era have won more than one slam after the age of 28. The exceptions are Laver, Rosewall, Newcombe, Connors, Sampras, Agassi, Wawrinka, Federer and Nadal. Djokovic turned 29 as the 2016 French Open began and won that event. He hasn‚Äôt won another title since then. If you want to know who is the greatest player of the three in their ‚Äúprimes,‚Äù the answer is clear. The proof is that only a handful of the greatest players of the Open Era have won more than one slam after the age of 28. The exceptions are Laver, Rosewall, Newcombe, Connors, Sampras, Agassi, Wawrinka, Federer and Nadal. Djokovic turned 29 as the 2016 French Open began and won that event. He hasn‚Äôt won another title since then. If you want to know who is the greatest player of the three in their ‚Äúprimes,‚Äù the answer is clear. I did a deep dive into this subject by looking at each of the players‚Äô head-to-head records during their prime. The margins are very, very close, but the order still comes out the same as their grand slam records: 1) Federer; 2) Nadal; and 3) Djokovic: Lon Shapiro's answer to At their peaks, how would you rank Nadal, Djokovic and Federer? For those people who argue for Djokovic, the biggest problem is he only dominates Federer and Nadal during his magical 2011 season, staying #1 for 53 weeks starting in July 2011. He was passed by Federer in 2012, regains #1 for 48 weeks in November 2012 and gets passed again by Nadal in October 2013. That‚Äôs only a total of 101 weeks at #1 while Federer and Nadal are in their primes. (Djokovic‚Äôs longest streak at #1 (122 weeks) comes between July 2014 and November 2016, at precisely the worst periods of Nadal‚Äôs and Federer‚Äôs play.) Nadal is ranked #1 on three separate occasions (2008, 2010, 2013) for a total of 141 weeks. That puts him clearly above Djokovic. Federer was ranked #1 (with Nadal #2), between July 2005 and August 2008, again in 2009, and again in 2012, approximately 221 weeks. For those who want to use the ‚Äúweaker era‚Äù argument, Nadal from age 19 to 22 was a far greater opponent than the older, weakened versions of Nadal and Federer from 2014‚Äì2016. His record is still clearly better than Djokovic. So what is a ‚Äútip prime?‚Äù My guess is you are describing what most people call a player‚Äôs ‚Äúpeak.‚Äù The difficulty with the word peak is to know where to draw the lines that define it. Is it one match? Is it one tournament? Is it a season? An entire year? Or some arbitrary number of months or year? The next problem is to compare one player‚Äôs peak to another. Djokovic might have had an amazing 2015 season, but Nadal (20 losses, no Slams past the quarters) and Federer (11 losses, including Seppi, Kyrgios, Wawrinkia, Ramos-Vinolas) were not playing anywhere near their old level. A lot of people have written about which player had the greatest single season, and most of them focus on Federer 2005, Federer 2006, Djokovic 2011, Connors 1974, McEnroe 1984, and Laver 1969 in the Open Era. Because you asked for the ‚Äútip prime,‚Äù I would like to analyze the best portion of each player‚Äôs best seasons. Here are the greatest seasons for these players: Federer (2005), Federer (2006), Nadal (2008), Nadal (2010), Djokovic (2011), Nadal (2013), and Djokovic (2015). There are amazing things to be pulled from parts of each of these seasons. Here are the all-time peaks for each player. I‚Äôll list them in reverse order: Honorable Mention, Nadal 2010: Nadal was 71‚Äì10, won 3 Grand Slams and 7 titles overall. However, this is the biggest what-if season. Nadal was recovering from the injuries that ended his 2009 season. He came back to the circuit, losing in the finals of Qatar, before defaulting in the Australian Open quarter-finals. Was he unwise to come back so quickly, or did he get hurt during the tournament? What makes this season special is Nadal might have won the calendar Slam, as he went on to with the next three Grand Slams. Nadals‚Äôs tip prime: starting with Monte Carlo, Nadal went was 42‚Äì3 (93.3%), with 3 consecutive Slams and 6 titles out of 9 tournaments. #6 Djokovic 2015‚Äì2016: Djokovic was 82‚Äì6, won 11 tournaments, with 3 Grand Slams and the ATP Finals. While others regard this one of the all-time great seasons, it happened against a greatly diminished Nadal and a 34-year-old Federer who beat him three times that year. He had a bad loss that year against Karlovic in Qatar. But the worst thing was blowing his chance to win a calendar Slam by losing to Stan Wawrinka in the finals of Roland Garros. In 2016 (again with Nadal and Federer no longer a factor), he won the Australian and the French to hold all four titles at the same time. But bad losses kept popping up every third week, so he never had a real run of invincibility. And after winning the French, he only won one more tournament the rest of the year, while Murray took over the #1 ranking. Djokovic‚Äôs tip prime: From the 2015 Australian Open to the 2016 French Open, Djokovic won all four Slams, compiling a record of 118‚Äì8 (93.6%), and winning 12 of 16 tournaments. #5 Nadal 2013: Nadal was 75‚Äì7, won 10 tournaments and 2 Grand Slams. It doesn‚Äôt boast the same gaudy numbers as Federer and Djokovic‚Äôs best seasons, but there are a number of reasons I ranked it fourth overall: 1.\xa0For the second time in his career, he came back from an injury that sidelined him since Wimbledon 2012 and regained the #1 ranking 2.\xa0After being dominated by the younger Djokovic, he reversed their psychological dynamic beating the #1 player at the French, the Rogers Cup and at the US Open. Nadal‚Äôs tip prime: starting at the Brazil Open, Nadal played himself back into shape, winning two of three Slams, compiling a record of 56‚Äì2 (96.5%) and winning 10 out of 12 tournaments. #4 Nadal 2008: Nadal was 82-11, won 8 tournaments, 2 Grand Slams and the Olympic Gold Medal. While the overall season isn‚Äôt regarded as highly as some of the others, there‚Äôs a fantastic streak in the middle marked by the following special achievements: 1.\xa0In spite of a freak loss to Juan Carlos Ferrero in Rome, Nadal won the last two clay court tournaments and finished it with one of the most dominating performances in the history of finals at Roland Garros, beating Federer 6‚Äì1, 6‚Äì3, 6‚Äì0. 2.\xa0Nadal made a rare seamless transition to grass, winning the Artois Championships, followed by his legendary 9‚Äì7 in the fifth win over Federer at Wimbledon 3.\xa0Nadal was still getting beaten by a lot of different players on hard courts that year, but put together a terrific run where he won the Canadian Open and then the Bejing Olympics. Nadal‚Äôs tip prime: starting with a Davis Cup match in April, Nadal won two consecutive Slams, plus a Gold Medal on three different surfaces, compiling a record of 52‚Äì2 (96.2%) and winning 8 out of 10 tournaments. Because Nadal won three ‚Äúmajors‚Äù (most people consider the Olympics almost as important as the Slams), on three different surfaces, I gave it the slightest edge over 2013. #3 Federer 2005‚Äì2006: Federer won 11 titles, and 2 Grand Slams. His 81‚Äì4 record makes this season as close as a tennis player will ever come to perfection because: 1.\xa0Federer held at least one match point in three of his losses (Safin 9-7 in the fifth, Gasquet 7‚Äì6 in the third, and Nalbandian 7‚Äì6 in the fifth). That‚Äôs three points away from being 84‚Äì1, with 13 titles and the chance to win 3 Grand Slams and the Masters finals. (The only match where he didn‚Äôt have a chance to win was a four-set loss to Nadal at the French Open.) 2.\xa0In the fall, Federer was injured in a training session, suffering torn ligaments in his ankle. After pulling out from Madrid, Basel and Paris and being confined to a cast and crutches for several weeks, Federer agreed to go to Shanghai for the Masters Finals after five top players pulled out due to injury or family matters. He was unsure if he would be able to play even two days from the start of the tournament, and somehow hobbled through the tournament before losing to Nalbandian in the finals. 3.\xa0The loss ended his 35-match winning streak, and broke his record of 24 consecutive finals won. 2005 Roger Federer tennis season - Wikipedia 4.\xa0In 2006, he won the Australian Open and another 15 straight matches. Federer‚Äôs tip prime: from the French Open semi-finals until his loss in the 2006 finals at Dubai, Federer won three consecutive Slams, compiling a record of 50‚Äì1 (98.0%), and winning 7 titles out of 8 tournaments. Or, you could count until his loss in Monte Carlos for a 68‚Äì2 (97.1%), winning 9 of 11 tournaments. Either way, it‚Äôs razor close to being the all-time best run of invincibility, but I still think it‚Äôs only number three. #2 Djokovic 2011: people overlook this season, focusing on 2015. But there is no comparison between the level of competition in 2011 and 2015. In 2011, Nadal is 25 and in his prime as the #1 player in the world. Federer is 29, turning 30 that August, and still formidable. Djokovic was 70‚Äì6, with 10 titles and 3 grand Slams. Injuries may have slowed him down, losing 4 matches to end the year, but here‚Äôs why it is by far his all-time best season: 1.\xa0Djokovic was 7‚Äì16 head to head against Nadal, including 0‚Äì8 on clay. Djokovic was playing so great, he beat the Spaniard twice on the dirt, and went 6‚Äì0 overall against Nadal that year. 2.\xa0In December 2010, Djokovic led Serbia to its first Davis Cup title, giving him a burst of confidence that would carry him to his greatest heights. 3.\xa0Adding his 2 Davis Cup singles wins, Djokovic ran off 43 straight wins to start the 2011 season, for the fifth longest win streak in history. 4.\xa0Federer bested Djokovic in four tough sets at the French Open semi-finals, which ended his streak, but he came back and won 15 straight matches, including Wimbledon, before retiring against Murray in the finals at Cincinnati. 5.\xa0Djokovic recovered again to win the U.S. Open, hitting the riskiest (luckiest?) serve return winner I‚Äôve ever seen when down match point in the semis against Federer. Djokovic‚Äôs tip prime: Including Davis Cup, Djokovic went on a 66‚Äì2 run (97.0%), including 43 straight wins, with 3 Slams and 10 titles out of 12 tournaments played. Or, if you want to cut off his record before the second loss, Djokovic went on a 58‚Äì1 run (98.27%), with 2 Slams and 9 titles out of 11 tournaments. #1: Federer 2006‚Äì2007: Federer won 12 titles, 3 Grand Slams and the ATP Finals. His 92‚Äì5 record is .005 lower than 2005, but is even more incredible, as only two players in the world won matches against him, a 20-year-old Nadal, already the greatest clay court player in history, and a rising Andy Murray, about to enter the top 15. The season is notable for the following reasons: 1.\xa0Out of 17 tournaments, he only lost one match that wasn‚Äôt in the finals. 2.\xa0Out of his 5 losses, four would come against Nadal, of which 3 were on clay. (He beat Nadal once on grass and once indoors that year). 3.\xa0Federer held match point against Nadal in the finals of Rome, but lost 7‚Äì6 in the fifth set. 4.\xa0This might have been Federer‚Äôs best chance to win the calendar Slam, reaching a fourth set tie breaker in the final against Nadal. Federer‚Äôs tip prime: Federer started the season 32‚Äì1, winning the Australian and three other titles. After losing three clay court finals to Nadal including the French, Federer won 3 consecutive Slams, compiling a 59‚Äì1 record (98.33%), including 41 straight wins, and won 10 titles out of 11 tournaments played. Notes: the difference between Federer and Djokovic‚Äôs best runs really comes down to microscopic differences: 1) Djokovic lost to Federer at Roland Garros, instead of getting the chance to test Nadal; and 2) Federer was up two sets to love and match point at the US Open; and 3) Federer won three consecutive Slams while losing only one match over a period of seven months, while Djokovic won three non-consecutive Slams while losing two matches over a nine month period.

But the thing that makes this season so special is because he went 6‚Äì0 against Nadal and 4‚Äì1 Federer that year.

People just don‚Äôt remember how good Federer was.

column3: What are some of the mind-blowing facts about Roger Federer?
column4:
Federer Has a Pet Cow Named ‚ÄúJuliette‚Äù


Federer received a special gift when he won the Wimbledon for the first time. And this gift was a milking cow that he named ‚ÄúJuliette‚Äù. Eventually, Juliette gave birth to ‚ÄúEdelweiss‚Äù, which was named by Federer himself.

2011‚Äôs 2nd Most Admired Person in the World


In a 2011 poll, Federer ranked as the 2nd most respected and admired person in the world, next to Nelson Mandela, out of the 54 well-known personalities in the field of sports, politics, business and culture.

column3: Do you think that Federer can end 2017 as Number 1? What's the probability as a percentage?
column4:
Federer is scheduled to play Basel (ATP 500), Shanghai (Master‚Äôs 1000), Paris (Master‚Äôs 1000) & ATP World Tour Finals (1500 points). If Federer wins all these 4 tournaments, he will end up securing 4000 points for himself, and along with that the no.1 position.

Nadal on the other hand is scheduled to play for 4500 points. That‚Äôs almost as many points as he won during the clay season this year. Winning any 2 tournaments along with deep finishes in the other 3 would be enough to help him secure the no.1 position (he will also play Beijing 500 in addition to all the tournaments mentioned above).

As things stand now, Federer has 7,505 points in the singles race which puts him 1,860 points behind Nadal‚Äôs 9,365. With around 4000 points remaining, I would say that the situation is ripe for a neck to neck finish. All Nadal has to do is win 2,140 points from the remainder of the tournaments and he is through.

But winning 2,140 points is not as easy as it sounds especially since all these tournaments are played in indoor courts which are pacier and thus Nadal‚Äôs least-favorite surface.

Here is the breakdown of points accumulated by Nadal post US-Open since 2010:

2010 - 1,510 points (won in Japan Open 500, 3rd round in Shanghai, Finals in ATP WTF)

2011 - 290 points (3R loss in Shanghai, 2 Round Robin losses in ATP WTF)

2012 - 0 points (Season ended after Wimbledon)

2013 - 2,020 points (Finals in Beijing and ATP WTF, SFs in Shanghai and Paris)

2014 - 225 points (suffering with appendicitis, he pulled out of Paris and ATP WTF)

2015 - 1,920 points (Finals in Beijing and Basel, SF in Shanghai, Paris and ATP WTF)

2016 - 225 Points (Hampered by injuries. Pulled out of the remainder of the season after Shanghai Open)

As we can see, Nadal has failed to accumulate 2,140 points in the last 6 seasons. He struggles to make finals or even semi finals here. He actually even failed to win these tournaments during his peak. 2 bad tournaments coupled with a stellar Federer season-end sweep could result in Federer sneaking ahead in the race.

That being said, it is unfair to assume that Federer will sweep all the tournaments that he will play in. Usually this is the part of season dominated by Djokovic and Murray. It will be interesting to see how Federer performs with both of them out of the picture. All it takes for Federer to lose the race is one bad tournament. For him to finish as world no.1, he has to partake in all these tournaments and end up winning them or making the finals (and praying Nadal sucks).

Here is the breakdown of points accumulated by Federer post US-Open since 2010:

2010 - 3,210 points (won Basel, Stockholm 250 and ATP WTF, Final in Shanghai, SF in Paris)

2011 - 3,000 points (Won Basel, Paris and ATP WTF. Did not play Shanghai)

2012 - 1,460 points (Final in Basel and ATP WTF, SF in Shanghai, Did not play Paris)

2013 - 1,150 points (Finals in Basel, SF in ATP WTF & Paris, 3rd round in Shanghai)

2014 - 2,860 points (Won in Basel and Shanghai, QF in Paris, Finals in ATP WTF)

2015 - 1,635 points (Won in Basel, 3rd round in Paris, 2nd Round in Shanghai, Finals ATP WTF)

2016 - 0 Points (withdrew after Wimbledon)

Even though Federer is more consistent in this part of the season, it is still advantage Nadal. This season, Nadal is as fit as he could be. That means Nadal is going to play all these tournaments and there will be no walk outs and withdrawals from his end.

Whenever Nadal play all the tournaments, he ends up winning at least 1,500 points. That is likely going to be the case this season as well. Therefore, for Federer to clinch the ranking, he would have to win more than 3,300 points. A feat he has not achieved in the last 7 seasons! (I haven‚Äôt seen the records prior to 2010)

The only seasons where Federer has won more than 1,860 points than Nadal during this time of the season in the last 7 years were in the years 2011 and 2014. During both these seasons, Nadal did not play all the tournaments. He was unfit. That will not be the case this season.

Federer is still hanging in there with an outside chance to clinch the ranking, but it is unlikely that he will win all the 4 tournaments. For Federer to end as year end no.1, he is going to need the best he has ever performed during this time of the season. It appears unlikely! The probability, therefore, is quite low.

That being said, it is unfair to assume that Federer will sweep all the tournaments that he will play in. Usually this is the part of season dominated by Djokovic and Murray. It will be interesting to see how Federer performs with both of them out of the picture. All it takes for Federer to lose the race is one bad tournament. For him to finish as world no.1, he has to partake in all these tournaments and end up winning them or making the finals (and praying Nadal sucks).

Here is the breakdown of points accumulated by Federer post US-Open since 2010:

2010 - 3,210 points (won Basel, Stockholm 250 and ATP WTF, Final in Shanghai, SF in Paris)

2011 - 3,000 points (Won Basel, Paris and ATP WTF. Did not play Shanghai)

2012 - 1,460 points (Final in Basel and ATP WTF, SF in Shanghai, Did not play Paris)

2013 - 1,150 points (Finals in Basel, SF in ATP WTF & Paris, 3rd round in Shanghai)

2014 - 2,860 points (Won in Basel and Shanghai, QF in Paris, Finals in ATP WTF)

2015 - 1,635 points (Won in Basel, 3rd round in Paris, 2nd Round in Shanghai, Finals ATP WTF)

2016 - 0 Points (withdrew after Wimbledon)

Even though Federer is more consistent in this part of the season, it is still advantage Nadal. This season, Nadal is as fit as he could be. That means Nadal is going to play all these tournaments and there will be no walk outs and withdrawals from his end.

Whenever Nadal play all the tournaments, he ends up winning at least 1,500 points. That is likely going to be the case this season as well. Therefore, for Federer to clinch the ranking, he would have to win more than 3,300 points. A feat he has not achieved in the last 7 seasons! (I haven‚Äôt seen the records prior to 2010)

The only seasons where Federer has won more than 1,860 points than Nadal during this time of the season in the last 7 years were in the years 2011 and 2014. During both these seasons, Nadal did not play all the tournaments. He was unfit. That will not be the case this season.

Federer is still hanging in there with an outside chance to clinch the ranking, but it is unlikely that he will win all the 4 tournaments. For Federer to end as year end no.1, he is going to need the best he has ever performed during this time of the season. It appears unlikely! The probability, therefore, is quite low.', 'aiModelVersion': '1'}

column3: Are tennis balls safe for dogs?
column4:
While tennis balls themselves are not toxic, there are potential risks associated with their use. The fuzzy covering of tennis balls can be shredded by some dogs, and if ingested, it can lead to choking or gastrointestinal blockage. Additionally, the abrasive texture of tennis balls can cause dental damage to dogs' teeth over time.

Dog lovers suggest that using balls specifically made for dogs, such as rubber balls, may be a safer alternative. These balls are designed with materials that are less likely to break down or pose a choking hazard.

It's important to supervise your dog during playtime and inspect toys regularly for signs of wear and tear.

column3: Why is Andy Murray considered a part of big 4, when he's far behind Novak, Nadal, and Federer in terms of talent?
column4:
As big as the divide between Andy Murray and the Big 3, the divide between him and the rest of the tour was wider.

Andy Murray was the only player to consistently win against the Big 3 in major tournaments. At the beginning of his career, he struggled to compete with them but by 2012, he was keeping up. That year he won the gold medal at the Olympics, won the US Open, and lost a tough battle to Federer in the Wimbledon Finals after 4 sets.

Murray was spotty for the next few years, but in 2016 he did it all again. He won his second consecutive gold medal in singles at the 2016 Olympics (the only player to ever do so) and won Wimbledon for the second time in his career. That, combined with a stellar performance at the lesser tournaments on the tour, propelled Murray to the coveted No.1 ranking and the ITF men‚Äôs world champion award.

No other player disrupted the Big 3 as much as Murray that year or since. He has 29 combined wins against them, significantly more than any other player outside the Big 3.

Murray may have only won 3 Grand Slams, but his performance against the Big 3 suggests that in any other era where the competition was weaker, he could have won many more. That‚Äôs why he‚Äôs often referred to as a member of the Big 4.

column3: Are Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray friends (off-court)?
column4:
I read these lines in an interview which Novak Djokovic gave in 2011:

"Sometimes, I have dinner with Andy or Rafa; but the reality is none of us can be real mates while we are fighting for history. But one day, when we've all retired, I look forward to sitting down over a beer with them all, and their families, and remember what we went through."

Sums it up, right!

column3: What are some interesting facts about tennis?
column4:
1. Men vs Women

In 1998, during the Australian Open, sisters Serena and Venus Williams declared that they could win a match against any man, who is under the 200th place in the ATP rating. Karsten Braasch, who was 203rd back then, accepted the challenge. He won the first set with Venus with the score 6-2 and the second one against Serena with the score 6-1. After the match, he added that he didn‚Äôt really do his best and that he actually played as a 600th place in the ATP rating.

Historic Men vs Women Tennis Matches

2. Ace-King combination

Anna Kournikova hasn‚Äôt won a single Professional Tournament in singles in the whole professional career. Poker players named the Ace-King combination after her because it looks good but almost never wins.

3. ‚ÄúMixed handedness‚Äù

Rafael Nadal plays with his left hand even though he was born right-handed. His uncle taught him to hold a tennis racket with his left hand when Nadal was 12 years old. He explained it to Rafael that the left-handed players can enjoy an advantage over their right-handed opponents because they‚Äôre uncomfortable to play with as they strike into the opposite direction and can make the ball whirl in an inconvenient for the right-handed players way.

4. Tennis during the Second World War

In 1943, in summer, Moscow Open Tennis Tournament should have been taken place, but it appeared that there were no tennis balls anywhere in Moscow. The only factory that was producing tennis balls, ‚ÄúKrasniy Treugolnyk‚Äù (‚ÄòRed Triangle‚Äô) was located in Leningrad (today‚Äôs St. Petersburg) that was under siege at that time and was almost destroyed during German bombardments. Russians managed to find tennis balls in the destroyed storehouses of the factory. However, they were all drained and covered with mold. Therefore, they had to pump up those balls full with the help of ultra-thin needles and then whiten them.

5. Tennis's reluctant transgender pioneer

Ren√©e Richards‚Äôs case is unprecedented in the history of tennis. She is the only person in the history who took part both in the Men‚Äôs Circuit and, after a sex reassignment surgery, in the Women‚Äôs Circuit.

6. Nadal-Federer Battle of Surfaces

The most noticeable and strange match took place in 2007. Roger Federer is considered ‚Äòthe king of grass‚Äô (he won Wimbledon multiple times), whereas Rafael Nadal is considered ‚Äòthe king of clay‚Äô. A special court was constructed in such a way that one side was made out of grass and another side was made out of clay. Both players had to change sneakers each time when changing sides. Nadal won that time in three sets.

column3: Why did Novak Djokovic struggle in plexicushion hard court surface in Japan Olympics, which look similar to Rod Laver arena in Australia?
column4:
Novak Djokovic was touted to be the favourite to win the Olympic gold this time around in tennis. It was no surprise as he was in a red hot form coming into the tournament.

He had won his favourite Australian open earlier in the year, French open by beating the favourite Rafael Nadal and Wimbledon open.

Add to that, the legendary players like Nadal, Federer and Murray (in the middle) pulling out of the games. It was literally supposed to be a cakewalk for the World no.1.

And till semifinals, there was no sign of any unexpected result. He hadn't dropped a set till then.

But..

On the given day of semifinal, how good was Zverev ! He beat the world no.1 after being 1‚Äì6, 1‚Äì3 down..!! He had the nerves of steel.

Image credits - The Japan Times.

As a result, Djokovic‚Äôs dream of achieving the golden slam came to an end.

In the bronze medal match too, he lost against Busta of Spain after giving a tough fight. He pulled out of the mixed doubles bronze medal match due to an injury suffered in the men's singles bronze medal match. So, he had to leave the games empty handed.

Image credits - Al Jazeera.

Now, here are some of the reasons why, I feel, Djokovic failed in the games-

Playing too many tournaments without break - Yes. He has been playing many tournaments without a break. As soon as he won the French open, he sensed an opportunity of achieving the golden slam. He hence participated in Wimbledon open and won there too. While his body needed rest, he didn't listen to it and took part in the games.
Hectic Olympic schedule - In Olympics, there would hardly be any rest day. The players will have to play in consecutive days for most of the games. Add to that his age. He's 34 and it's difficult to sustain the calmness for a longer period of time.
Playing both singles and mixed double events - I guess that's the biggest reason for his failure. He could've avoided playing in mixed doubles. The schedule was already tough and playing one more game daily for about couple of sets would've led him to heavy fatigue.
Opponent better on the day - Of course, Djokovic is a master on hard courts. But the new generation players are very very good on hard court. They can beat any player on hard courts on the given day. The examples of recent support the fact (Tsitsipas beating Nadal in Australian open 2021).
Crowd (!?) - This is on a funnier note. Djokovic rises to his own when the crowd tried to demoralise him. But due to no crowds in the stadium, there was no factor of demoralisation for the Serbian. Somewhere it would've played a part in his loss.

Here's what Djokovic had to say about his journey in the Games-

‚ÄúI do have a regret for not winning a medal for my country and opportunities missed both in mixed doubles and singles and, yeah, I just didn't deliver yesterday and today.

The level of tennis dropped also due to exhaustion, you know, mentally and physically.

But I don't regret coming to the Olympics at all. Of course not. I believe there is no coincidence in life, everything happens for a reason and I had some heartbreaking losses at the Olympic Games and some big tournaments in my career.

Djokovic told to reporters.

He's a champion player and is known for the comeback. I'm pretty sure he'd comeback in style at US Open where he would be having an opportunity of achieving a rare calender slam.

Thank you.
