The level of tennis dropped also due to exhaustion, you know, mentally and physically.

But I don't regret coming to the Olympics at all. Of course not. I believe there is no coincidence in life, everything happens for a reason and I had some heartbreaking losses at the Olympic Games and some big tournaments in my career.

Djokovic told to reporters.

He's a champion player and is known for the comeback. I'm pretty sure he'd comeback in style at US Open where he would be having an opportunity of achieving a rare calender slam.

Thank you.", 'aiModelVersion': '1'}

column3: Should Naomi Osaka give back the US Open title in solidarity with Serena Williams?
column4:
This is an extremely leading question that assumes the following:

Mr. Ramos (the chair umpire) treated Serena unfairly.
Mr. Ramos ill-treated Serena because she is a woman.
After decades of enforcing rules consistently across gender lines, Mr. Ramos singled out Serena Williams, the most notable female figure in the sport, in front of millions of viewers, to administer unfair punitive measures.
Chair umpires should not enforce the rules at the US Open final.
Professional tennis treats women so unfairly that solidarity is necessary to fight for their cause.
Naomi Osaka should feel she did not earn the U.S. Open title but rather received it unjustly in a manner that is an oppression to women everywhere.
Those who scream the loudest should be rewarded for their ridiculous behavior.
Serena William‚Äôs harsh reaction to an umpire professionally and correctly enforcing the rules is a great example for impressionable female players everywhere.

Instead of elaborating on the absurdity of these assumptions, I offer the following:

Naomi Osaka has revered Serena Williams for most of her life. She always dreamed of playing against her idol in a major final and winning a tough competitive match. She stated on a talk show after the final, that she was crying because she felt the crowd may be booing her because they did not get the winner they wanted. She felt so privileged that Serena recognized she was crying and consoled her. She didn‚Äôt understand what was going on mainly because during the match she was extremely focused on what she had set out to accomplish.

She stated that she will go back and review everything so she can understand what happened. When she does, it would be reasonable for her to lose her reverence for Serena and lower her opinion of her idol, but I doubt that she will.

She fulfilled her dream of winning the major title against Serena Williams, but instead of joy, she experienced sadness and pain. Instead of experiencing the thrill of victory, she felt compelled to apologize for winning. This caused because Serena threw a tantrum, not because she was being treated unfairly, but because she was getting soundly beaten in a major final.

I think the answer to the question above is completely obvious.

column3: Why has Grigor Dimitrov not lived up to his potential?
column4:
There is a whole generation of incredible players (Gasquet, Tsonga, Berdych, Nishikori, Verdasco, Monfils, Goffin and Raonic, etc) who have fallen short of the Big Four in terms of breaking into the top rankings or winning Slams. Dimitrov is just one more great player who, for various reasons, has been unable to break through.

Calling Dimitrov ‚ÄúBaby Fed‚Äù is not only unfortunate because of the ridiculous extra pressure it put on him as a young player, but is inaccurate on many levels (even though it is a tidy literary trope we are all guilty of using):

Technique: Dimitrov‚Äôs one-handed backhand is super wristy and looks much closer to Richard Gasquet. His serve isn‚Äôt a weapon like Federer‚Äôs. And he is not as comfortable flattening out his forehand and taking balls on the rise. Also, Federer is unique among players for his ability to hit offensive shots off the half volley when an opponent hits a deep serve return or groundstroke.

Style: Dmitrov is one of those guys who can do a lot of things really well, but doesn‚Äôt have one single unique attribute that is outstanding. To have early success, a player needs to do something at an other worldly level which means he only has to focus on playing one way. Examples are Becker‚Äôs serve on grass, Chang‚Äôs legs on clay and Nadal‚Äôs topspin forehand and fighting spirit on clay. Guys like Dmitrov and David Goffin don‚Äôt have the weapons to blow someone off a court, like Tsonga did at age 23 to Nadal at the 2008 Australian Open.

Dmitrov just turned 26 and is still figuring out how to play the big points. At present, he has reached two semi-finals at the Slams, compared to none for Stan Wawrinka at the same stage of his career.

Training: Dmitrov, like many young players, enjoyed a spectacular rise in the rankings on the strength of their natural talent and youthful energy. As other players learned his game, the matches get tougher and he begin to feel the grind of the tour. In 2015, he started working with Larry Stefanki, a coach famous for getting Roddick into the shape of his life when his ranking started to drop off. Dmitrov.

Mental Toughness: Like many young stars, Dmitrov wasn‚Äôt ready for primetime as soon as pundits thought he was. It is very rare for young players to reach the top without going through a period of taking some knocks and paying their dues. Federer, Nadal and Djokovic are geniuses and freaks of nature. Even all-time greats like Agassi and Sampras have had great early results, then fell back until they matured more.

Dmitrov destroyed world #3 Andy Murray in straight sets at the 2014 Wimbledon quarter-finals, then had a competitive 4-set match with world #1 Djokovic in the semis, and reached #8 in the world at 23. He lost focus, firing his coach, and started losing. Over the last year and a half, he started to climb back into the top 10, so his trajectory seems pretty normal to me.

Surfaces: Back in the old days, before the surface and balls speeds were adjusted to be more uniform, players who were specialists on a particular surface (especially grass and clay) could sneak up on the field a win Slam titles. In spite of Sampras‚Äô dominance at Wimbledon, ...

column3: What do you think about Serena Williams losing her match? Was it sexism or her behavior?
column4:
I think she lost because she just got beat.

Her loss in the US Open final was the 136th defeat of her WTA career, and her second straight in a major final. She‚Äôs lost eight times in the final of a major tournament.

Even the greatest player of all time doesn‚Äôt win everything. Maybe she had a bad day, or maybe she‚Äôs still not completely back to her form before she had the baby, and maybe she never will be‚Äîshe is 36, after all.

It had nothing to do with sexism or her behavior. It had to do with a tennis player named Naomi Osaka who went out on the court and beat her.

column3: How many players are required to play tennis?
column4:
Tennis can be played with two player setups or four player setups, depending on the format:

Singles: This is the standard format where two players compete against each other, one-on-one. This is the most common format seen in professional and competitive tennis.
Doubles: This format involves four players, with two players on each side of the net forming a team. Teams compete against each other, and each team member takes turns hitting the ball.

So, the number of players required to play tennis depends on the chosen format: either 2 players in singles or 4 players in doubles.

column3: Serb Novak Djokovic has problems to be admitted to defend his title at Australian Open. Do you think, healthy but unvaccinated players should be or shouldn‚Äôt be allowed to play?
column4:
I think that people that want to enter a country, no matter which one, should follow the immigration laws of that country. This should apply to every person equally, no matter if they're a poor student, a tourist, a businessman, an actor, musician or a world class sports person.

Once they've done that they can participate in whatever event said country has to offer.

column3: What do you think of Roger Federer's retirement from tennis at 41?
column4:
We all knew it was coming, but it‚Äôs still sad to see.

Somehow, none of us wanted to believe the Federer era was over. We all wanted to see one last run at Wimbledon, one Grand Slam match, and one last battle against Djokovic or Nadal. Alas, it wasn‚Äôt to be.

Only Federer could keep us believing he could come back. He‚Äôs 41 years old now, and hasn‚Äôt been on tour in over a year. Yet millions of fans around the world still waited with bated breath for the announcement that he was back in form and winning again. That‚Äôs what happens when you witness Federer pull off the greatest comebacks in the history of tennis.

How many people thought Federer was washed up and ready to retire after 2016? He was turning 35, struggling with knee and back injuries (and later surgery), failed to win a single title for the first time since 2000, and even fell out of the Top 15. He just couldn‚Äôt keep up. Then the magic happened.

Federer roared back into action with an unbelievable 2017 season, winning his 18th and 19th Grand Slams, including a record 8th Wimbledon. Along the way, he beat Nadal in all 3 of their meetings and managed a 54‚Äì5 record, rising to No.2 and proving he was far from retiring. And it only continued into 2018, when he won his 20th Grand Slam at the Australian Open, and finally reclaimed his spot as No.1 in the world, becoming the oldest No.1 in ATP history.

Federer reigned in the Top 3 all the way through 2019, after making another historic run at Wimbledon to reach the finals. 37 years old and he was still one of the best players in the world, only narrowly losing to Novak Djokovic after nearly 5 hours on court.

Finally, things slowed down in 2020 as he underwent more surgery, and it seemed like Federer was winding down for a long-overdue retirement. Or so we thought. Sure enough, Federer bounced back in 2021 to make one last run at Wimbledon, becoming the oldest quarterfinalist (39!) in the Open era, and defying expectations one last time. Then surgery hit again, he stopped playing for a year, and now he‚Äôs officially decided to retire from tennis.

What a career. At least, in a fitting swan song, Federer will be playing his last matches at the Laver Cup, alongside Djokovic, Nadal, and Murray, marking the first time the Big 4 plays together and the last time we‚Äôll ever see them together on the tour.

Only Federer could keep us believing he could come back. He‚Äôs 41 years old now, and hasn‚Äôt been on tour in over a year. Yet millions of fans around the world still waited with bated breath for the announcement that he was back in form and winning again. That‚Äôs what happens when you witness Federer pull off the greatest comebacks in the history of tennis.

How many people thought Federer was washed up and ready to retire after 2016? He was turning 35, struggling with knee and back injuries (and later surgery), failed to win a single title for the first time since 2000, and even fell out of the Top 15. He just couldn‚Äôt keep up. Then the magic happened.

Federer roared back into action with an unbelievable 2017 season, winning his 18th and 19th Grand Slams, including a record 8th Wimbledon. Along the way, he beat Nadal in all 3 of their meetings and managed a 54‚Äì5 record, rising to No.2 and proving he was far from retiring. And it only continued into 2018, when he won his 20th Grand Slam at the Australian Open, and finally reclaimed his spot as No.1 in the world, becoming the oldest No.1 in ATP history.

Federer reigned in the Top 3 all the way through 2019, after making another historic run at Wimbledon to reach the finals. 37 years old and he was still one of the best players in the world, only narrowly losing to Novak Djokovic after nearly 5 hours on court.

Finally, things slowed down in 2020 as he underwent more surgery, and it seemed like Federer was winding down for a long-overdue retirement. Or so we thought. Sure enough, Federer bounced back in 2021 to make one last run at Wimbledon, becoming the oldest quarterfinalist (39!) in the Open era, and defying expectations one last time. Then surgery hit again, he stopped playing for a year, and now he‚Äôs officially decided to retire from tennis.

What a career. At least, in a fitting swan song, Federer will be playing his last matches at the Laver Cup, alongside Djokovic, Nadal, and Murray, marking the first time the Big 4 plays together and the last time we‚Äôll ever see them together on the tour.', 'aiModelVersion': '1'}

column3: What is your favorite tennis moment?
column4:
Ok, I'm going to pick a pretty unconventional, but nevertheless exhilarating tennis moment. Something that just turned the sagging fortunes of a man around. After winning that crucial point , somehow everything sorted itself out and That man went on to win the Tournament, thus becoming the 6th ever person to achieve a career Grand slam. Yes that person is the Swiss Maestro, Roger Federer and the Tournament was French Open 2009. To fully understand and appreciate the gravity of that moment, that shot, lets quickly recap what preceded it.

BACKGROUND

The year 2008 is a sort of a watershed year in tennis. 2 very significant things happened:

Roger Federer, who dominated the game like it was nobody's business for the past 4 years ushering in an era of absolute dominance never before seen on a tennis court, fell from his throne and his invincibility waned rapidly




The meteoric surge of Rafael Nadal from a clay court genius to an all court player.


Nadal manhandled Federer in the Roland Garros 2008 final that year handing him the worst defeat of his career in a Grand Slam(6-1,6-3,6-0), thus thwarting the Swiss Maestro's 3rd consecutive attempt to capture the title.

Then, Wimbledon happened. Roger Federer who was on an unbeaten 5 tournament streak at SW 19 lost in 5 excrutiatingly closely fought sets to Rafael Nadal in the finals. Nadal was the crowned the new King. The King of the lawns and beyond, The world no.1 was finally his.

Federer somehow managed to save himself the blushes and went on to take the US Open 2008, thus saving what had been quite an ordinary year by his standards(1 SF, 2 Finals, 1 GS.. Yeah, ordinary)


ENTER THE YEAR 2009

A year that would prove to be iconic in more than one way.

We Fed fans were hoping Fed would be back to his winning ways. But Oh well, that was not the script that was in store for us. The script was a bit more tortuous, more dramatic.

Federer and Nadal met yet again in the finals of the Australian Open and Nadal dealt Federer yet another 5 set death blow. This was their 3rd final in less than a year, all 3 having been won by Nadal. This humiliation was further capped by a public meltdown where Federer just broke down, sobbing uncontrollably.
The nightmare would just not end. Nowhere to run. Nowhere to hide.



Wait, did you think things couldn't get any worse?! Oh, but it did.
Yet. Another. Meltdown. In a match against Djokovic at Miami, Federer just went nuts and smashed his racquet, shattering its frame completely. Federer . Never. Smashes. Racquets. Bizarre. Just Bizarre. This was the Rock Bottom. Federer was mentally crushed. So were his fans.

On top of that Federer told the press he was looking forward to clay!. This in particular tickled my funny bone. Talk about Bizarre statements. He couldn't do jack squat on Hard courts, what could he do on his weakest surface, especially when Nadal was in the form of his life?! Frankly as a fan, there were 0 expectations.

CLAY SEASON 2009

Madrid Masters happened. Federer and Nadal again in the finals. On clay. We know how that goes. I didn't even bother watching. So it did surprise me(to put it mildly) when I learned he beat Nadal in straight sets!!.. And his finger wag after the victory. It indicated something. This man was back from the dead.

Yeah, don't mess with me.

But this victory did nothing to boost my expectations for The French Open. I fully expected Nadal to win RG for the 5th consecutive time and after last year's finals I had reconciled myself to the very plausible idea that Federer may never win the French.

But then came the mother of all surprises, in the form of ROBIN "GODSEND" SODERLING. He packed Rafa off in 4 sets becoming the first man ever(the only man till now) to take down Rafa at the French.

Now, this French Open was Federer's to take. The Draw was wide open.

Federer was to play Tommy Haas in the fourth round of the French Open, a day after Soderling vanquished Nadal. I expected it to be a breeze. But boy, was I in for a shock.

FIrst set, Federer served admirably, and yet ended up losing 7-6.

Second set Roger was shanking left, right and centre.. putting on an ugly, unwatchable performance and in that process, losing that set too..

Federer was down two sets to love, apparently following Rafa on his way out.

The errors continued to flow thick and fast even in the 3rd set.

So finally we arrive at "The Moment"

THE MOMENT


It was 4-4 in the 3rd set. Federer was serving .Tommy was up 2 sets to love. And another spate of errors from helped Tommy go up break point.

It was 30-40. Staring down the barrel now.

Federer was hanging by a thread and Tommy was on the cusp of a legendary victory.

A rally ensues at Break Point and on predictable lines, Tommy takes control of it. Federer runs around his backhand and WHAM!! He takes a wild crack at the ball, inside-out Forehand, My heart almost sank..I think it actually stopped beating for a second or two..I expected it would go out like many other balls from Federer did that day! But it catches the line. Oh! It catches the frikkin line!!! Unbelievable. What a shot at what a crucial juncture. I'm telling you, had he lost that point, Roger would have been knocked out. The relief on Federer's face said it all.

Yeah that's the look.

That Forehand liberated him, it set his mind free, it reminded him of who he was. He got out of jail there. It was the magic potion which he so badly needed. From that point on I knew , this match was over and Federer was gonna stomp over Haas, which was precisely what happened and order was restored at last.

And of one more thing I was pretty certain once that Forehand went in:

The French Open was coming home baby! Yeah! Finally!!

Sweet kiss of accomplishment

If Roger Federer has to credit any one single shot that brought him eternal glory and immortality, it has to be this insane inside out Forehand against Haas on Break point. The single most important shot he has ever hit.

column3: What is the best color tennis ball for dogs?
column4:
Q: What is the best color tennis ball for dogs?

A: Dogs have limited colour perception (dichromatic) and can only discern blue and yellow colours. Everything else is probably a browny- grey colour. Given these limitations, I‚Äôd say that a yellow coloured ball would be best.

column3: Tennis:
column4: Rafa Nadal: much more than a tennis player, than a sportsman It  is three years ago now since we inaugurated our centre, NOVAELITE. It   was an unforgettable day with many Olympic champions there, Rafa Nadal   among them. You can imagine what it meant to us to count on his  presence  and support. We thought and thought about what gesture we  could make  for him. I got in touch with Miguel √Ångel Calleja, one of  those friends  who always help you: "Miguel √Ångel, could you prepare us  an emotive  video of the 50 best points in Rafa's career with the type  of music he  likes?"... and he, who is really good at it, prepared the  video for us. 			 Before the official inauguration and in  private... we put the video  on for Rafa... the 50 best points of his  career. There were points from  matches at any time... the 4th game from  the 2nd round in Australia  years ago... the 7th game from the 4th  round at Wimbledon... and you  cannot imagine our surprise, our  incredulity... when he began to be one  step ahead when he saw what  point it was... and he described the point  to us... before it  happened!!! He even told us to watch out for a bad  bounce in one point  from a match in Rome... three years before!! 			 We had to rub our eyes... we were not dreaming... I will never forget this moment. 			 There are many things I admire about Rafa, one of which is every   time he speaks at press conferences. He always does it perfectly. Not   long ago he said: "There is something that makes me even happier than   being number one and that is the process, the effort, the path taken to   get there." 			 I have always thought that one competes as one  lives. Rafa is an  example of the importance of day to day work, of  getting up each day and  trying to be a bit better than yesterday, and  of an unlimited desire to  improve. He manages to achieve levels on the  mental side, in the  capacity to overcome adversity, that you do not  think exist, you think  are impossible, and Rafa shows you they are  possible for him (only for  him). 			 A person who is capable of  remembering the points we prepared for  him on this video, in detail...  shows you that he lives his passion -  tennis, competition and  everything it involves - in his interior like  nobody else, to an  extraordinary degree. 			 I think we have run out of adjectives  and qualifications to use when  speaking about Rafa Nadal the person and  Rafa Nadal the tennis player.  He is an authentic world number one both  on and off the court, because  of his values, his attitude, everything  he communicates to us, his  capacity for surpassing himself, his passion  and many things more. .... @http://www.vamosbrigade.com/arti...

column3: What are some interesting facts about tennis?
column4:
The man in the picture below is Miguel Homar who played in three FIFA world cups.

But what has it got to do with Tennis? Do you recognize the boy in the picture :)





Dr Renee Richards had competed in the US Open, in both Men's and Women's singles event.

She had previously played as Richard Raskind and then underwent a sex change surgery.





A Pineapple, adorns the top of the Wimbledon's Men Singles' Trophy

It represents English sailors who used to put pineapples outside their homes after returning from a long voyage.





Roland Garros, the person after which the stadium where French Open takes place, never played professional Tennis.

In 1927, the stadium authorities offered the tennis authorities 3 hectares of land to play tennis if they named the stadium after the French World War 1 Pilot - Roland Garros




Until today, Goran Ivanisevic is the only grand slam champion whose name alternates consonants and vowels.

He also happens to be the only 'wildcard' entrant to have won a grand slam in the men's singles category.





Before moving to the hard courts at Flushing Medows - US Open used to be a clay and before that a grass court tournament.


Adding to the last one, Jimmy Connors is the only player to have won the US Open - on grass('74), on clay('76) and on hard courts('78).


A trained Hawk, called Hamish, keeps pigeons at bay during the Wimbledon tournament.





Elton John's song - Philadelphia Freedom - is a tribute to Billie Jean King.





Tim Henman - became the first player to be disqualified from Wimbledon in 1995.

In a fit of rage, he smashed the ball away which hit a ball girl directly in her face. This was a doubles match and his partner also got affected.





The Center Court at Wimbledon took 5 bombs during the World War 2 and 1200 seats were destroyed.

It took 9 years to fix the stadium. Fortunately, no one died.


A tennis match once lasted for 3 days.

In the 2010 Wimbledon, John Isner and Nicolas Mahut played an epic match which lasted for 11 hours 5 min and was played over 3 days. It is the longest match in tennis history both by time and number of games.

The loudest recorded 'grunt' came from Maria Sharapova.

It was of 105 decibels recorded at the Wimbledon'09.






In a 2007 US Open match, Roger Federer went through 105 consecutive points without making an unforced error !!

What will happen when a cricket player, who doesn't know tennis, falls in love with a tennis player, who doesn't know cricket?

column3: What is the science behind why dogs love tennis balls?
column4:
Its not that they love `Tennis Balls ` in particular. A dog with a decent prey drive will get attached to anything that is regularly thrown for it to chase after. MY dog with his OTT prey drive, will chase after ANYTHING that is thrown for him. The highlight of this game is if I throw his reward toy for him, which is a 4‚Ä≥ rubber ring. ______By the way, standard Tennis balls are very dangerous throw items, for large dogs in particular, as they can be punctured easily and collapse and get stuck in the dogs windpipe (trachea) and if not quickly removed can suffocate the dog. Always uses a ball on a rope when playing fetch with a dog.

Tennis balls dangerous for dogs
Some dogs enjoy shredding the yellow-green fuzz that covers the tennis ball, but your dog isn't able to digest the rubber or furry cover at all. Over time, these pieces can lead to choking hazards and intestinal blockages , creating a dangerous medical emergency that may require surgery to resolve.

column3: Tennis:
column4:
"Sometimes you're just happy playing. Some people, some media, unfortunately, don't understand that it's okay just to play tennis and enjoy it. They always think you have to win everything, it always needs to be a success story, and if it's not, obviously, what is the point? Maybe you have to go back and think, Why have I started playing tennis? Because I just like it. It's actually sort of a dream hobby that became somewhat of a job. Some people just don't get that, ever"



- In the champion's own words.

column3: Did Sir David Attenborough Invent yellow tennis balls?
column4:
Well, sort of.

Tennis balls were originally white, but in 1967, Sir David Attenborough suggested that they looked too much like the eggs of sea turtles, and should really be made a different bright color so that the turtles wouldn‚Äôt get confused.

(Wikipedia photo
 by Yosri Mohamed Yong)

Makes sense, when you think about it‚Ä¶ but sadly, I‚Äôm joking. What actually happened in 1967 was that Sir David Attenborough introduced color broadcasting on the BBC, and after watching that year‚Äôs Wimbledon tournament, he suggested that the balls be made a bright fluorescent yellow to make them easier to see on color television.

It took a few years, but most tennis balls were changed to yellow in 1972. Wimbledon was stubborn and kept using its traditional white balls until 1986!

column3: What do you think was the major problem with yesterday‚Äôs tennis match between Serena and Osaka?
column4:
I don't wish to delve into the hyperbolic tantrums thrown by Serena, as we are used to seeing her go off her rocker in a defeat. But what was repugnant to me was the distasteful, detestable gesture of the US Crowd, and some of the organizers.

Katrina Adams, The chairman of the board and president of USTA , started out by saying,

Perhaps this is not the finish we were looking for today, but Serena, you are quite a champion of champions, and Naomi, welcome to the big stage.

I was shocked to hear these words from the madam president. She was more focused on consoling Serena for the defeat than congratulating Naomi for putting up an inspiring performance to defeat the greatest women's tennis player of all time.

No wonder, we all like to see our favorite players win. No wonder, we all get shattered when someone pulls an upset of this sort, but to explicitly express that before such a large crowd, so as to bring down the morale of the young champion was completely in bad taste. Perhaps, the president must have exercised a little bit of discretion in making such unseemly statements.

In fact, Serena herself did not show much grace in defeat. She extended a cursory congratulations to her nemesis and started engaging with the crowd. Some of her words,

I'm sure that's not what we came to expect, and I'm sure we shall get through this quickly, (With a craned face)

Ostentatiously exposed her puerility and lack of grace in defeat. But I don't have much problems with that, because as players, we tend to let our emotions take the best of us.

However, the major problem, according to me, was the lack of respect showed by the disgraceful US crowd. They time and again booed the young champion and made her feel bad for defeating the best player in women's history.

After all, was it the fault of the young champion? The first player ever to win a Grand Slam for Japan? She was thoroughly embarrassed for no fault of hers. She felt so bad that she started out by apologizing to the crowd for defeating Serena.

She even sidestepped the question of how it felt to defeat her own role model Serena. This clearly shows that the young champion was deeply hurt. She hung her head in shame and would have probably cursed herself for defeating Serena.

Thanks to the US Crowd.

column3: Is Rafael Nadal's loss against Jordan Thompson an indication that he is not ready to compete at the Australian Open?
column4:
Unclear right now. He had pain in the area of his hip surgery, and he looked off as the third set progressed. He said it was not the same kind of pain that he experienced last year, so it could be muscular. That match was much more physical than the other two, which he won pretty easily, and it was the first time he played two days in a row.

I‚Äôm being optimistic and think that this is something, in the past, he would have played through. But when you‚Äôve had surgery, every pain in the area is scary. It takes a while for you to trust that the injury won‚Äôt reoccur.

I, personally, would have liked to see him skip this part of the season and start on the clay in South America (kinder on the body, especially the joints). He may or may not play AO, depending on what the scan shows. It will take a few months to know for sure if his body is going to hold up. Maybe it will; maybe it won‚Äôt. This season is one big question mark.

column3: Why doesn't Australia test Novak Djokovic to see if he has COVID or not? If negative, let him stay. If positive, let him leave Australia. What do you think?
column4: Not how it works! He lied on visa application. He was caught out attending events while apparently infectious and after he got positive result. He was late in applying for the exemption in the first place. If I tried to go to Serbia without the correct paperwork, I would be rightfully detained and sent home. As a Victorian, we have had 7 lockdowns in last 2 years. People have lost their jobs because they refuse to get vaccinated. I‚Äôve had one child with additional needs struggling as he hasnt been able to receive any therapy in 18 months. He has been having mental health problems too brought around by snap lockdowns. My other child has a social delay thanks to not getting the social opportunities they usually get as a toddler. We have sacrificed too much to have a prat like Novac come in and put us back again. Being a celebrity should not get you special treatment.

column3: What is Rafael Nadal's best victory?
column4:
That‚Äôs a tough call. In my opinion, it‚Äôs his 2022 Australian Open win over Daniil Medvedev.

There‚Äôs a lot of backstory to this win.

For one, Nadal had just missed half of the 2022 season for a recurring foot injury that had bothered him for months. This was the same foot injury that had bothered him, off-and-on, since 2005 thanks to a rare birth defect, and Nadal was almost ready to finally throw in the towel and retire, so that he could get the necessary surgery.

But instead, Nadal decided to return to the tour, making his comeback at the 2021 Mubadala World Tennis Championship, where he promptly lost in straight sets to Andy Murray. Then, he followed that up with a 3-set loss to Denis Shapovalov. Overall? Not great.

Still, Nadal was determined. He always has been. He dusted himself off, kept up the training, and launched himself into the 2022 season with everything he had.

Nadal started the 2022 season by winning in Melbourne without dropping a set, although he never faaced a seeded opponent and faced a few tiebreakers. Next up was the Australian Open, which looked like a much bigger challenge.

The Australian Open was Nadal‚Äôs least successful Grand Slam. He‚Äôd only won it once, and that was 13 years ago. If you had to pick a Grand Slam tournament he was least likely to win, this was the one.

Worst of all was his opponent: Daniil Medvedev, the same man who dispatched Novak Djokovic in straight sets at the US Open. That‚Äôs the same Novak Djokovic who won the first three Grand Slams of the year. Medvedev wasn‚Äôt supposed to stand a chance, but he won handily. The last time Nadal faced Medvedev, Daniil won in 3 sets. And that was only a year ago, on hard court. For a 35-year-old man trying to make a comeback from a foot injury, this was worst-case-scenario in many ways.

But it got worse. At his age, Nadal needed a quicker match. He couldn‚Äôt afford to rely on endurace against an opponent 10 years younger, especially on a faster hard court surface like the Australian Open. Instead, Medvedev dominated the first set (6‚Äì2) and polished off the second set with a close tiebreaker.

Nadal, the 35-year-old player just coming off a season-ending injury‚Ä¶ was now down 2 sets against the man who destroyed Djokovic in straight sets at the last Grand Slam. Again, this was worst-case scenario.

But never underestimate Rafael Nadal. His mental strength is unparalleled on the tour. He started fighting back, breaking Medvedev for a 6‚Äì4 win in the third set, then maintain that momentum in th fourth set for another 6‚Äì4 win, then finally battled his way to a 7‚Äì5 win in the deciding set. That match took 5 and a half hours, far longer than Nadal would have liked, but he did it. And thanks to that win, Nadal lead the Grand Slam race for the first time in his entire career.

That win really boosted Nadal‚Äôs 2022 season, as well. His wins at the Australian Open contributed to a 20-match winning streak, his best start to a season ever. Only an injury broke the streak. And later that year, Nadal beat Djokovic himself at the French Open, before winning his 22nd Grand Slam, increasing his lead. I don‚Äôt think anybody expected that from him, not after the injuries he‚Äôs suffered.

Fans and analysts, ever since Nadal debuted, have questioned his potential longevity. His style was so physically demanding, so dynamic, that surely he couldn‚Äôt keep it up as long as Federer or Djokovic could keep up. These wins proved them all wrong. Even at 35, even at 36, Nadal could still compete with the best and the youngest talent on the tour. Yes, his style is physically demanding and for an ordinary player, shouldn‚Äôt be sustainable. But Nadal is no ordinary player. He is a once-in-a-lifetime phenomenon and one of the greatest sportsman in history. Bravo Nadal.

column3: In tennis, how long do you have to call the ball out after it lands?
column4:
In tennis, the rule states that calls (out or let) must be made immediately after the ball has gone out of play, but before either opponent has had the opportunity to return the shot. This means you have a very limited window to make the call.

Here are some key points to remember:

"Immediately" is the key word: Don't wait to see if your opponent will hit the ball, call it out as soon as you know it's out.
Don't call before the ball lands: This can be seen as unsportsmanlike and potentially give your opponent an advantage.
Late calls have consequences: If you call late and your opponent has already started their swing, the point might be replayed or even awarded to your opponent.
Doubles vs. Singles: In doubles, you can still call a ball "out" if your partner lets it bounce first. However, this option doesn't exist in singles.

Remember, sportsmanship and fair play are crucial in tennis, so be honest and call the ball as soon as you know it's out. This will ensure a smooth and enjoyable game for all players.

column3: How unrealistic is it that a sixty-year-old would still do well at a sport like tennis, fencing, or kendo?
column4:
Depends on what you mean by ‚Äúwell‚Äù. I‚Äôm 60 and I still fence saber (well, did until COVID). I‚Äôm not going to make the Olympics or even fence at the level of good college fencers, but I can more than hold my own against a lot of younger fencers. The last tournament I entered was an open event (fencers of any age) and I placed 9th out of 26; I was eliminated by the person who eventually finished third.

As I often say (only half in jest), old age and treachery can often overcome youth and skill. You have to learn how to trick people, use their speed and aggression against them, and work on defensive maneuvers.

column3: How do you rate the tennis skills of Stanislas Wawrinka?
column4:
To unpack this question, we need to break down Wawrinka‚Äôs game into three categories: technique; movement and conditioning; and, mental toughness.

#1: TECHNIQUE

Stan Wawrinka doesn‚Äôt get the acclaim of the Big 3, but one could argue that his ball striking abilities are better than any player of his generation. If he has time to set up and hit the ball, he can outhit anyone.

Just look at what he did in the 2015 French Open, as he crushed Federer and Djokovic. In that tournament, his opponents‚Äô attacking shots were muted by the heavy, slow conditions. Wawrinka had time to set up and he simply hit them off the court.

Backhand: Wawrinka is one of only two players with a one-handed backhand who has been able to consistently step in and attack Nadal‚Äôs high bouncing cross court topspin forehands (The other was Ljubicic, who is 6‚Ä≤4‚Ä≥ - Federer has only done it for the last three years). He is also one of the only players ever who could consistently dominate Djokovic in backhand to backhand rallies.

I‚Äôve written about his backhand before: Lon Shapiro's answer to Who on the professional tour has the best one-handed backhand?

From a technique perspective, I would use Wawrinka as the ideal model to from which to learn the topspin backhand. His stroke is simple, compact and rock solid, regardless of whether he hits a low ball or a high ball.

Wawrinka is one of the few players in the world whose backhand is so good that he doesn‚Äôt even need to run around it to hit inside out forehand. In his matches against Djokovic, he could hit winners with his cross court backhand, or crush untouchable balls up the line.

While Federer has more variety and a far better slice backhand, Wawrinka‚Äôs topspin backhand is able to neutralize Djokovic, and that says a lot.

Forehand: Wawrinka hits a semi-western forehand like most of his contemporaries, but his swing is simpler and more compact than Djokovic:

Serve: Wawrinka is shorter than his Big 3 competitors, but he is the only one who is capable of hitting 130 mph. If he is hitting in those bombs consistently, he becomes very tough to break. Also, his kick second serve is good enough to give him time to set up and crush his first shot off the ground.

While he can generates power effortlessly, his slice serve isn‚Äôt at the same level as Federer, so he doesn‚Äôt dominate opponents as thoroughly as the Swiss #1.

Wawrinka is in the top 10 this year in 2nd serve points won, and fewest double faults, but he is #72 in 1st serve percentage, which drags down his percentage of service games won (#12 overall). If Wawrinka gets hot with his first serve, those are the tournaments when he can become a monster.

Serve Return: This has been Wawrinka‚Äôs biggest weakness, as he rarely drives the ball on the first serve. Because he chips the ball so much, players gain the advantage in rallies and hold serve easier.

Interesting notes about Wawrinka vs Djokovic: In 2013, when Djokovic was battling for #1, Wawrinka put his game together and forced the Serb to go to the distance at the Australian Open (12‚Äì10 in the 5th) and the US Open (6‚Äì4 in the 5h). While enjoying one of his greatest tennis seasons ever in 2015, Djokovic got manhandled by Wawrinka at the French Open, and lost again to Wawrinka in the 2016 US Open finals.

Wawrinka is now 34 years old, and in the midst of a long come back from injuries and jumped from 66 at the start of the year to his current ranking of 23.

Meanwhile, Djokovic has had a dominant run at #1, but has shown vulnerability in the early matches of tournaments. He is also battling a left shoulder injury.

These two players play a night match at the Open today, September 1st. If there‚Äôs some humidity, the conditions could be very slow and it would give Wawrinka the chance to use his power to pull off a huge upset.

I think this might be Djokovic‚Äôs toughest match. Unless his body lets him down, he has been unbeatable in the late rounds of Grand Slams, winning 4 of the last 5.

#2: MOVEMENT & CONDITIONING

Wawrinka has never been a great mover. This weakness is highlighted by his lack of success at Wimbledon, where the combination of fast courts and poor footing helps players like Djokovic, Federer and Nadal even though Wawrinka hits the ball harder than they do.

Wawrinka has won titles at the Australian, French and US Open, but has never gone past the quarters on grass. Movement is why Murray won enough to be considered for a while as part of the Big 4, while the Stanimal has only been considered a possible spoiler.

Wawrinka struggled for many years when he was young because his poor movement was magnified by poor conditioning.

#3: MENTAL TOUGHNESS

What I love about the Stan Wawrinka story is the fact that a super talented player could struggle on the circuit for years, and then finally transform himself to become a Grand Slam champion. This is the rarest type of career trajectory, and is a source of hope for anyone who struggles at their craft for years.

Wawrinka cracked the top 50 at age 21, then made the jump to the top 20 by age 23, a rise similar to other attacking players, whose games take longer to jell than defensive players. He stayed stuck at that level for 5 years, and then everything changed when he hired Magnus Norman as his coach in 2013. From there, he jumped into the top 10, won three Slams and reached a career high ranking of #3.

He stayed in the top 5 for four years until he was slowed down by a knee injury in 2017, when he stopped playing after Wimbledon and didn‚Äôt play again until the 2018 Australian Open. He struggled for a good part of the year, dropping as low as #261, and ending the year at #69.

Wawrinka is famous for pointing to his head with his finger, to affirm the mental toughness he worked so hard to gain so late in his career.

Can he do it again at age 34 and get back into the top 5?

Tonight‚Äôs match against Djokovic will give us a much better idea if he can scale the mountain again.

Thanks for the A2A.

Wawrinka is one of the few players in the world whose backhand is so good that he doesn‚Äôt even need to run around it to hit inside out forehand. In his matches against Djokovic, he could hit winners with his cross court backhand, or crush untouchable balls up the line.

While Federer has more variety and a far better slice backhand, Wawrinka‚Äôs topspin backhand is able to neutralize Djokovic, and that says a lot.

Forehand: Wawrinka hits a semi-western forehand like most of his contemporaries, but his swing is simpler and more compact than Djokovic:

Serve: Wawrinka is shorter than his Big 3 competitors, but he is the only one who is capable of hitting 130 mph. If he is hitting in those bombs consistently, he becomes very tough to break. Also, his kick second serve is good enough to give him time to set up and crush his first shot off the ground.

While he can generates power effortlessly, his slice serve isn‚Äôt at the same level as Federer, so he doesn‚Äôt dominate opponents as thoroughly as the Swiss #1.

Wawrinka is in the top 10 this year in 2nd serve points won, and fewest double faults, but he is #72 in 1st serve percentage, which drags down his percentage of service games won (#12 overall). If Wawrinka gets hot with his first serve, those are the tournaments when he can become a monster.

Serve Return: This has been Wawrinka‚Äôs biggest weakness, as he rarely drives the ball on the first serve. Because he chips the ball so much, players gain the advantage in rallies and hold serve easier.

Interesting notes about Wawrinka vs Djokovic: In 2013, when Djokovic was battling for #1, Wawrinka put his game together and forced the Serb to go to the distance at the Australian Open (12‚Äì10 in the 5th) and the US Open (6‚Äì4 in the 5h). While enjoying one of his greatest tennis seasons ever in 2015, Djokovic got manhandled by Wawrinka at the French Open, and lost again to Wawrinka in the 2016 US Open finals.

Wawrinka is now 34 years old, and in the midst of a long come back from injuries and jumped from 66 at the start of the year to his current ranking of 23.

Meanwhile, Djokovic has had a dominant run at #1, but has shown vulnerability in the early matches of tournaments. He is also battling a left shoulder injury.

These two players play a night match at the Open today, September 1st. If there‚Äôs some humidity, the conditions could be very slow and it would give Wawrinka the chance to use his power to pull off a huge upset.

I think this might be Djokovic‚Äôs toughest match. Unless his body lets him down, he has been unbeatable in the late rounds of Grand Slams, winning 4 of the last 5.

#2: MOVEMENT & CONDITIONING

Wawrinka has never been a great mover. This weakness is highlighted by his lack of success at Wimbledon, where the combination of fast courts and poor footing helps players like Djokovic, Federer and Nadal even though Wawrinka hits the ball harder than they do.

Wawrinka has won titles at the Australian, French and US Open, but has never gone past the quarters on grass. Movement is why Murray won enough to be considered for a while as part of the Big 4, while the Stanimal has only been considered a possible spoiler.

Wawrinka struggled for many years when he was young because his poor movement was magnified by poor conditioning.

#3: MENTAL TOUGHNESS

What I love about the Stan Wawrinka story is the fact that a super talented player could struggle on the circuit for years, and then finally transform himself to become a Grand Slam champion. This is the rarest type of career trajectory, and is a source of hope for anyone who struggles at their craft for years.

Wawrinka cracked the top 50 at age 21, then made the jump to the top 20 by age 23, a rise similar to other attacking players, whose games take longer to jell than defensive players. He stayed stuck at that level for 5 years, and then everything changed when he hired Magnus Norman as his coach in 2013. From there, he jumped into the top 10, won three Slams and reached a career high ranking of #3.

He stayed in the top 5 for four years until he was slowed down by a knee injury in 2017, when he stopped playing after Wimbledon and didn‚Äôt play again until the 2018 Australian Open. He struggled for a good part of the year, dropping as low as #261, and ending the year at #69.

Wawrinka is famous for pointing to his head with his finger, to affirm the mental toughness he worked so hard to gain so late in his career.

Can he do it again at age 34 and get back into the top 5?

Tonight‚Äôs match against Djokovic will give us a much better idea if he can scale the mountain again.
